docs.title: flow do
docs.text: Natural language to shell command translation

docs.title: Synopsis
docs.text: flow do [options] "<natural language description>"

docs.title: Description
docs.text: flow do translates plain English descriptions into shell commands using AI. It understands your project context and generates appropriate commands for your environment.

docs.title: Options
docs.text: Option Description -n, --dry-run Show command without executing -v, --verbose Show AI reasoning -h, --help Show help message

docs.title: Dangerous Command Detection
docs.text:
Commands that could cause data loss are flagged:

flow do "delete all files"

Output:

⚠️  DANGEROUS COMMAND DETECTED
📝 Command: rm -rf *

This command could cause data loss.
Execute anyway? [y/N]:

Dangerous patterns detected:

  • rm -rf
  • rm -r
  • > /dev/
  • mkfs
  • dd if=
  • :(){:|:&};:

docs.title: Dry Run Mode
docs.text:
Always preview before executing uncertain commands:

flow do --dry-run "remove all backup files"

Output:

🔍 Translating: "remove all backup files"
📝 Command: find . -name "*.bak" -delete

⚠️  DRY RUN - command not executed

docs.title: File Operations
docs.text:
flow do "find large files over 100MB"
# → find . -size +100M -type f

flow do "show files modified in the last hour"
# → find . -mmin -60 -type f

flow do "count lines in all zsh files"
# → find . -name "*.zsh" -exec wc -l {} +

docs.title: Git Operations
docs.text:
flow do "show commits from last week"
# → git log --since='1 week ago' --oneline

flow do "find who last modified this file"
# → git log -1 --format='%an' -- <file>

flow do "show branches merged into main"
# → git branch --merged main

docs.title: System Information
docs.text:
flow do "check disk usage"
# → df -h

flow do "show running node processes"
# → pgrep -fl node

flow do "what's using port 3000"
# → lsof -i :3000

docs.title: Project-Specific
docs.text:
The AI considers your project type:

# In an R package directory:
flow do "run the tests"
# → Rscript -e "devtools::test()"

# In a Node.js project:
flow do "run the tests"
# → npm test

# In a Quarto project:
flow do "build the document"
# → quarto render

docs.title: ADHD-Friendly Usage
docs.text:
1. Don't memorize syntax - Just describe what you want
  2. Always use --dry-run first - Build confidence before executing
  3. Be specific - "show git log" vs "show commits by me this week"

docs.title: Chaining with Other Commands
docs.text:
# Preview first, then run
flow do --dry-run "find duplicate files" && flow do "find duplicate files"

# Use output in pipes (careful!)
flow do "list all TODO comments" | head -20

docs.title: Limitations
docs.text:
• Requires Claude CLI (claude)
  • Response time: 1-3 seconds for API call
  • Complex multi-step operations may need refinement
  • Always verify generated commands before execution

docs.title: Requirements
docs.text:
• Claude CLI (claude) must be installed
  • Install: npm install -g @anthropic-ai/claude-code

docs.title: See Also
docs.text:
• flow ai - General AI assistant
  • Tutorial: AI-Powered Commands

Added in v3.2.0

docs.title: doctor - Health Check & Dependency Manager
docs.text: Command: flow doctor [options] Purpose: Check installed dependencies and optionally fix issues Type: Setup/Diagnostics Added: v3.1.0 (2025-12-26)

docs.title: Quick Summary
docs.text: The doctor command checks all flow-cli dependencies across multiple categories (required, recommended, optional, integrations, ZSH plugins). It can also interactively or automatically install missing tools using Homebrew, npm, or pip.

docs.title: Simple View
docs.text:
flowchart LR
    A([flow doctor]) --> B{Check Dependencies}
    B --> C[Display Status]
    C --> D{--fix mode?}
    D -->|yes| E[Install Missing]
    D -->|no| F([Done])
    E --> F

    style A fill:#4CAF50,stroke:#2E7D32,color:#fff
    style F fill:#2196F3,stroke:#1565C0,color:#fff

In plain words: Check → Report → (Optional) Fix

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
# Check all dependencies
flow doctor

# Interactive fix mode (prompts before each install)
flow doctor --fix

# Auto-fix mode (install all without prompts)
flow doctor --fix -y

# AI-assisted troubleshooting (via Claude CLI)
flow doctor --ai

# Verbose output
flow doctor --verbose

docs.title: Options
docs.text: Option Short Description --fix -f Enable fix mode (install missing tools) --yes -y Auto-confirm all installs (use with --fix) --ai -a AI-assisted troubleshooting via Claude CLI --verbose -v Show additional diagnostic information --help -h Show help

docs.title: Required (Core Functionality)
docs.text: Tool Purpose fzf Fuzzy finder for pick, dash -i, interactive modes

docs.title: Recommended (Enhanced Experience)
docs.text: Tool Purpose Replaces eza Modern ls with icons & git status ls bat Syntax-highlighted file viewer cat zoxide Smart directory jumping cd, z fd Fast file finder find ripgrep Fast text search grep

docs.title: Optional (Nice to Have)
docs.text: Tool Purpose Replaces dust Disk usage analyzer du duf Disk free viewer df btop System monitor top delta Better git diffs diff gh GitHub CLI - jq JSON processor -

docs.title: Integrations
docs.text: Tool Purpose Install Via atlas Session tracking & state management npm radian Enhanced R console (if R installed) pip

docs.title: ZSH Plugins (via antidote)
docs.text: Plugin Purpose powerlevel10k Modern ZSH prompt theme autosuggestions Fish-like suggestions syntax-highlighting Command syntax colors completions Extended completions

docs.title: Check Mode (Default)
docs.text:
╭─────────────────────────────────────────────╮
│  🩺 flow-cli Health Check                   │
╰─────────────────────────────────────────────╯

🐚 SHELL
  ✓ zsh          5.9
  ✓ git          2.43.0

⚡ REQUIRED (core functionality)
  ✓ fzf          0.46.0

✨ RECOMMENDED (enhanced experience)
  ✓ eza          0.18.0
  ✓ bat          0.24.0
  ✓ zoxide       0.9.2
  ✓ fd           9.0.0
  ✓ rg           14.1.0

📦 OPTIONAL (nice to have)
  ✓ dust         0.8.6
  ✓ duf          0.8.1
  ✓ btop         1.2.13
  ✓ delta        0.16.5
  ✓ gh           2.40.0
  ✓ jq           1.7

🔌 INTEGRATIONS
  ✓ atlas        1.2.0
  ✓ radian       0.6.7

🔧 ZSH PLUGINS (via antidote)
  ✓ powerlevel10k
  ✓ autosuggestions
  ✓ syntax-highlighting
  ✓ completions

🌊 FLOW-CLI
  ✓ Plugin loaded    v3.1.0
  ✓ Plugin directory ~/projects/dev-tools/flow-cli

────────────────────────────────────────────────
✅ All dependencies OK!

docs.title: With Missing Dependencies
docs.text:
⚡ REQUIRED (core functionality)
  ✗ fzf          NOT INSTALLED → brew install fzf

✨ RECOMMENDED (enhanced experience)
  ✓ eza          0.18.0
  ✗ bat          NOT INSTALLED → brew install bat
  ✓ zoxide       0.9.2
  ...

────────────────────────────────────────────────
⚠️  Some dependencies are missing

Quick fix options:
  flow doctor --fix       Interactive install (prompts each)
  flow doctor --fix -y    Auto-install all missing
  brew bundle --file=$FLOW_PLUGIN_DIR/setup/Brewfile

docs.title: Interactive Fix (--fix)
docs.text:
Prompts before each installation:

$ flow doctor --fix

Found 3 missing tools:
  1. fzf (required) - brew install fzf
  2. bat (recommended) - brew install bat
  3. dust (optional) - brew install dust

Install fzf? (y/N) y
⏳ Running: brew install fzf
✓ fzf installed successfully

Install bat? (y/N) y
⏳ Running: brew install bat
✓ bat installed successfully

Install dust? (y/N) n
⏸️  Skipped dust

────────────────────────────────────────────────
✅ Installed 2 tools, skipped 1

docs.title: Auto-Fix (--fix -y)
docs.text:
Installs all missing without prompts:

$ flow doctor --fix -y

Auto-installing 3 missing tools...

⏳ brew install fzf...
✓ fzf installed

⏳ brew install bat...
✓ bat installed

⏳ brew install dust...
✓ dust installed

────────────────────────────────────────────────
✅ Installed 3 tools

docs.title: AI Mode
docs.text:
Uses Claude CLI for intelligent troubleshooting:

$ flow doctor --ai

🤖 AI-Assisted Troubleshooting

Analyzing your environment...

Based on your flow-cli installation and missing dependencies,
here are my recommendations:

1. **fzf is required** - This is the core dependency for interactive
   project picking. Install with: brew install fzf

2. **Consider adding radian** - Since you have R installed, radian
   provides a much better console experience with syntax highlighting
   and multiline editing.

3. **Your ZSH plugins look good** - All recommended plugins are installed.

Would you like me to run the installation commands? (y/N)

docs.title: Quick Install All
docs.text:
For a complete setup, use the included Brewfile:

# Install all recommended tools at once
brew bundle --file=~/projects/dev-tools/flow-cli/setup/Brewfile

# Then verify
flow doctor

docs.title: Related Commands
docs.text: Command Purpose flow help Show all flow-cli commands flow version Show flow-cli version man flow View man page

docs.title: Issue: "brew not found"
docs.text:
Cause: Homebrew not installed

Solution:

/bin/bash -c "$(curl -fsSL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Homebrew/install/HEAD/install.sh)"

docs.title: Issue: ZSH plugin shows as missing
docs.text:
Cause: Plugin not in antidote bundle

Solution:

# Add to ~/.config/zsh/.zsh_plugins.txt
echo "romkatv/powerlevel10k" >> ~/.config/zsh/.zsh_plugins.txt

# Rebuild antidote bundle
antidote bundle < ~/.config/zsh/.zsh_plugins.txt > ~/.config/zsh/.zsh_plugins.zsh

docs.title: Issue: npm packages fail to install
docs.text:
Cause: Global npm permissions issue

Solution:

# Use npx instead of global install for atlas
npx @data-wise/atlas --version

# Or fix npm permissions
npm config set prefix ~/.npm-global
export PATH=~/.npm-global/bin:$PATH

docs.title: Source Code
docs.text:
File: commands/doctor.zsh Dependencies:

  • brew command (Homebrew)
  • npm command (optional, for atlas)
  • pip command (optional, for radian)
  • claude command (optional, for --ai mode)

Key Functions:

  • doctor() - Main entry point
  • _doctor_check_cmd() - Check individual command
  • _doctor_check_zsh_plugin() - Check ZSH plugin
  • _doctor_install() - Install missing tool
  • _doctor_help() - Display help

docs.title: Design Philosophy
docs.text:
The doctor command follows these principles:

  1. Non-Destructive - Check mode is read-only, fix mode requires explicit flag
  2. Categorized - Clear distinction between required/recommended/optional
  3. Progressive - Start with check, graduate to fix if needed
  4. Multi-Manager - Supports Homebrew, npm, and pip package managers
  5. AI-Augmented - Optional Claude integration for smart troubleshooting

docs.title: See Also
docs.text:
• Setup Guide - First-time setup
  • Brewfile - All recommended tools
  • DISPATCHER-REFERENCE.md - Command reference

Last Updated: 2025-12-26 Version: 1.0 Status: Production ready

docs.title: finish
docs.text:
End your current work session with an optional commit

The finish command cleanly ends your work session and optionally commits your changes.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text: finish [note]

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text: Argument Description Default note Session note / commit message "Work session completed"

docs.title: What It Does
docs.text:
1. Ends the session - Records session end time in atlas
  2. Detects git changes - Counts uncommitted changes
  3. Prompts for commit - Asks if you want to commit (if changes exist)
  4. Creates commit - Uses your note as the commit message

docs.title: Basic Finish
docs.text:
# End session with a note
finish "Completed feature implementation"

# End session without note
finish

docs.title: With Commit
docs.text:
$ finish "Fixed authentication bug"

# Output:
# ✓ Session ended
# Commit 3 change(s)? [y/N] y
# ✓ Changes committed: Fixed authentication bug

docs.title: Skip Commit
docs.text:
$ finish "WIP - will continue tomorrow"

# Output:
# ✓ Session ended
# Commit 5 change(s)? [y/N] n

docs.title: Session Tracking
docs.text:
When you finish, your session metrics are recorded:

  • Duration - How long you worked
  • Project - Which project you were on
  • Note - What you accomplished

View your session history:

# See today's sessions
flow status -v

# See session stats in dashboard
dash

docs.title: Git Integration
docs.text:
The finish command has smart git integration:

Scenario Behavior No git repo Skips commit prompt No changes Skips commit prompt Has changes Prompts to commit User confirms Runs git add -A && git commit

Stages All Changes

finish uses git add -A which stages all changes including new files. Review your changes before confirming the commit.

docs.title: Related Commands
docs.text: Command Description work Start a new session hop Switch projects without ending session win Log an accomplishment before finishing

docs.title: Workflow Example
docs.text:
A typical work session:

# Start
work my-project

# ... do your work ...

# Log accomplishments
win "Implemented user auth"
win "Added tests"

# End session
finish "Auth feature complete"

docs.title: Tips
docs.text:
Log Wins Before Finishing

Use win to log your accomplishments before running finish. This builds your streak and gives you a dopamine boost!

Meaningful Notes

Use descriptive notes - they become your commit messages and help you remember what you did.

docs.title: See Also
docs.text:
• work - Start a session
  • capture - Log wins and ideas
  • Workflow Quick Reference

docs.title: flow
docs.text:
Unified CLI dispatcher for all flow-cli commands

The flow command is the main entry point for the flow-cli plugin. It provides access to all subcommands through a unified namespace.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text: flow <command> [args]

docs.title: Getting Help
docs.text:
flow help              # Show all commands
flow help <command>    # Help for specific command
flow help --list       # List all commands
flow help --search <term>  # Search commands

docs.title: Core Workflow
docs.text: Command Description flow work <project> Start focused work session flow pick [category] Interactive project picker flow dash [scope] Project dashboard flow finish [note] End session, optionally commit flow hop <project> Quick switch (tmux) flow why Show current context

docs.title: ADHD Helpers
docs.text: Command Description flow start, js Just start (picks for you) flow stuck Get unstuck when blocked flow focus <text> Set current focus flow next What to work on next flow break [min] Take a proper break

docs.title: Capture & Track
docs.text: Command Description flow catch <idea> Quick capture to inbox flow crumb <note> Leave breadcrumb flow inbox View inbox flow win <text> Log a win flow goal [set n] Daily win goal tracking flow status View/update .STATUS file

docs.title: Context-Aware Actions
docs.text: Command Description flow test Run tests (auto-detects type) flow build Build project flow preview Preview output flow sync Smart git sync flow check Health check (lint, types) flow plan Sprint/project planning flow log Activity log

docs.title: Timer & Routine
docs.text: Command Description flow timer [min] Start focus timer flow morning Morning startup routine

docs.title: Setup & Diagnostics
docs.text: Command Description flow doctor Check dependencies & health flow setup Interactive setup wizard flow install Install tools flow upgrade Update flow-cli flow learn Interactive tutorial

docs.title: AI-Powered
docs.text: Command Description flow ai <query> Ask AI anything flow do "request" Natural language commands

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text: Command Description flow config show Show settings flow config set Set a config value flow plugin Manage plugins

docs.title: Direct Command Access
docs.text:
Most commands work directly without the flow prefix:

# These are equivalent:
flow work my-project
work my-project

# Direct access commands:
work, pick, dash, finish, hop, why
catch, crumb, inbox, win
timer, morning
doctor, status

docs.title: Starting Your Day
docs.text:
# Morning routine
flow morning

# Or quick version
am

# Start working
flow work my-project
# or just
work my-project

docs.title: During Work
docs.text:
# Log wins as you go
flow win "Fixed the auth bug"

# Check progress
flow status

# Take a break
flow break 5

docs.title: Context-Aware Actions
docs.text:
# Run tests (auto-detects R/Node/Python)
flow test

# Build project (auto-detects Quarto/npm/R CMD)
flow build

# Preview output
flow preview

docs.title: Getting Help
docs.text:
# Search for git-related commands
flow help --search git

# Get help on sync
flow help sync

# List all available commands
flow help --list

docs.title: Dispatchers
docs.text:
Flow-cli includes domain-specific dispatchers that are separate from the flow command:

Dispatcher Domain Example g Git workflows g push, g status r R package dev r test, r check qu Quarto publishing qu preview mcp MCP servers mcp status obs Obsidian notes obs daily cc Claude Code cc, cc pick

Get help for any dispatcher with <dispatcher> help.

docs.title: Version
docs.text:
flow version
# flow-cli v4.0.1

docs.title: Tips
docs.text:
Use Direct Commands

For common commands like work, dash, pick, skip the flow prefix for speed.

Search When Unsure

Use flow help --search <term> to find commands you don't remember.

Tab Completion

If you have completions installed, flow <Tab> shows available commands.

docs.title: Related
docs.text:
• Command Quick Reference
  • Dispatcher Reference
  • Getting Started

docs.title: hop
docs.text:
Quick project switch with tmux session management

The hop command provides fast project switching, especially powerful when using tmux. It creates or switches to project-specific tmux sessions.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text: hop [project]

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text: Argument Description Default project Project name to switch to Interactive picker (fzf)

docs.title: What It Does
docs.text:
1. Without tmux - Simple cd to project directory
  2. With tmux - Creates or switches to a named tmux session for the project

docs.title: Tmux Behavior
docs.text:
When running inside tmux:

  • Session exists - Switches to the existing session
  • Session doesn't exist - Creates new session in project directory
  • Session naming - Uses sanitized project name (replaces special chars with _)

docs.title: Basic Switch
docs.text:
# Switch to a project
hop flow-cli

# Interactive picker (if no project specified)
hop

docs.title: With Tmux
docs.text:
# Creates/switches to 'flow_cli' tmux session
hop flow-cli

# View all tmux sessions
tmux list-sessions

docs.title: Without Tmux
docs.text:
# Simply changes to project directory
hop my-project
# Changed to: my-project (start tmux for session management)

docs.title: Output
docs.text:
With tmux:

✓ Hopped to: flow-cli

Without tmux:

ℹ Changed to: my-project (start tmux for session management)

docs.title: hop vs work
docs.text:
Feature hop work Session tracking No Yes (atlas) Editor launch No Yes Context display No Yes (.STATUS shown) Tmux integration Full (creates sessions) No Speed Instant Slightly slower (setup) Use case Quick context switches Starting focused work

Rule of thumb:

  • Use work when starting a focused work block
  • Use hop when quickly checking something in another project

docs.title: Tmux Tips
docs.text:
View All Sessions

```bash # List all tmux sessions tmux ls

# Kill a specific session
tmux kill-session -t session_name
```

Detach and Return

bash # Detach from current session: Ctrl-b d # Then hop to another project hop other-project

docs.title: Related Commands
docs.text: Command Description work Start focused session (with editor) pick Interactive project picker dash View all projects dashboard

docs.title: See Also
docs.text:
• work - Start a full work session
  • pick - Interactive project picker
  • Workflow Quick Reference

docs.title: flow install
docs.text: Profile-based tool installation

docs.title: Synopsis
docs.text:
flow install [options]
flow install --profile <name>
flow install --category <name>
flow install <tool> [tool...]

docs.title: Description
docs.text: flow install provides a convenient way to install recommended CLI tools using Homebrew. It supports profile-based installation for different workflows and category-based installation for specific tool groups.

docs.title: Options
docs.text: Option Description -p, --profile <name> Install tools from a profile -c, --category <name> Install tools from a category -n, --dry-run Show what would be installed -f, --force Reinstall even if present -l, --list List available profiles and categories -h, --help Show help message

docs.title: Profiles
docs.text: Profile Tools Use Case minimal fzf, zoxide, bat Essential tools only developer + eza, fd, rg, gh, delta, jq Full development setup researcher + quarto Academic writing writer + pandoc, quarto Publishing workflows full + dust, duf, btop Everything

docs.title: Profile Details
docs.text:
minimal (3 tools)

fzf      - Fuzzy finder (required for pick, dash-tui)
zoxide   - Smart cd replacement
bat      - Cat with syntax highlighting

developer (9 tools)

+ eza    - Modern ls replacement
+ fd     - Fast file finder
+ rg     - Ripgrep (fast grep)
+ gh     - GitHub CLI
+ delta  - Git diff viewer
+ jq     - JSON processor

researcher (10 tools)

+ quarto - Scientific publishing

writer (5 tools)

fzf, bat, pandoc, quarto

full (13 tools)

+ dust   - Disk usage analyzer
+ duf    - Disk free viewer
+ btop   - System monitor

docs.title: Categories
docs.text: Category Tools core fzf, bat, eza productivity zoxide, fzf git gh, delta dev fd, rg, jq research quarto, pandoc

docs.title: Interactive Installation
docs.text:
flow install

Launches an interactive menu to select tools.

docs.title: Profile-Based
docs.text:
# Essential tools only
flow install --profile minimal

# Full developer setup
flow install --profile developer

# Academic workflow
flow install --profile researcher

docs.title: Category-Based
docs.text:
# Just git tools
flow install --category git

# Core productivity tools
flow install --category core

docs.title: Individual Tools
docs.text:
# Install specific tools
flow install fzf bat eza

docs.title: Dry Run
docs.text:
# See what would be installed
flow install --profile developer --dry-run

Output:

🔍 DRY RUN - Would install:
  • fzf
  • zoxide
  • bat
  • eza
  • fd
  • rg (ripgrep)
  • gh
  • delta (git-delta)
  • jq

Total: 9 tools

docs.title: List Available Options
docs.text: flow install --list

docs.title: Requirements
docs.text:
• Homebrew must be installed
  • macOS or Linux with Linuxbrew

docs.title: Related Commands
docs.text:
• flow doctor - Check which tools are installed
  • flow upgrade - Update installed tools

docs.text:

  • Brewfile

docs.title: morning
docs.text:
ADHD-friendly daily startup routine

The morning command provides a structured startup routine to reduce decision fatigue and get you working faster. It shows your inbox, active projects, yesterday's wins, and suggests what to work on.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text: morning [options]

docs.title: Options
docs.text: Flag Short Description --quick -q Quick summary only

docs.title: What It Shows
docs.text:
The full morning command displays:

  1. Inbox count - Captured ideas awaiting review
  2. Active projects - Top 5 with progress and focus
  3. Yesterday's wins - Recent accomplishments
  4. Suggestion - What to work on next

docs.title: Full Morning Routine
docs.text:
morning

Output:

━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━
  ☀️  GOOD MORNING
━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━

  📥 3 items in inbox

  Active Projects:
     🔧 flow-cli        [ 85%] → Documentation enhancement
     📦 rmediation      [ 60%] → CRAN submission prep
     🎓 stat-440        [ 40%] → Week 12 materials

  Yesterday's wins:
     💻 Implemented dark mode toggle
     🔧 Fixed session tracking bug

  💡 Suggestion:
     Work on flow-cli
     Run: work flow-cli

━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━
  Ready to start? Try: js (just-start) or work <project>
━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━

docs.title: Quick Mode
docs.text:
morning -q
# or
am

Output:

  📥 3 inbox  │  📂 5 active projects

  → js to start working

docs.title: today
docs.text:
Quick daily status showing current session and today's wins:

today

Output:

📅 TODAY Friday, December 27

  🎯 Working on: flow-cli (2h 15m)

  Today's wins:
     💻 Added hop command documentation
     📝 Updated Quick Start guide

  Active Projects:
     🔧 flow-cli        [ 85%] → Documentation enhancement

docs.title: week
docs.text:
Weekly review helper showing session stats and wins:

week

Output:

📊 WEEKLY REVIEW
Week of December 27, 2025

  Sessions this week:
    Mon: flow-cli (3h), rmediation (1h)
    Tue: stat-440 (2h)
    Wed: flow-cli (4h)
    ...

  Wins this week:
     🚀 Deployed v4.0.1
     💻 Added win categories
     📝 Updated documentation
     ...

  Take a moment to celebrate progress! 🎉

docs.title: Aliases
docs.text: Alias Command am morning -q

docs.title: How Suggestions Work
docs.text:
The morning command suggests projects based on:

  1. Priority - P1/P0 projects are suggested first
  2. Status - Active projects only
  3. Recency - Recently worked projects get priority

docs.title: Tips
docs.text:
Make It a Habit

Run morning as the first command when you open your terminal. It sets the context for your day.

Quick Mode for Busy Days

Use morning -q (or just am) when you're in a rush but still want to see the essentials.

Follow the Suggestion

If you're not sure what to work on, just follow the suggestion. Reducing decision fatigue is the goal.

Use with js

After morning, run js (just-start) to let the system pick and open a project for you automatically.

docs.title: Workflow Example
docs.text:
# Start your day
morning

# Follow the suggestion or pick your own
work flow-cli     # Explicit choice
# or
js                # Let system decide

# ... do your work ...

# Check progress later
today

# End of week
week              # Review accomplishments

docs.title: Related Commands
docs.text: Command Description work Start focused work session dash Project dashboard js Just start (auto-picks project) timer Focus timer capture View inbox with inbox

docs.text:

docs.title: pick
docs.text:
Interactive project picker with fzf

The pick command provides an interactive, ADHD-friendly way to select and navigate to projects. It supports category filtering, fuzzy matching, and smart session resume.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text: pick [options] [category|project-name]

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text: Argument Description category Filter by category (r, dev, q, etc.) project-name Fuzzy match for direct jump

docs.title: Options
docs.text: Flag Description --fast Skip git status checks (faster loading) -a, --all Force full picker (skip direct jump)

docs.title: Categories
docs.text: Shortcut Category Icon r, R, rpkg R packages 📦 dev, DEV Development tools 🔧 q, qu, quarto Quarto projects 📝 teach, teaching Teaching courses 🎓 rs, research Research projects 🔬 app, apps Applications 📱

docs.title: Interactive Picker
docs.text:
# Show all projects
pick

# Filter by category
pick dev         # Development tools only
pick r           # R packages only
pick teach       # Teaching courses only

docs.title: Direct Jump
docs.text:
# Jump directly to matching project
pick flow        # → cd to flow-cli (if unique match)
pick med         # → cd to mediationverse

# If multiple matches, shows filtered picker
pick stat        # Shows all projects containing "stat"

docs.title: Category Aliases
docs.text:
pickr            # pick r
pickdev          # pick dev
pickq            # pick q

docs.title: Smart Resume
docs.text:
When you run pick without arguments and have a recent session (< 24 hours), you'll see:

╔════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════╗
║  🔍 PROJECT PICKER                                          ║
╚════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════╝

  💡 Last: flow-cli (2h ago)
  [Enter] Resume  │  [Space] Browse all  │  Type to search...
Key Action Enter Resume last project Space Bypass resume, show full picker Type Search/filter projects

docs.title: Interactive Keys
docs.text:
While in the fzf picker:

Key Action Enter Go to project directory Ctrl-S View .STATUS file Ctrl-L View git log Ctrl-C Exit without action

docs.title: Output
docs.text:
When selecting a project:

  📂 /Users/dt/projects/dev-tools/flow-cli

When viewing .STATUS (Ctrl-S):

  📊 .STATUS file for: flow-cli

  ## Status: Active
  ## Phase: v4.0.1 Released
  ## Focus: Documentation enhancement

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text:
Projects are discovered from $FLOW_PROJECTS_ROOT (default: ~/projects). Categories are defined in:

PROJ_CATEGORIES=(
    "r-packages/active:r:📦"
    "r-packages/stable:r:📦"
    "dev-tools:dev:🔧"
    "teaching:teach:🎓"
    "research:rs:🔬"
    "quarto/manuscripts:q:📝"
    "quarto/presentations:q:📊"
    "apps:app:📱"
)

docs.title: Tips
docs.text:
Direct Jump for Speed

If you know your project name, use direct jump: pick flow is faster than browsing the full picker.

Category Filtering

When you have many projects, filter by category first: pick dev shows only dev tools.

Resume Your Session

Just press Enter when the resume hint appears to continue where you left off.

docs.title: Related Commands
docs.text: Command Description work Start session (includes pick) hop Quick switch (tmux) dash View all projects dashboard

docs.title: See Also
docs.text:
• work - Start a full work session
  • hop - Quick project switch with tmux
  • Workflow Quick Reference

docs.title: flow plugin
docs.text: Plugin management for flow-cli extensions

docs.title: Synopsis
docs.text:
flow plugin [command] [options]
flow plugin list
flow plugin install <path|gh:user/repo>
flow plugin create <name>

docs.title: Description
docs.text: flow plugin manages the flow-cli plugin system. Plugins extend flow-cli with new commands, hooks, and functionality without modifying the core codebase.

docs.title: Commands
docs.text: Command Description list List all installed plugins enable <name> Enable a disabled plugin disable <name> Disable a plugin (persists across sessions) create <name> Create a new plugin from template install <path> Install plugin from local path install gh:user/repo Install plugin from GitHub remove <name> Remove a user-installed plugin info <name> Show plugin details hooks Show all registered hooks path Show plugin search paths

docs.title: Plugin Search Paths
docs.text:
Plugins are discovered in these locations:

  1. ~/.config/flow/plugins/ - User plugins
  2. ~/.local/share/flow/plugins/ - Installed plugins
  3. <flow-cli>/plugins/ - Bundled plugins

docs.title: Hook System
docs.text:
Plugins can register callbacks for these events:

Hook Trigger Use Case post-work After work command Project setup, notifications pre-finish Before finish command Validation, cleanup post-finish After finish command Notifications, stats session-start When session begins Logging, timers session-end When session ends Cleanup, reporting project-change On chpwd in project Context switching pre-command Before any command Logging, validation post-command After any command Stats, notifications

docs.title: List Plugins
docs.text:
flow plugin list

Output:

INSTALLED PLUGINS

  example  v1.0.0  [enabled]
    Example plugin demonstrating capabilities
    Path: ~/.config/flow/plugins/example

  TOTALS
    Installed: 1
    Enabled: 1

docs.title: Create a Plugin
docs.text:
flow plugin create my-plugin

Creates:

~/.config/flow/plugins/my-plugin/
├── main.zsh          # Plugin entry point
├── plugin.json       # Metadata (optional)
└── README.md         # Documentation

docs.title: Install from GitHub
docs.text:
# Install from GitHub
flow plugin install gh:username/flow-plugin-name

# Install as dev (symlink)
flow plugin install --dev ~/code/my-plugin

docs.title: Enable/Disable
docs.text:
# Disable a plugin
flow plugin disable example

# Re-enable it
flow plugin enable example

docs.title: View Hook Registrations
docs.text:
flow plugin hooks

Output:

REGISTERED HOOKS

  post-work:
    _example_on_work (example)

  session-start:
    _example_on_session (example)

  TOTALS
    Events with hooks: 2
    Total callbacks: 2

docs.title: Minimal Plugin (Single File)
docs.text:
~/.config/flow/plugins/hello/main.zsh:

# Register the plugin
_flow_plugin_register "hello" "1.0.0" "Says hello"

# Define commands
hello() {
    echo "Hello from my plugin!"
}

docs.title: Plugin with Hooks
docs.text:
_flow_plugin_register "notify" "1.0.0" "Desktop notifications"

# Register hook callback
_notify_on_finish() {
    local project="$1"
    osascript -e "display notification \"Finished $project\" with title \"flow-cli\""
}
_flow_hook_register "post-finish" "_notify_on_finish"

docs.title: Plugin with Dependencies
docs.text:
_flow_plugin_register "git-stats" "1.0.0" "Git statistics"

# Check dependencies
_flow_plugin_require_tool "git" || return 1
_flow_plugin_require_tool "gh" || return 1

# Plugin code here...

docs.title: Plugin Metadata (plugin.json)
docs.text:
{
  "name": "my-plugin",
  "version": "1.0.0",
  "description": "My awesome plugin",
  "author": "Your Name",
  "requires": {
    "flow": ">=3.3.0",
    "tools": ["git", "fzf"]
  },
  "hooks": ["post-work", "post-finish"]
}

docs.title: Registration
docs.text:
# Register plugin
_flow_plugin_register "name" "version" "description"

# Check if plugin exists
_flow_plugin_exists "name"

# Get plugin info
_flow_plugin_info "name"

docs.title: Hooks
docs.text:
# Register hook callback
_flow_hook_register "event-name" "callback_function"

# Run hooks for an event
_flow_hook_run "event-name" "$arg1" "$arg2"

docs.title: Dependencies
docs.text:
# Require a CLI tool
_flow_plugin_require_tool "tool-name"

# Require flow version
_flow_plugin_require_version "3.3.0"

docs.title: Logging
docs.text:
# Use flow-cli logging
_flow_log_success "Operation complete"
_flow_log_error "Something went wrong"
_flow_log_warning "Watch out"
_flow_log_debug "Debug info"

docs.title: Plugin Registry
docs.text:
Disabled plugins are tracked in:

~/.config/flow/plugin-registry.json

Format:

{
  "disabled": ["plugin-a", "plugin-b"],
  "settings": {}
}

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
1. Use unique prefixes - Prefix functions with plugin name (e.g., _myplugin_func)
  2. Check dependencies - Use _flow_plugin_require_tool for external tools
  3. Handle errors gracefully - Don't break flow-cli if plugin fails
  4. Document hooks - Specify which hooks your plugin uses
  5. Keep it focused - One plugin, one purpose

docs.title: Related Commands
docs.text:
• flow config - Configuration management
  • flow doctor - Check system health

docs.title: See Also
docs.text:
• Contributing Guide
  • Example Plugin

Added in v3.3.0

docs.title: Command Reference: flow status
docs.text: Complete reference for the flow status command - update and query project status.

docs.title: Synopsis
docs.text:
flow status [project] [options]
flow status [project] <status> <priority> <task> <progress>
flow status --help

docs.title: Description
docs.text:
The flow status command manages project metadata stored in .STATUS files. It tracks:

  • Project status (active, ready, paused, blocked)
  • Priority level (P0, P1, P2)
  • Current task description
  • Progress percentage (0-100)
  • Last update timestamp
  • Project category and type

docs.title: Interactive Mode (Recommended)
docs.text:
Prompts you for each field:

flow status mediationverse

Example interaction:

📋 UPDATE STATUS: mediationverse
═══════════════════════════════════════════

Current values shown in [brackets]

Status? [active]
   (active/paused/blocked/ready)
> active

Priority? [P0]
   (P0=critical, P1=important, P2=normal)
> P0

Next task? [Run final simulations]
> Complete simulations and write up results

Progress? [85]
   (0-100)
> 90

✅ Updated! Press Enter to continue...

docs.title: Quick Mode
docs.text:
Provide all values at once:

flow status <project> <status> <priority> <task> <progress>

Example:

flow status mediationverse active P0 "Complete sims" 90

docs.title: Create Mode
docs.text:
Initialize a new .STATUS file:

flow status newproject --create

docs.title: Show Mode
docs.text:
View status without updating:

flow status mediationverse --show

docs.title: project
docs.text:
Project name to update (optional if in project directory):

# Update specific project
flow status mediationverse

# Update current project
cd ~/projects/r-packages/active/mediationverse
flow status .

docs.title: status
docs.text:
Project status (one of):

Value Meaning When to Use active Currently working on Project is your focus right now ready Ready to start All prerequisites met paused Temporarily on hold Will resume later blocked Waiting on something Can't proceed until X happens

Examples:

flow status proj active   # Working on it now
flow status proj paused   # On hold
flow status proj blocked  # Waiting for review/approval
flow status proj ready    # Ready when you are

docs.title: priority
docs.text:
Priority level (one of):

Value Meaning How Many? P0 Critical, urgent 1-2 max P1 Important 2-3 P2 Normal Unlimited

Examples:

flow status proj active P0   # Critical priority
flow status proj active P1   # Important priority
flow status proj active P2   # Normal priority

Guidelines:

  • P0: Must be done today/this week
  • P1: Should be done this week/month
  • P2: Nice to have, do when time permits

Warning: Too many P0 projects = everything urgent = nothing urgent

docs.title: task
docs.text:
Next action description (quoted string):

flow status proj active P0 "Run final simulations" 85

Good task descriptions:

  • ✅ "Grade 20 midterm exams"
  • ✅ "Fix bug in calculation function"
  • ✅ "Write introduction section"
  • ✅ "Complete simulation study"

Poor task descriptions:

  • ❌ "Work on it"
  • ❌ "Continue"
  • ❌ "More stuff"
  • ❌ "TODO"

Tips:

  • Be specific (what exactly?)
  • Use action verbs (Grade, Fix, Write, Complete)
  • Include quantities when relevant (20 exams, 3 bugs, 2 sections)

docs.title: progress
docs.text:
Progress percentage (0-100):

flow status proj active P0 "Task" 75

Progress guidelines:

Range Milestone 0% Just started / Planning 25% Foundation complete 50% Core features done 75% Integration complete 90% Polish and testing 100% Complete and shipped

Tips:

  • Update in small increments (5-10%)
  • Be honest (accurate > inflated)
  • Expect 80-100% to be slow
  • Celebrate milestones (25%, 50%, 75%, 100%)

docs.title: --create
docs.text:
Create new .STATUS file for project:

flow status newproject --create

What it does:

  1. Detects project type (R package, Quarto, etc.)
  2. Creates .STATUS file with defaults
  3. Prompts for initial values

Example:

cd ~/projects/r-packages/active/newpackage
flow status newpackage --create

# Creates:
project: newpackage
type: r-package
status: ready
priority: P2
progress: 0
next: Define first task
updated: 2025-12-24
category: r-packages

docs.title: --show
docs.text:
Display status without updating:

flow status mediationverse --show

Output:

📦 mediationverse
═══════════════════════════════════════════
Status:   🔥 ACTIVE
Priority: [P0] Critical
Progress: ████████░░ 85%
Task:     Run final simulations
Updated:  2025-12-24 10:30 AM
Category: r-packages
Type:     r-package

Location: ~/projects/r-packages/active/mediationverse

docs.title: --json
docs.text:
Output in JSON format (useful for scripts):

flow status mediationverse --json

Output:

{
  "project": "mediationverse",
  "status": "active",
  "priority": "P0",
  "progress": 85,
  "task": "Run final simulations",
  "updated": "2025-12-24T15:30:00Z",
  "category": "r-packages",
  "type": "r-package",
  "location": "~/projects/r-packages/active/mediationverse"
}

docs.title: --help, -h
docs.text:
Show help message:

flow status --help

docs.title: Example 1: Start Tracking New Project
docs.text:
cd ~/projects/research/new-study
flow status new-study --create
flow status new-study ready P2 "Literature review" 0

docs.title: Example 2: Daily Updates
docs.text:
# Morning: Start work
flow status mediationverse active P0 "Begin simulations" 80

# Midday: Progress update
flow status mediationverse active P0 "Halfway through sims" 85

# End of day: Save state
flow status mediationverse paused P0 "Resume tomorrow - 2 sims left" 90

docs.title: Example 3: Project State Changes
docs.text:
# Start working
flow status proj ready P2 "Initial task" 0
flow status proj active P1 "Actually started!" 5

# Make progress
flow status proj active P1 "Core complete" 50

# Hit a blocker
flow status proj blocked P1 "Waiting for data from collaborator" 50

# Unblocked, resume
flow status proj active P0 "Got data - final push!" 75

# Complete
flow status proj ready P2 "Done!" 100

docs.title: Example 4: Batch Updates
docs.text:
# Update multiple projects (shell script)
flow status proj1 active P0 "Task A" 80
flow status proj2 paused P1 "On hold" 50
flow status proj3 active P1 "Task B" 60
flow status proj4 ready P2 "Not started" 0

# Verify
flow dash

docs.title: Example 5: Integration with Other Commands
docs.text:
# After working
work mediationverse
# ... do work ...
flow status . active P0 "Completed feature X" 90

# After git commit
git add . && git commit -m "feat: add feature X"
flow status . active P0 "Feature X committed" 95

# After testing
npm test
flow status . active P0 "All tests passing!" 100

docs.title: .STATUS File Format
docs.text:
Located at project root: ~/projects/category/project/.STATUS

Example file:

project: mediationverse
type: r-package
status: active
priority: P0
progress: 85
next: Run final simulations
updated: 2025-12-24
category: r-packages
location: ~/projects/r-packages/active/mediationverse

Fields:

  • project: Project name
  • type: Detected type (r-package, quarto, teaching, research, dev-tools)
  • status: Current status (active/ready/paused/blocked)
  • priority: Priority level (P0/P1/P2)
  • progress: Percentage (0-100)
  • next: Next action description
  • updated: Last update date (YYYY-MM-DD)
  • category: Project category
  • location: Full path to project

docs.title: Exit Status
docs.text: Code Meaning 0 Success 1 Invalid arguments 2 Project not found 3 Permission denied 4 Invalid status value

docs.title: FLOW_CLI_HOME
docs.text:
Override default config directory:

export FLOW_CLI_HOME=~/.flow-cli
flow status proj --show

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
Update frequency:

  • Daily: Active P0 projects
  • Weekly: Active P1/P2 projects
  • Monthly: Paused/blocked projects

Progress accuracy:

  • Update in 5-10% increments
  • Be conservative (better to underestimate)
  • Don't wait for "perfect" 100%

Task descriptions:

  • Specific action verbs
  • Clear completion criteria
  • Next concrete step

docs.title: Integration with Dashboard
docs.text:
Status updates appear in:

flow dash              # Terminal dashboard
flow dashboard --web   # Web dashboard

Both auto-refresh to show latest status.

docs.title: Version Control
docs.text:
Add .STATUS to git:

git add .STATUS
git commit -m "docs: update project status"

Or gitignore it:

echo ".STATUS" >> .gitignore

Choose based on whether you want to share status with collaborators.

docs.title: See Also
docs.text:
• flow dashboard - View all project statuses
  • work - Start working on a project
  • dash - Quick dashboard alias
  • Tutorial 1: First Session
  • Tutorial 3: Status Visualizations

docs.title: History
docs.text:
• v1.0 (2025-12-14) - Initial implementation
  • v1.1 (2025-12-21) - Added --json flag
  • v1.2 (2025-12-24) - Added interactive mode improvements

Last updated: 2025-12-24

docs.title: flow sync
docs.text:
Unified sync orchestration for flow-cli v4.0.0

Synchronize workflow data across all flow-cli components with a single command. Designed for ADHD-friendly operation with smart detection, clear feedback, and safe defaults.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
flow sync              # Smart sync - see what needs syncing
flow sync all          # Sync everything
flow sync --status     # View sync dashboard

docs.title: Synopsis
docs.text: flow sync [target] [options]

docs.title: Targets
docs.text: Target Description Speed session Persist current session data to worklog ~2ms status Update .STATUS timestamps and streaks ~120ms wins Aggregate project wins to global wins.md ~15ms goals Recalculate daily goal progress ~5ms git Smart git push/pull with stash handling ~1.2s remote iCloud sync for multi-device access ~10ms all Run all targets in dependency order ~1.4s (none) Smart sync - auto-detect what needs syncing ~50ms

docs.title: Options
docs.text: Option Short Description --dry-run -n Preview changes without executing --verbose -v Show detailed output --quiet -q Minimal output (for scripts) --skip-git Skip git sync for quick local sync --status Show sync dashboard --help -h Show help message

docs.title: Basic Usage
docs.text:
# See what needs syncing (smart detection)
flow sync

# Sync everything
flow sync all

# Preview what would happen
flow sync all --dry-run

# Quick local sync (skip git)
flow sync all --skip-git

docs.title: Individual Targets
docs.text:
# Update .STATUS files only
flow sync status

# Aggregate wins across projects
flow sync wins

# Recalculate goal progress
flow sync goals

# Sync git (fetch, rebase, push)
flow sync git

docs.title: Scripting
docs.text:
# Quiet mode for scripts
flow sync all --quiet

# Check sync status
flow sync --status

docs.title: flow sync session
docs.text:
Persists the current work session to the worklog.

  • Reads: $FLOW_DATA_DIR/.current-session
  • Writes: $FLOW_DATA_DIR/worklog
  • Output: Duration and project name (e.g., "45m on flow-cli")

Use this to capture session data without ending the session.

docs.title: flow sync status
docs.text:
Updates .STATUS files for recently active projects.

  • Scans: $FLOW_PROJECTS_ROOT/**/.STATUS
  • Updates: last_active timestamp
  • Triggers: Streak updates (if configured)

Only updates files modified in the last hour (avoids touching inactive projects).

docs.title: flow sync wins
docs.text:
Aggregates project-level wins to a global wins file.

  • Scans: .STATUS files with wins: field
  • Writes: $FLOW_DATA_DIR/wins.md
  • Deduplicates: Won't add the same win twice

Useful for seeing all accomplishments across projects in one place.

docs.title: flow sync goals
docs.text:
Recalculates daily goal progress based on wins.

  • Reads: $FLOW_DATA_DIR/wins.md
  • Reads: $FLOW_DATA_DIR/goal.json (for target)
  • Writes: Updated $FLOW_DATA_DIR/goal.json
  • Output: Progress (e.g., "5/3 (100%)")

docs.title: flow sync remote
docs.text:
iCloud sync for multi-device access (v4.7.0+).

flow sync remote              # Show sync status
flow sync remote init         # Set up iCloud sync
flow sync remote disable      # Revert to local storage

Setup:

  1. Run flow sync remote init to migrate core data to iCloud
  2. Add source ~/.config/flow/remote.conf to your ~/.zshrc
  3. Restart shell - Apple handles sync automatically

Synced data:

  • wins.md - Daily accomplishments
  • goal.json - Daily goal progress
  • sync-state.json - Last sync metadata

Multi-device:

  • Same iCloud account = automatic sync across devices
  • Works offline (syncs when connected)
  • No conflicts with local-only data (worklog, inbox)

iCloud path: ~/Library/Mobile Documents/com~apple~CloudDocs/flow-cli/

docs.title: flow sync git
docs.text:
Smart git synchronization with safety features.

Workflow:

  1. Stash uncommitted changes (if any)
  2. Fetch from remote
  3. Rebase if behind remote
  4. Push if ahead
  5. Pop stash

Safety:

  • Auto-aborts on rebase conflicts
  • Restores stash on any failure
  • Reports ahead/behind status

docs.title: Execution Order
docs.text:
When running flow sync all, targets execute in dependency order:

session → status → wins → goals → git
   ↓         ↓        ↓       ↓      ↓
 (2ms)    (120ms)  (15ms)  (5ms)  (1.2s)
  • Session must run first (captures current state)
  • Status updates timestamps before win aggregation
  • Wins aggregates before goal calculation
  • Goals calculates progress from wins
  • Git runs last (longest operation, optional)

docs.title: Standard Output
docs.text:
🔄 Syncing flow-cli
━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━
  [1/5] session... done (45m on flow-cli)
  [2/5] status... done (2 projects updated)
  [3/5] wins... done (3 new wins aggregated)
  [4/5] goals... done (5/3 (100%))
  [5/5] git... done (pushed 2 commits)

✓ Sync complete (1.4s)

docs.title: Quiet Output
docs.text: With --quiet, only errors are shown.

docs.title: Dry Run Output
docs.text:
🔍 Dry run - no changes will be made

  [1/5] session... Would log: 45m on flow-cli
  [2/5] status... Would update: 2 projects
  ...

Run without --dry-run to execute

docs.title: State File
docs.text:
Sync state is stored in $FLOW_DATA_DIR/sync-state.json:

{
  "last_sync": {
    "all": "2025-12-27T14:07:57Z"
  },
  "results": {
    "session": "success",
    "status": "success",
    "wins": "success",
    "goals": "success",
    "git": "skipped"
  }
}

View with flow sync --status.

docs.title: Error Handling
docs.text: Scenario Behavior Network timeout Log warning, continue Missing directory Log error, abort Git merge conflict Abort, restore stash, provide steps Optional dependency missing Skip silently

docs.title: Recovery
docs.text:
If git sync fails with a conflict:

# View conflict
git status

# Option 1: Abort and sync again later
git rebase --abort

# Option 2: Resolve and continue
git add <resolved-files>
git rebase --continue
git push

docs.title: With finish Command
docs.text:
The finish command can optionally sync before ending a session:

finish "Completed feature"  # Commits and optionally syncs

docs.title: With dash Command
docs.text:
The dashboard shows sync status:

dash          # Shows last sync time
dash --watch  # Auto-refreshes with sync status

docs.title: With CI/CD
docs.text:
# In a pre-push hook
flow sync all --quiet || exit 1

docs.title: Environment Variables
docs.text: Variable Default Description FLOW_DATA_DIR ~/.local/share/flow Data storage location FLOW_PROJECTS_ROOT ~/projects Root for project scanning

docs.title: Related Commands
docs.text:
• flow goal - Manage daily goals
  • win - Log accomplishments
  • dash - Project dashboard
  • finish - End work session

docs.title: Scheduled Sync
docs.text:
Enable automatic background sync using macOS launchd:

flow sync schedule                 # Show status
flow sync schedule enable          # Every 30 minutes
flow sync schedule enable 15       # Every 15 minutes
flow sync schedule disable         # Stop scheduled sync
flow sync schedule logs            # View logs

What runs: session, status, wins, goals (git is skipped - requires user interaction)

docs.title: Version History
docs.text:
Version Changes v4.0.0 Initial release with 5 sync targets v4.0.1 Added schedule for automated background sync v4.7.0 Added remote for iCloud multi-device sync

See also: Dopamine Features Guide for win tracking and goals.

docs.title: timer
docs.text:
Focus and break timer for ADHD-friendly time management

The timer command provides Pomodoro-style focus timers with visual countdown, break reminders, and macOS notifications.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text: timer [command] [options]

docs.title: Commands
docs.text: Command Alias Description [minutes] - Start focus timer (default: 25) focus - Start focus session break brk Start break timer (default: 5) pomodoro pom Run pomodoro cycles stop - Cancel active timer status st Show remaining time help -h Show help

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
# Default 25-minute focus timer
timer

# Custom duration
timer 45           # 45 minutes

# 5-minute break
timer break

docs.title: Focus Sessions
docs.text:
# Start focus session with label
timer focus 30 "Finish documentation"

# Check remaining time
timer status
# ⏱️ focus: 23:45 remaining
#    Finish documentation

docs.title: Pomodoro Cycles
docs.text:
# Run 4 pomodoro cycles (default)
timer pomodoro

# Custom: 6 cycles, 30-min focus, 5-min break, 20-min long break
timer pomodoro 6 30 5 20

# Shortcut alias
pom                # Same as: timer pomodoro

docs.title: Focus Timer
docs.text:
🎯 FOCUS MODE
Focus session - 25 minutes

  ⏱️  23:45 [████████████░░░░░░░░]

docs.title: Break Timer
docs.text:
☕ BREAK TIME
5 minutes - stretch, hydrate, move

  ☕ 4:23 remaining

docs.title: Pomodoro
docs.text:
🍅 POMODORO
4 cycles: 25m focus, 5m break

━━━ Cycle 1 of 4 ━━━

docs.title: Notifications
docs.text:
On macOS, timer sends system notifications when timers complete:

  • Focus complete: Glass sound
  • Break over: Ping sound

docs.title: Timer State
docs.text:
Timers save state to $FLOW_DATA_DIR/timer.state, allowing you to:

  • Check status from any terminal
  • Cancel from any terminal
  • Resume awareness after terminal switch
# From any terminal
timer status
timer stop

docs.title: Integration with Work Sessions
docs.text:
The timer command integrates with the work flow:

# Start working
work my-project

# Start a focus block
timer 45 "Complete feature X"

# Timer leaves a breadcrumb
# 🍞 Started 45 min focus: Complete feature X

# When done
finish "Completed feature X"

docs.title: Pomodoro Options
docs.text:
timer pomodoro [cycles] [focus] [break] [long-break]
Parameter Default Description cycles 4 Number of pomodoro cycles focus 25 Focus duration (minutes) break 5 Short break duration (minutes) long-break 15 Long break after all cycles

Long break logic:

  • After every 4th cycle: long break
  • After final cycle: long break

docs.title: Tips
docs.text:
Start Small

If 25 minutes feels too long, start with timer 15. Build up gradually.

Respect the Break

When the break timer starts, actually step away. The short break is essential for ADHD focus management.

Use Labels

timer 25 "Fix the auth bug" helps you remember what you were doing when you return.

Interrupt = Stop

Press Ctrl+C to interrupt any timer. Your session state is preserved.

docs.title: Aliases
docs.text: Alias Command pom timer pomodoro

docs.title: Related Commands
docs.text: Command Description work Start focused work session finish End session morning Morning startup routine flow break Take a proper break

docs.title: See Also
docs.text:
• Dopamine Features Guide
  • Workflow Quick Reference

docs.title: flow upgrade
docs.text: Update flow-cli and related tools

docs.title: Synopsis
docs.text: flow upgrade [target] [options]

docs.title: Description
docs.text: flow upgrade updates flow-cli itself, Homebrew packages, and ZSH plugins. It provides a unified interface for keeping your workflow tools current.

docs.title: Targets
docs.text: Target Description self Update flow-cli via git pull tools Update Homebrew packages plugins Update ZSH plugins (antidote) all Update everything

docs.title: Options
docs.text: Option Description -c, --check Check for updates without installing --changelog Show what's new in latest version -f, --force Skip confirmations -h, --help Show help message

docs.title: Update flow-cli
docs.text:
flow upgrade self

This runs git pull in the flow-cli directory and reloads the plugin.

docs.title: Update Homebrew Packages
docs.text:
flow upgrade tools

Runs brew update && brew upgrade for flow-cli recommended tools.

docs.title: Update ZSH Plugins
docs.text:
flow upgrade plugins

Updates plugins via antidote (if installed).

docs.title: Update Everything
docs.text:
flow upgrade all

Updates flow-cli, Homebrew packages, and ZSH plugins in sequence.

docs.title: Check for Updates
docs.text:
flow upgrade --check

Output:

📦 Checking for updates...

flow-cli:
  Current: v3.2.0
  Latest:  v3.2.0
  Status:  ✅ Up to date

Homebrew:
  Outdated packages: 3
    • bat (0.23.0 → 0.24.0)
    • fzf (0.44.0 → 0.45.0)
    • gh (2.40.0 → 2.41.0)

ZSH Plugins:
  Status: ✅ Up to date

docs.title: Show Changelog
docs.text:
flow upgrade --changelog

Shows recent changes from the git log.

docs.title: Force Update (No Prompts)
docs.text: flow upgrade all --force

docs.title: Self Update
docs.text:
1. Checks current git remote for flow-cli
  2. Runs git fetch to check for updates
  3. Shows diff of incoming changes
  4. Runs git pull if confirmed
  5. Reloads the plugin

docs.title: Tools Update
docs.text:
1. Runs brew update to refresh formulae
  2. Checks for outdated packages
  3. Runs brew upgrade for selected packages

docs.title: Plugins Update
docs.text:
1. Detects plugin manager (antidote, zinit, oh-my-zsh)
  2. Runs appropriate update command
  3. Reloads shell configuration

docs.title: Requirements
docs.text:
• Git (for self-update)
  • Homebrew (for tools update)
  • Plugin manager: antidote, zinit, or oh-my-zsh (for plugins update)

docs.title: Related Commands
docs.text:
• flow install - Install new tools
  • flow doctor - Check installation health

docs.title: See Also
docs.text:
• Installation Guide

Added in v3.2.0

docs.title: work
docs.text:
Start a focused work session on a project

The work command is the primary entry point for flow-cli. It sets up your entire development context in one command.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text: work [project] [editor]

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text: Argument Description Default project Project name or path Interactive picker (if fzf) or current directory editor Editor to open $EDITOR or code

docs.title: What It Does
docs.text:
1. Checks for existing session - Prompts to switch if another project is active
  2. Locates the project - Uses atlas registry or scans $FLOW_PROJECTS_ROOT
  3. Changes to project directory - cd to the project root
  4. Starts a session - Records session start time in atlas
  5. Shows context - Displays project type, status, and focus
  6. Opens your editor - Launches VS Code, Cursor, Vim, Emacs, etc.

docs.title: Start Working on a Project
docs.text:
# Start working on flow-cli
work flow-cli

# With a specific editor
work flow-cli cursor

# Use vim
work my-project vim

docs.title: Interactive Selection
docs.text:
# Opens fzf picker if no project specified
work

docs.title: Use Current Directory
docs.text:
# If you're already in a project directory
cd ~/projects/my-app
work

docs.title: Output
docs.text:
When you run work, you'll see:

━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━
🔧 flow-cli (zsh-plugin)
━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━
🟢 Status: active
📍 Phase: v4.0.1 Released
🎯 Focus: Documentation enhancement

docs.title: Session Management
docs.text:
work automatically manages your session state:

  • Single active session - Only one project can be "active" at a time
  • Conflict detection - Prompts before switching projects
  • Duration tracking - Session time is recorded for productivity stats

docs.title: Check Current Session
docs.text:
# See what you're working on
flow status

# Or use the quick status
st

docs.title: Editor Support
docs.text:
The work command supports these editors out of the box:

Editor Command Notes VS Code code Default if $EDITOR not set Cursor cursor AI-powered VS Code fork Vim/Neovim vim, nvim Opens in terminal Emacs emacs, emacsclient Uses emacsclient if available Positron positron RStudio-based IDE (macOS)

docs.title: Custom Editor
docs.text:
# Set default editor in .zshrc
export EDITOR="nvim"

# Or specify per-session
work my-project "code-insiders"

docs.title: Related Commands
docs.text: Command Description finish End the current session hop Quick switch between projects (tmux) dash View all projects dashboard pick Interactive project picker

docs.title: Tips
docs.text:
ADHD-Friendly Workflow

The work command is designed to minimize friction:

- **One command** to set up everything
- **Smart defaults** so you rarely need arguments
- **Visual feedback** confirms what's happening

Project Detection

flow-cli automatically detects your project type (R package, Node.js, Python, ZSH, etc.) and shows the appropriate icon and context.

docs.title: See Also
docs.text:
• First Session Tutorial
  • Multiple Projects Tutorial
  • Workflow Quick Reference

docs.title: Contributing to flow-cli
docs.text: Thank you for your interest in contributing! This guide will help you get started.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• ZSH (default shell on macOS)
  • Git (for version control)
  • fzf (optional, for interactive features)

docs.title: Setup
docs.text:
1. Clone the repository:
git clone https://github.com/Data-Wise/flow-cli.git
cd flow-cli
  1. Source the plugin:
source flow.plugin.zsh
  1. Run tests:
zsh tests/test-cc-dispatcher.zsh
  1. Build documentation (optional): 
    mkdocs serve
# Visit http://127.0.0.1:8000

docs.title: Project Structure
docs.text:
flow-cli/
├── flow.plugin.zsh           # Plugin entry point
├── lib/
│   ├── core.zsh              # Colors, logging, utilities
│   ├── atlas-bridge.zsh      # Optional Atlas integration
│   ├── project-detector.zsh  # Project type detection
│   ├── tui.zsh               # Terminal UI components
│   └── dispatchers/          # Smart command dispatchers
│       ├── cc-dispatcher.zsh     # Claude Code
│       ├── g-dispatcher.zsh      # Git workflows
│       ├── wt-dispatcher.zsh     # Worktrees
│       ├── mcp-dispatcher.zsh    # MCP servers
│       ├── r-dispatcher.zsh      # R packages
│       ├── qu-dispatcher.zsh     # Quarto
│       ├── tm-dispatcher.zsh     # Terminal
│       └── obs.zsh               # Obsidian
├── commands/                 # Core command implementations
├── completions/              # ZSH completions
├── tests/                    # Test suite
└── docs/                     # Documentation (MkDocs)

docs.title: Making Changes
docs.text:
1. Create a feature branch:
g feature start my-feature
# or: git checkout -b feature/my-feature
  1. Make your changes:
  2. Dispatchers: lib/dispatchers/<name>-dispatcher.zsh
  3. Commands: commands/<name>.zsh

  4. Core utilities: lib/core.zsh

  5. Test your changes:

# Source and test manually
source flow.plugin.zsh
my_command help

# Run automated tests
zsh tests/test-<name>-dispatcher.zsh
  1. Commit your changes: 
    git add .
git commit -m "feat: add new feature"

docs.title: Commit Message Format
docs.text:
We use conventional commits:

<type>(<scope>): <description>

Types:

  • feat: New feature
  • fix: Bug fix
  • docs: Documentation only
  • refactor: Code refactoring
  • test: Adding or updating tests
  • chore: Maintenance tasks

Examples:

feat(cc): add worktree integration
fix(g): handle missing dev branch
docs(reference): update dispatcher docs
test(mcp): add validation tests

docs.title: Running Tests
docs.text:
# Run specific dispatcher test
zsh tests/test-cc-dispatcher.zsh

# Run all dispatcher tests
for f in tests/test-*-dispatcher.zsh; do zsh "$f"; done

# Interactive validation (fun!)
./tests/interactive-dog-feeding.zsh

docs.title: Writing Tests
docs.text:
Create tests/test-<name>.zsh:

#!/usr/bin/env zsh

# Test framework
TESTS_PASSED=0
TESTS_FAILED=0

pass() {
    echo "✓ PASS"
    ((TESTS_PASSED++))
}

fail() {
    echo "✗ FAIL - $1"
    ((TESTS_FAILED++))
}

# Setup
setup() {
    local project_root="${0:A:h:h}"
    source "$project_root/lib/dispatchers/my-dispatcher.zsh"
}

# Tests
test_help_shows_usage() {
    echo -n "Testing: help shows usage ... "
    local output=$(my_command help 2>&1)
    if [[ "$output" == *"Usage:"* ]]; then
        pass
    else
        fail "Usage not found"
    fi
}

# Run
setup
test_help_shows_usage

# Summary
echo "Passed: $TESTS_PASSED, Failed: $TESTS_FAILED"
[[ $TESTS_FAILED -eq 0 ]] && exit 0 || exit 1

docs.title: Test Guidelines
docs.text:
• Test function existence, help output, error handling
  • Follow existing test patterns
  • Add to CI workflow when ready

docs.title: ZSH Functions
docs.text:
General:

  • Use local for all variables
  • Add help subcommand to dispatchers
  • Error messages to stderr (>&2)
  • Follow naming: _dispatcher_action()

Dispatcher Pattern:

# Main dispatcher function
mydisp() {
    case "$1" in
        action1) shift; _mydisp_action1 "$@" ;;
        action2) shift; _mydisp_action2 "$@" ;;
        help|--help|-h) _mydisp_help ;;
        *) _mydisp_help ;;
    esac
}

# Action implementation
_mydisp_action1() {
    # Implementation
}

# Help function
_mydisp_help() {
    cat << 'EOF'
mydisp - Description

Usage: mydisp <command> [options]

Commands:
  action1     Do something
  action2     Do something else
  help        Show this help

Examples:
  mydisp action1
  mydisp action2 --flag
EOF
}

Avoid:

  • Global variables (use local)
  • External dependencies where ZSH builtins work
  • eval unless absolutely necessary
  • Bash-specific syntax ([[ ]] is fine, $'...' is fine)

docs.title: Adding a New Dispatcher
docs.text:
1. Create the file: 

    touch lib/dispatchers/mydisp-dispatcher.zsh

  2. Implement the pattern:

  3. Main function: mydisp()
  4. Help function: _mydisp_help()

  5. Action functions: _mydisp_action()

  6. Create tests: 

    touch tests/test-mydisp-dispatcher.zsh

  7. Add to CI: Edit .github/workflows/test.yml

  8. Document: Create docs/reference/MYDISP-DISPATCHER-REFERENCE.md

docs.title: Adding Documentation
docs.text:
1. Create markdown file in docs/
  2. Add to mkdocs.yml navigation
  3. Test locally: mkdocs serve
  4. Deploy: mkdocs gh-deploy --force

docs.title: Documentation Guidelines
docs.text:
ADHD-Friendly Writing:

  • Use visual hierarchy (headers, bullets, tables)
  • Keep sections short (< 200 words)
  • Add examples liberally
  • Provide quick reference tables

File Naming:

  • Reference docs: NAME-REFERENCE.md (CAPS)
  • Tutorials: 01-tutorial-name.md (numbered)
  • Guides: GUIDE-NAME.md

docs.title: Pull Request Process
docs.text:
1. Ensure tests pass: 

    zsh tests/test-<name>-dispatcher.zsh

  2. Create PR to dev branch: 

    g feature finish
# or: git push && gh pr create

  3. Wait for CI checks

  4. PR description should include:

  5. What changed and why
  6. Testing instructions
  7. Related issues

docs.title: Merge Flow
docs.text:
feature/* → dev → main
  • Feature branches merge to dev
  • dev merges to main for releases
  • Direct pushes to main are blocked

docs.title: Questions?
docs.text:
• Testing: See TESTING.md
  • Dispatchers: See DISPATCHER-REFERENCE.md
  • Issues: https://github.com/Data-Wise/flow-cli/issues

Last Updated: 2025-12-30 Version: v4.4.3

docs.title: Documentation Style Guide
docs.text:
Standards for writing and maintaining flow-cli documentation

Last Updated: 2025-12-24 Target Audience: Documentation contributors

docs.title: Table of Contents
docs.text:
• Philosophy
  • File Organization
  • Writing Style
  • Markdown Standards
  • ADHD-Friendly Design
  • Code Examples
  • Diagrams and Visuals
  • Maintenance

docs.title: Core Principles
docs.text:
1. Progressive Disclosure - Start simple, reveal complexity gradually
  2. ADHD-Optimized - Scannable, visual, clear hierarchy
  3. Practical Over Perfect - Real examples > theoretical explanations
  4. Accessibility - Clear language, no jargon without explanation
  5. Maintainable - Easy to update, clear ownership

docs.title: Documentation Goals
docs.text:
Good documentation:

  • ✅ Answers "How do I...?" questions quickly
  • ✅ Provides copy-paste examples that work
  • ✅ Uses visuals (diagrams, tables, code blocks)
  • ✅ Links to related documentation
  • ✅ Stays current with code changes

Bad documentation:

  • ❌ Walls of text without structure
  • ❌ Jargon without explanation
  • ❌ Examples that don't work
  • ❌ Outdated information
  • ❌ No clear next steps

docs.title: Directory Structure
docs.text:
docs/
├── getting-started/       # New user onboarding
│   ├── 00-welcome.md      # Learning paths
│   ├── quick-start.md     # 5-minute start
│   ├── installation.md    # Setup guide
│   └── troubleshooting.md # Common issues
│
├── tutorials/             # Step-by-step guides
│   ├── 01-first-session.md
│   ├── 02-multiple-projects.md
│   ├── 03-status-visualizations.md
│   └── 04-web-dashboard.md
│
├── guides/                # How-to guides
│   ├── WORKFLOWS-QUICK-WINS.md
│   └── WORKFLOW-TUTORIAL.md
│
├── reference/             # Technical reference
│   ├── COMMAND-EXPLORER.md
│   ├── ALIAS-REFERENCE-CARD.md
│   └── WORKFLOW-QUICK-REFERENCE.md
│
├── testing/               # Testing guides
│   └── TESTING.md
│
└── contributing/          # Contributor guides
    ├── PR-WORKFLOW-GUIDE.md
    └── DOCUMENTATION-STYLE-GUIDE.md (this file)

docs.title: File Naming
docs.text:
Pattern: CAPITALIZED-KEBAB-CASE.md for major docs

Examples:

  • ✅ ALIAS-REFERENCE-CARD.md - Clear, descriptive
  • ✅ PR-WORKFLOW-GUIDE.md - Acronym + purpose
  • ✅ 01-first-session.md - Numbered tutorial
  • ❌ reference.md - Too generic
  • ❌ aliases_reference.md - Snake case inconsistent
  • ❌ AliasReferenceCard.md - PascalCase inconsistent

Numbering:

  • Tutorials: 01-, 02-, 03- (sequential learning)
  • ADRs: ADR-001-, ADR-002- (chronological decisions)
  • Regular docs: No numbers (timeless reference)

docs.title: Tone and Voice
docs.text:
Be:

  • ✅ Clear and direct
  • ✅ Conversational but professional
  • ✅ Encouraging and supportive
  • ✅ Honest about limitations

Avoid:

  • ❌ Overly formal/academic language
  • ❌ Condescending "obviously" or "simply"
  • ❌ Marketing speak / hype
  • ❌ Unexplained jargon

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
Good:

The `flow status` command shows your current work session. If you have
an active session, you'll see the project name, task, and duration.

Example:

```bash
flow status
```

Bad:

The flow status command, which is obviously one of the most important
commands in the entire system, provides comprehensive visibility into
your current workflow state by leveraging our proprietary session
tracking algorithm.

docs.title: Sentence Structure
docs.text:
Keep it simple:

  • ✅ One idea per sentence
  • ✅ Active voice preferred
  • ✅ Short paragraphs (3-5 sentences max)
  • ✅ Use bullet points for lists

Examples:

Good (active voice):

The system caches project scans for one hour.

Bad (passive voice):

Project scans are cached by the system for a duration of one hour.

docs.title: Headers
docs.text:
Use ATX-style headers (with #):

# H1 - Document Title (only one per document)

## H2 - Major Section

### H3 - Subsection

#### H4 - Rarely needed

##### H5 - Avoid if possible

Best practices:

  • One H1 per document
  • Don't skip levels (no H1 → H3)
  • Use sentence case, not Title Case
  • Add blank lines before and after headers

docs.title: Code Blocks
docs.text:
Always specify language:

```bash
flow status
```

const session = new Session('id', 'project', 'task')

# Python example
result = process_data()

**Languages we use:**
- `bash` - Shell commands
- `javascript` - Node.js code
- `json` - Configuration files
- `yaml` - YAML files
- `markdown` - Markdown examples
- `mermaid` - Diagrams

### Links

**Use relative links for internal docs:**

```markdown
✅ See [Testing Guide](../testing/TESTING.md)
✅ Read the [Dispatcher Reference](../reference/DISPATCHER-REFERENCE.md)
❌ See [Testing Guide](https://data-wise.github.io/flow-cli/testing/TESTING/)

Use full URLs for external links:

✅ [Clean Architecture Book](https://blog.cleancoder.com/uncle-bob/2012/08/13/the-clean-architecture.html)

docs.title: Lists
docs.text:
Unordered lists:

- First item
- Second item
  - Nested item
  - Another nested item
- Third item

Ordered lists:

1. First step
2. Second step
3. Third step

Task lists:

- [ ] Todo item
- [x] Completed item

docs.title: Tables
docs.text:
Use tables for structured data:

| Command       | Purpose              | Example             |
| ------------- | -------------------- | ------------------- |
| `flow status` | Show current session | `flow status`       |
| `flow work`   | Start session        | `flow work project` |

Alignment:

| Left aligned | Center aligned | Right aligned |
| :----------- | :------------: | ------------: |
| Text         |      Text      |          Text |

docs.title: Visual Hierarchy
docs.text:
Use clear structure:

  1. Headers - Break up content
  2. Bullet points - Scannable lists
  3. Code blocks - Highlight examples
  4. Tables - Compare options
  5. Admonitions - Call attention

docs.title: Admonitions (Info Boxes)
docs.text:
MkDocs Material supports admonitions:

!!! note "Quick Tip"
This is a helpful note that stands out.

!!! warning "Important"
Pay attention to this warning.

!!! tip "Pro Tip"
Use this pattern for better results.

!!! danger "Critical"
Don't do this - it will break things.

docs.title: Scannable Content
docs.text:
Good (scannable):

## Quick Start

**Three steps to get started:**

1. **Install:** `npm install`
2. **Test:** `npm test`
3. **Run:** `flow status`

**Time:** 5 minutes

Bad (wall of text):

## Quick Start

To get started with flow-cli you'll need to first install the
dependencies using npm install and then run the test suite to
make sure everything is working properly and finally you can
run the flow status command to see your first output.

docs.title: Visual Elements
docs.text:
Use emojis sparingly:

  • ✅ Status indicators
  • 🔥 Flow state
  • ⚡ Quick wins
  • 📊 Data/stats
  • ❌ Don't overuse

Use formatting:

  • Bold - Important terms, emphasis
  • Italic - Technical terms first use
  • Code - Commands, file names, variables

  • Blockquotes - Important callouts

docs.title: Principles
docs.text:
1. Working examples - Must actually run
  2. Self-contained - Don't assume context
  3. Commented - Explain non-obvious parts
  4. Realistic - Real-world scenarios

docs.title: Example Template
docs.text:
### Example: Creating a Session

**Scenario:** Start a work session on the rmediation project.

```bash
# Start session
flow work rmediation "Fix bug #123"

# Check status
flow status

# Output:
# ✅ ACTIVE SESSION
# Project: rmediation
# Task: Fix bug #123
# Duration: 0 min
```

What this does:

  1. Creates new session for rmediation
  2. Sets task description
  3. Starts timer
### Best Practices

**DO:**
```markdown
✅ Show expected output
✅ Include comments
✅ Use realistic data
✅ Show error cases

DON'T:

❌ Use "foo", "bar", "baz"
❌ Leave output ambiguous
❌ Skip error handling
❌ Use outdated examples

docs.title: Mermaid Diagrams
docs.text:
We use Mermaid for diagrams:

```mermaid
graph LR
    A[User] --> B[CLI]
    B --> C[Domain]
    C --> D[Use Cases]
    D --> E[Adapters]
```

**Diagram types we use:**
- **Flowcharts** - Process flows
- **Sequence diagrams** - Interactions
- **Class diagrams** - Entities
- **State diagrams** - State machines

### ASCII Art

**For simple visualizations:**

```markdown

┌─────────────────────────────────────┐ │ 📊 Dashboard │ ├─────────────────────────────────────┤ │ Active: 3 projects │ │ Flow %: 85% │ └─────────────────────────────────────┘

docs.title: Screenshots
docs.text:
When to use:

  • UI demonstrations
  • Visual bugs
  • Before/after comparisons

How to include:

![Dashboard Screenshot](../images/dashboard-example.png)

docs.title: Document Metadata
docs.text:
Every document should have:

# Document Title

**Brief description in one sentence**

**Last Updated:** YYYY-MM-DD
**Target Audience:** Who this is for
**Read Time:** Estimated time (optional)

---

[Content begins...]

docs.title: Version Information
docs.text:
Include version where relevant:

**Version:** v2.0.0-beta.1
**Status:** Production Use Phase

docs.title: Update Protocol
docs.text:
When to update documentation:

  1. Code changes - Update affected docs same PR
  2. API changes - Update API reference immediately
  3. New features - Add tutorial/guide
  4. Bug fixes - Update troubleshooting if relevant
  5. Monthly - Review for accuracy

docs.title: Deprecation Notices
docs.text:
How to mark deprecated content:

!!! warning "Deprecated"
This feature was removed in v2.0.0. Use [new feature](#) instead.

docs.title: Before Publishing
docs.text:
Every documentation update should:

  • [ ] Have clear title and description
  • [ ] Include last updated date
  • [ ] Use proper markdown formatting
  • [ ] Include working code examples
  • [ ] Link to related documentation
  • [ ] Follow ADHD-friendly design
  • [ ] Pass spell check
  • [ ] Test all commands/examples
  • [ ] Build successfully (mkdocs build --strict)

docs.title: Review Criteria
docs.text:
Self-review questions:

  1. Clarity - Would a newcomer understand this?
  2. Accuracy - Are examples current and correct?
  3. Completeness - Did I answer the user's question?
  4. Structure - Is it easy to scan and navigate?
  5. Links - Do all links work?

docs.title: Tutorial Template
docs.text:
# Tutorial: [Topic]

**What you'll learn:** [Brief description]
**Time:** X minutes
**Prerequisites:** [What you need first]

---

## Overview

[1-2 paragraph introduction]

## Step 1: [Action]

[Clear instructions]

```bash
# Command example
```

What this does: [Explanation]

docs.title: Step 2: [Next Action]
docs.text: [Continue pattern...]

docs.title: Summary
docs.text:
You learned:

  • Bullet point 1
  • Bullet point 2

Next steps:

  • Suggested next tutorial
  • Related documentation

Questions? [Link to support]

### Reference Template

```markdown
# [Feature] Reference

**Quick reference for [feature]**

**Last Updated:** YYYY-MM-DD

---

## Quick Start

```bash
# Minimal example

docs.title: All Options
docs.text: Option Description Example --flag What it does command --flag

docs.title: Example 1: [Use Case]
docs.text: # Command

docs.title: Example 2: [Another Use Case]
docs.text:
# Command

See also:

  • Related doc 1
  • Related doc 2
---

## Common Mistakes

### Mistake 1: No Examples

**Bad:**
```markdown
The status command shows your session.

Good:

The status command shows your session.

Example:

```bash
flow status
# ✅ ACTIVE SESSION
# Project: rmediation
# Duration: 45 min 🔥 IN FLOW
```

### Mistake 2: Outdated Information

**Problem:** Documentation mentions features that don't exist or old commands.

**Solution:**
- Update docs in same PR as code changes
- Monthly review cycle
- Add "Last Updated" dates

### Mistake 3: Broken Links

**Problem:** Links to moved/deleted files.

**Solution:**
- Use relative links
- Test with `mkdocs build --strict`
- Link checker in CI/CD

### Mistake 4: Walls of Text

**Problem:** Dense paragraphs without structure.

**Solution:**
- Break into sections with headers
- Use bullet points
- Add code examples
- Include visuals

---

## Tools and Resources

### Writing Tools

- **Spell check:** Use editor spell check
- **Markdown linter:** markdownlint
- **Link checker:** `mkdocs build --strict`
- **Preview:** `mkdocs serve`

### Reference Materials

- [Markdown Guide](https://www.markdownguide.org/)
- [MkDocs Material](https://squidfunk.github.io/mkdocs-material/)
- [Mermaid Docs](https://mermaid.js.org/)
- [Google Developer Docs Style](https://developers.google.com/style)

---

## Related Documentation

- [Contributing Guide](../contributing/CONTRIBUTING.md) - How to contribute
- [PR Workflow Guide](PR-WORKFLOW-GUIDE.md) - Pull request process
- [ADR Process Guide](ADR-PROCESS-GUIDE.md) - Architecture decisions

---

**Last Updated:** 2025-12-24
**Version:** v2.0.0-beta.1
**Maintained by:** flow-cli contributors

docs.title: Pull Request Workflow Guide
docs.text:
Complete guide to contributing code to flow-cli

Last Updated: 2025-12-30 Target Audience: Contributors and maintainers Architecture: Pure ZSH plugin (v4.4.x)

docs.title: Table of Contents
docs.text:
• Quick Start
  • Before You Start
  • Creating a Pull Request
  • PR Review Process
  • After Merge
  • Common Scenarios
  • Troubleshooting

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
# 1. Fork and clone
git clone https://github.com/YOUR-USERNAME/flow-cli.git
cd flow-cli

# 2. Create feature branch
git checkout -b feature/your-feature-name

# 3. Load plugin and test
source flow.plugin.zsh
zsh tests/run-tests.zsh

# 4. Commit with conventional commits
