git commit -m "feat: add new feature"

# 5. Push and create PR
git push origin feature/your-feature-name
# Then create PR on GitHub

docs.title: 1. Check Existing Work
docs.text:
Avoid duplicate effort:

# Search for existing issues
# Visit: https://github.com/Data-Wise/flow-cli/issues

# Search for existing PRs
# Visit: https://github.com/Data-Wise/flow-cli/pulls

docs.title: 2. Read Project Documentation
docs.text:
Essential reading:

  • CLAUDE.md - Architecture overview
  • CONTRIBUTING.md - Contribution guidelines
  • Testing Guide - Test requirements

docs.title: 3. Understand the Architecture
docs.text:
flow-cli is a pure ZSH plugin with this structure:

flow-cli/
├── flow.plugin.zsh       # Plugin entry point
├── lib/
│   ├── core.zsh          # Core utilities
│   ├── atlas-bridge.zsh  # Atlas integration
│   ├── project-detector.zsh
│   ├── tui.zsh           # Terminal UI
│   └── dispatchers/      # Smart dispatchers
├── commands/             # Command implementations
├── completions/          # ZSH completions
├── hooks/                # ZSH hooks
└── tests/                # Test suite

Key principles:

  • Pure ZSH (no external runtime)
  • Sub-10ms response time
  • ADHD-friendly design

docs.title: 4. Set Up Development Environment
docs.text:
# Load the plugin in your current shell
source flow.plugin.zsh

# Run tests to verify setup
zsh tests/run-tests.zsh

# Verify commands work
work --help
dash --help
r help

docs.title: Step 1: Create Feature Branch
docs.text:
Branch naming convention:

# Features
git checkout -b feature/add-dashboard-widget

# Bug fixes
git checkout -b fix/session-timeout-bug

# Documentation
git checkout -b docs/update-dispatcher-reference

# Refactoring
git checkout -b refactor/simplify-cache-logic

Pattern: type/short-description-kebab-case

docs.title: Step 2: Make Changes
docs.text:
Follow coding standards:

  1. ZSH plugin patterns
  2. Commands in commands/
  3. Dispatchers in lib/dispatchers/

  4. Utilities in lib/core.zsh

  5. Code style

  6. Use _flow_ prefix for internal functions
  7. Use _<dispatcher>_ prefix for dispatcher internals

  8. Add inline comments for complex logic

  9. Testing required

  10. Add tests to tests/
  11. Use the existing test framework
  12. Aim for 100% pass rate

docs.title: Step 3: Write Tests
docs.text:
Test-Driven Development (TDD) encouraged:

# 1. Write failing test
# 2. Implement feature
# 3. Test passes
# 4. Refactor if needed

# Run tests
zsh tests/run-tests.zsh

Test requirements:

  • [ ] Unit tests for new functions
  • [ ] Integration tests for commands
  • [ ] All tests pass

See: Testing Guide

docs.title: Step 4: Commit Your Changes
docs.text:
Use Conventional Commits:

# Feature
git commit -m "feat: add dashboard auto-refresh"

# Bug fix
git commit -m "fix: resolve session timeout race condition"

# Documentation
git commit -m "docs: update dispatcher reference for new commands"

# Tests
git commit -m "test: add integration tests for project scanning"

# Refactor
git commit -m "refactor: simplify cache invalidation logic"

# Performance
git commit -m "perf: optimize project scanning with caching"

# Breaking change
git commit -m "feat!: change session API signature

BREAKING CHANGE: work command now requires project name"

Commit message format:

<type>[optional scope]: <description>

[optional body]

[optional footer(s)]

Types:

  • feat: - New feature
  • fix: - Bug fix
  • docs: - Documentation only
  • test: - Adding tests
  • refactor: - Code change that neither fixes bug nor adds feature
  • perf: - Performance improvement
  • chore: - Maintenance (dependencies, build, etc.)

docs.title: Step 5: Push and Create PR
docs.text:
# Push your branch
git push origin feature/your-feature-name

# GitHub CLI (optional)
gh pr create --title "Add dashboard auto-refresh" --body "Closes #123"

# Or create PR via GitHub web interface

PR template will guide you through:

  1. Description of changes
  2. Type of change (feature, fix, docs, etc.)
  3. Testing checklist
  4. Breaking changes (if any)

docs.title: What Reviewers Look For
docs.text:
1. Code Quality

  • [ ] Follows ZSH plugin patterns
  • [ ] Clear, readable code with good naming
  • [ ] Appropriate comments for complex logic
  • [ ] No unnecessary complexity

2. Testing

  • [ ] All tests pass
  • [ ] New tests added for new functionality
  • [ ] Tests are clear and maintainable
  • [ ] Edge cases covered

3. Documentation

  • [ ] CLAUDE.md updated if architecture changed
  • [ ] User-facing docs updated if needed
  • [ ] Help functions updated (_<cmd>_help)
  • [ ] Completions updated if commands changed

4. Breaking Changes

  • [ ] Clearly documented in commit message
  • [ ] Migration guide provided if needed
  • [ ] Deprecation warnings added for gradual migration

5. Performance

  • [ ] No performance regressions
  • [ ] Maintains sub-10ms response time for core commands
  • [ ] Efficient ZSH patterns

docs.title: Responding to Review Comments
docs.text:
Be professional and collaborative:

# Good response

Thanks for catching that! I've updated the implementation to use
the dispatcher pattern as you suggested. See commit abc123.

# Address each comment

- Fixed variable naming in work.zsh
- Added edge case test for empty project list
- Still working on the performance optimization - will update soon

Iterate quickly:

# Make requested changes
git add .
git commit -m "refactor: address review comments"
git push origin feature/your-feature-name

# PR automatically updates

docs.title: Approval and Merge
docs.text:
Merge criteria:

  1. All tests passing
  2. At least one approval from maintainer
  3. All review comments addressed
  4. No merge conflicts
  5. CI/CD checks passing

Merge strategies:

  • Squash and merge (default) - All commits squashed into one
  • Rebase and merge - Linear history, individual commits preserved
  • Merge commit - Preserves full history

Most PRs use squash and merge for clean history.

docs.title: 1. Delete Your Branch
docs.text:
# Delete local branch
git checkout main
git branch -d feature/your-feature-name

# Delete remote branch (usually done automatically by GitHub)
git push origin --delete feature/your-feature-name

docs.title: 2. Update Your Fork
docs.text:
# Add upstream remote (one-time setup)
git remote add upstream https://github.com/Data-Wise/flow-cli.git

# Fetch and merge
git fetch upstream
git merge upstream/main
git push origin main

docs.title: 3. Celebrate!
docs.text: Your contribution is now part of flow-cli! Thank you for contributing.

docs.title: Scenario 1: Adding a New Command
docs.text:
# 1. Create issue first (discuss approach)
# 2. Get approval/feedback
# 3. Create branch
git checkout -b feature/new-command

# 4. Implement
# - Add command to commands/yourcommand.zsh
# - Add help function _yourcommand_help()
# - Add completion to completions/_yourcommand
# - Write tests

# 5. Update documentation
# - Add to COMMAND-QUICK-REFERENCE.md
# - Update CLAUDE.md if significant

# 6. Create PR with clear description

docs.title: Scenario 2: Adding a Dispatcher Subcommand
docs.text:
# 1. Edit lib/dispatchers/<name>-dispatcher.zsh
# 2. Add case in main function
# 3. Add implementation function _<name>_<action>()
# 4. Update _<name>_help() function
# 5. Add tests
# 6. Update DISPATCHER-REFERENCE.md

docs.title: Scenario 3: Fixing a Bug
docs.text:
# 1. Reproduce the bug
# 2. Write failing test that demonstrates bug

# 3. Create fix branch
git checkout -b fix/session-timeout-issue

# 4. Fix the bug
# 5. Verify test now passes
zsh tests/run-tests.zsh

# 6. Create PR
# - Reference issue number: "Fixes #123"
# - Explain root cause and solution

docs.title: Scenario 4: Updating Documentation
docs.text:
# 1. Create docs branch
git checkout -b docs/improve-dispatcher-reference

# 2. Make documentation changes
# - Update markdown files
# - Fix typos, improve clarity
# - Add examples

# 3. Test documentation build
mkdocs build --strict

# 4. Create PR
# - Explain what was unclear before
# - Show improvement

docs.title: Tests Failing Locally
docs.text:
# Run tests to see failures
zsh tests/run-tests.zsh

# Run specific test file
zsh tests/unit/test-core.zsh

# Check for syntax errors
zsh -n lib/core.zsh

Common causes:

  • Forgot to update tests after code change
  • Missing source statement in flow.plugin.zsh
  • ZSH syntax error (different from bash)

docs.title: Merge Conflicts
docs.text:
# Update your branch with latest main
git fetch origin
git merge origin/main

# Resolve conflicts manually
# Edit conflicted files
# Remove conflict markers (<<<<, ====, >>>>)

# Mark as resolved
git add .
git commit -m "resolve merge conflicts"
git push origin feature/your-feature-name

docs.title: CI/CD Checks Failing
docs.text:
GitHub Actions runs tests on every PR:

  1. Check Actions tab for detailed logs
  2. Common issues:
  3. Tests pass locally but fail in CI (environment differences)
  4. Missing files (ensure all changes committed)

  5. ZSH version differences

  6. Fix and push: 

    git add .
git commit -m "fix: resolve CI test failures"
git push origin feature/your-feature-name

docs.title: Need Help?
docs.text:
Ask for help early:

  • Comment on your PR: "I'm stuck on X, any suggestions?"
  • Tag a maintainer: @Data-Wise could you review this approach?
  • Open a discussion: GitHub Discussions tab

docs.title: DO
docs.text:
1. Keep PRs focused
  2. One feature/fix per PR
  3. Easier to review and merge

  4. Reduces merge conflicts

  5. Write clear descriptions

  6. Explain what and why
  7. Link to relevant issues

  8. Add examples for new commands

  9. Test thoroughly

  10. Write tests for new code
  11. Run full test suite

  12. Test edge cases

  13. Update documentation

  14. Keep docs in sync with code
  15. Add examples for new features

  16. Update help functions

  17. Respond to reviews promptly

  18. Address comments quickly
  19. Ask questions if unclear
  20. Be open to feedback

docs.title: DON'T
docs.text:
1. Large PRs
  2. Hard to review
  3. More likely to have bugs

  4. Delays merge

  5. Mixed changes

  6. Refactor + feature in same PR
  7. Multiple unrelated fixes

  8. Code + unrelated docs

  9. Ignoring tests

  10. Skipping test coverage
  11. Leaving tests broken

  12. Not testing edge cases

  13. Breaking changes without notice

  14. No migration guide
  15. No deprecation warnings

  16. Surprise API changes

  17. Force pushing after review

  18. Loses review comments
  19. Confuses reviewers
  20. Use regular push instead

docs.title: Essential Commands
docs.text:
# Setup
git clone <fork-url>
source flow.plugin.zsh
zsh tests/run-tests.zsh

# Development
git checkout -b feature/name
# edit files
zsh tests/run-tests.zsh
git commit -m "type: message"
git push origin feature/name

# Keep updated
git fetch upstream
git merge upstream/main

# Cleanup
git branch -d feature/name
git push origin --delete feature/name

docs.title: Links
docs.text:
• Issues: https://github.com/Data-Wise/flow-cli/issues
  • PRs: https://github.com/Data-Wise/flow-cli/pulls
  • Actions: https://github.com/Data-Wise/flow-cli/actions
  • Documentation: https://data-wise.github.io/flow-cli/

docs.title: Related Documentation
docs.text:
• Contributing Guide - High-level contribution guidelines
  • Testing Guide - How to write and run tests
  • CLAUDE.md - Architecture overview

Last Updated: 2025-12-30 Version: v4.4.x Questions? Open an issue or discussion on GitHub

docs.title: Welcome to Flow CLI
docs.text: Choose your learning path based on your time and goals:

docs.title: 🚀 5-Minute Quick Start
docs.text:
Perfect if you: Just want to try it out and see what it does.

You'll learn: How to install, run your first command, and see immediate results.

Start here: Quick Start Guide

What you'll do:

  1. Install flow-cli (source the plugin)
  2. Run dash to see your project dashboard
  3. Try work <project> to start a session
  4. Use win "text" to log accomplishments

Time investment: 5 minutes Outcome: Working installation + first successful command

docs.title: 📚 30-Minute Tutorial Path
docs.text:
Perfect if you: Want to learn the complete workflow from start to finish.

You'll learn: How to use flow-cli in your daily development workflow.

Recommended sequence:

docs.title: Tutorial 1: Your First Session (10 min)
docs.text:
→ Tutorial: Your First Session

What you'll learn:

  • Create and manage work sessions
  • Track time and context
  • Understand flow state
  • End sessions with outcome tracking

Outcome: Comfortable with session management

docs.title: Tutorial 2: Multiple Projects (10 min)
docs.text:
→ Tutorial: Multiple Projects

What you'll learn:

  • Use the project picker (pick)
  • Filter by project type and status
  • Track recent activity
  • Use dispatchers for domain-specific workflows

Outcome: Efficiently switch between projects

docs.title: Tutorial 3: Status Visualizations (10 min)
docs.text:
→ Tutorial: Status Visualizations

What you'll learn:

  • Read dashboard visualizations
  • Interpret productivity metrics (streaks, wins)
  • Use interactive mode (dash -i)
  • Understand .STATUS file format

Outcome: Master the dashboard features

Time investment: 30 minutes Outcome: Complete workflow mastery

docs.title: 🔬 Deep Dive (1-2 hours)
docs.text:
Perfect if you: Want to master the system and contribute.

You'll learn: Dispatchers, customization, testing, and contribution.

Learning path:

docs.title: Phase 1: Advanced Features (30 min)
docs.text:
1. Dispatcher Reference - All 8 dispatchers
  2. Command Reference - Complete command list
  3. Workflow Quick Reference - Common patterns

docs.title: Phase 2: Customization & Extension (30-60 min)
docs.text:
1. Contributing Guide - How to contribute
  2. Testing Guide - 150+ ZSH tests
  3. CLAUDE.md - Project overview

Time investment: 1-2 hours Outcome: Expert-level understanding + ability to customize/contribute

docs.title: "I Just Want to Track My Work"
docs.text:
1. Read: Quick Start (5 min)
  2. Do: Tutorial 1: First Session (10 min)
  3. Use: dash and win daily

Total time: 15 minutes

docs.title: "I Work on Multiple Projects"
docs.text:
1. Read: Quick Start (5 min)
  2. Do: Tutorial 2: Multiple Projects (10 min)
  3. Learn: Project filters and pick command
  4. Use: Dispatchers (cc, g, r, qu)

Total time: 20 minutes

docs.title: "I Want Beautiful Dashboards"
docs.text:
1. Read: Quick Start (5 min)
  2. Do: Tutorial 3: Status Visualizations (10 min)
  3. Try: dash -i for interactive mode
  4. Try: dash --watch for live updates

Total time: 20 minutes

docs.title: "I'm a Developer - Show Me the Code"
docs.text:
1. Read: CLAUDE.md (10 min)
  2. Browse: Dispatcher Reference (15 min)
  3. Review: Testing Guide (15 min)
  4. Run: flow doctor to check your setup

Total time: 45 minutes

docs.title: "I Want to Contribute"
docs.text:
1. Read: Contributing Guide (15 min)
  2. Review: Testing Guide (15 min)
  3. Run: zsh tests/test-cc-dispatcher.zsh (5 min)
  4. Build: Pick a good first issue

Total time: 1 hour (+ implementation time)

docs.title: Quick References (Keep These Handy)
docs.text:
• Command Quick Reference - All commands
  • Dispatcher Reference - All 8 dispatchers
  • Workflow Quick Reference - Common patterns
  • Alias Reference Card - Shortcuts

docs.title: Comprehensive Guides
docs.text:
• Documentation Home - Everything organized
  • Dopamine Features - Win tracking, streaks

docs.title: Common Questions
docs.text:
"Which commands do I use daily?" → work, dash, win, finish - See Quick Start

"How do I switch between projects?" → Use pick or hop - See Tutorial 2

"What are the dispatchers?" → cc, g, mcp, obs, qu, r, tm, wt - See Dispatcher Reference

"How do I check my setup?" → Run flow doctor - See Installation

docs.title: Still Stuck?
docs.text:
1. Run health check: flow doctor
  2. Check troubleshooting: Troubleshooting Guide
  3. Search the docs: Use the documentation site
  4. Ask for help: GitHub Issues

docs.title: Latest Features
docs.text:
• ✅ 8 dispatchers - cc, g, mcp, obs, qu, r, tm, wt
  • ✅ 150+ tests - Full ZSH test suite with CI
  • ✅ Worktree integration - cc wt <branch> for Claude in worktrees
  • ✅ Git feature workflow - g feature start/sync/finish
  • ✅ Dopamine features - Win tracking, streaks, daily goals

docs.title: Pure ZSH Architecture
docs.text:
• 🚀 Sub-10ms response - No Node.js runtime
  • 📦 Zero dependencies - Just ZSH and Git
  • 🔌 Plugin manager support - antidote, zinit, oh-my-zsh

Current status: v4.4.x is production-ready and actively maintained.

docs.title: For ADHD-Friendly Learning
docs.text:
• ✅ Hands-on learners: Jump straight to Tutorial 1
  • ✅ Reference learners: Bookmark Command Reference
  • ✅ Speed learners: Use the 5-Minute Quick Start

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
• Start small: Don't try to learn everything at once
  • Practice immediately: Use what you learn right away
  • Bookmark references: Keep quick reference cards handy
  • Ask questions: Use GitHub Issues if you get stuck

docs.title: Progressive Mastery
docs.text:
1. Week 1: Basic workflow (Quick Start + Tutorial 1)
  2. Week 2: Multiple projects (Tutorial 2 + Dispatchers)
  3. Week 3: Advanced features (Dashboard modes + Dopamine)
  4. Month 2+: Customization (Contributing + Testing)

Ready to start? Pick your path above and dive in!

Questions? See the Getting Help section.

Version: v4.4.x Last updated: 2025-12-30

docs.title: Frequently Asked Questions
docs.text: Common questions and solutions for Flow CLI.

docs.title: Command not found: work / dash / flow
docs.text:
Problem: You get "command not found" when running flow-cli commands.

Solution: Ensure the plugin is sourced in your .zshrc:

# Check if sourced
which work

# If not found, add to ~/.zshrc:

# Via antidote (recommended)
antidote bundle data-wise/flow-cli

# Or manual source
source /path/to/flow-cli/flow.plugin.zsh

# Then reload
source ~/.zshrc

docs.title: How do I verify flow-cli is installed correctly?
docs.text:
Run the doctor command:

flow doctor

This checks all dependencies and shows what's missing.

docs.title: What dependencies does flow-cli need?
docs.text:
Required:

  • ZSH (your shell)
  • Git (for project detection)

Recommended:

  • fzf (for interactive pickers)
  • bat (for syntax highlighting)

Optional:

  • tig (for git log viewing)
  • Atlas (for enhanced state management)

Install recommended tools:

brew install fzf bat tig

docs.title: My project isn't detected
docs.text:
Problem: work my-project says "Project not found."

Solutions:

  1. Check project location:
# Projects should be under FLOW_PROJECTS_ROOT
echo $FLOW_PROJECTS_ROOT  # Default: ~/projects
ls ~/projects/
  1. Check for git:
# Projects must have a .git directory
ls -la ~/projects/my-project/.git
  1. Check category configuration: 
    # View configured categories
grep -A20 "PROJ_CATEGORIES" ~/.config/zsh/functions/pick.zsh

docs.title: How do I add a new project location?
docs.text:
Edit the PROJ_CATEGORIES in your config or set FLOW_PROJECTS_ROOT:

# In .zshrc
export FLOW_PROJECTS_ROOT="$HOME/code"  # Different root

# Or add categories in pick.zsh
PROJ_CATEGORIES=(
    "my-custom-folder:custom:🎨"
    # ... existing categories
)

docs.title: Wrong project type detected
docs.text:
Problem: flow-cli shows wrong icon/type for your project.

Solution: Check detection priority in lib/project-detector.zsh:

# Detection order:
# 1. DESCRIPTION → R package
# 2. package.json → Node.js
# 3. _quarto.yml → Quarto
# 4. pyproject.toml → Python
# etc.

# Add a .STATUS file to override:
echo "## Type: my-custom-type" > .STATUS

docs.title: How do I switch projects?
docs.text:
Option 1: Full session switch

work other-project
# Prompts to end current session

Option 2: Quick switch (tmux)

hop other-project
# Creates/switches tmux session

Option 3: Just cd

pick other-project
# Changes directory without session tracking

docs.title: Session conflicts: "Active session on X"
docs.text:
Problem: You get prompted about an existing session.

Solutions:

# Option 1: End current and start new
work other-project  # Say "yes" to switch

# Option 2: Check current session
flow status

# Option 3: Force end session
finish "Switching context"

docs.title: How do I see my session history?
docs.text:
# View worklog
cat ~/.local/share/flow/worklog | tail -20

# Or use dashboard
dash

docs.title: Wins not saving
docs.text:
Problem: win command runs but wins don't appear in yay.

Solutions:

# Check wins file location
echo $FLOW_DATA_DIR
ls -la ~/.local/share/flow/wins.md

# View raw file
cat ~/.local/share/flow/wins.md

# Check permissions
ls -la ~/.local/share/flow/

docs.title: How do I reset my streak?
docs.text:
Streaks reset automatically if you miss a day. To manually reset:

# Edit the worklog (advanced)
vim ~/.local/share/flow/worklog

docs.title: Goal not updating
docs.text:
# Check global goal
cat ~/.local/share/flow/goal.json

# Check project goal
grep daily_goal .STATUS

# Reset goal
flow goal set 3

docs.title: Wrong category detected for win
docs.text:
# Force category with flag
win --code "My accomplishment"
win --fix "Fixed something"
win --ship "Deployed feature"

# Available flags: --code, --docs, --review, --ship, --fix, --test

docs.title: Dashboard looks broken / colors wrong
docs.text:
Problem: Dashboard has weird characters or no colors.

Solutions:

# Check terminal supports 256 colors
echo $TERM  # Should be xterm-256color or similar

# In .zshrc, ensure:
export TERM=xterm-256color

# Check locale
echo $LANG  # Should be en_US.UTF-8 or similar

docs.title: Dashboard is slow
docs.text:
Problem: dash takes several seconds to load.

Solutions:

# Use fast mode
dash --fast

# Or limit scope
dash active  # Only active projects

# Check for too many projects
ls ~/projects | wc -l  # If > 50, consider organizing

docs.title: fzf picker not working
docs.text:
# Check fzf installed
which fzf

# Install if missing
brew install fzf

# Check SHELL is zsh
echo $SHELL

docs.title: "Not in a git repository"
docs.text:
Problem: Commands that need git don't work.

Solution: Initialize git in your project:

cd ~/projects/my-project
git init

docs.title: Finish command doesn't commit
docs.text:
Problem: finish doesn't prompt for commit.

Possible reasons:

  1. No git repository
  2. No uncommitted changes
  3. User said "no" to commit prompt
# Check git status
git status

# Manual commit
git add -A && git commit -m "Your message"

docs.title: Sync git failed
docs.text:
# Check for conflicts
git status

# If rebasing
git rebase --abort  # Cancel
# or
git rebase --continue  # After resolving

# Check remote
git remote -v

docs.title: I keep forgetting to log wins
docs.text:
Set up reminders:

# Add to your workflow
alias done='echo "Did you log your win? (win \"text\")"'

# Or use finish prompt
# finish automatically asks about uncommitted work

docs.title: Too many commands to remember
docs.text:
Start with just three:

work    # Start
win     # Log accomplishment
finish  # End

Everything else is optional enhancement.

docs.title: I lose track of what I was doing
docs.text:
Use breadcrumbs:

# Before switching context
crumb "Was working on auth module line 45"

# To see your trail
trail

docs.title: Can't decide what to work on
docs.text:
Let flow-cli decide:

js  # Just start - picks for you

# Or get suggestions
morning
next

docs.title: Commands are slow
docs.text:
# Check for issues
flow doctor

# Disable optional features
export FLOW_ATLAS_ENABLED=no  # If using atlas

# Use fast mode where available
dash --fast
pick --fast

docs.title: Too much output
docs.text:
# Quiet mode
export FLOW_QUIET=1

# Or per-command
flow sync all --quiet

docs.title: "Atlas not found"
docs.text:
Atlas is optional. If you don't use it:

# Disable in .zshrc
export FLOW_ATLAS_ENABLED=no

docs.title: "Permission denied"
docs.text:
# Check file permissions
ls -la ~/.local/share/flow/

# Fix permissions
chmod 755 ~/.local/share/flow
chmod 644 ~/.local/share/flow/*

docs.title: "fzf not found"
docs.text: brew install fzf

docs.title: Built-in help
docs.text:
# Main help
flow help

# Specific command
flow help work
work --help

# Dispatcher help
r help
g help
cc help

# Search commands
flow help --search git

docs.title: Health check
docs.text:
flow doctor
flow doctor --fix  # Interactive install

docs.title: Documentation
docs.text:
• Website: https://data-wise.github.io/flow-cli/
  • Issues: https://github.com/Data-Wise/flow-cli/issues

docs.title: Still Stuck?
docs.text:
1. Run flow doctor to check for issues
  2. Check the Troubleshooting Guide
  3. Search existing issues
  4. Open a new issue with:
  5. Your ZSH version: echo $ZSH_VERSION
  6. flow-cli version: flow version
  7. What you tried and what happened

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
Time: ~5 minutes | Level: Beginner

This guide walks you through installing flow-cli and verifying it works.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
Before starting, verify you have:

# Check ZSH (required)
zsh --version
# Expected: zsh 5.8 or higher

# Check Git (required)
git --version
# Expected: any recent version

docs.title: Quick Install (Recommended)
docs.text:
The easiest way to install:

curl -fsSL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Data-Wise/flow-cli/main/install.sh | bash

This auto-detects your plugin manager (antidote, zinit, oh-my-zsh) and installs accordingly.

docs.title: Manual Installation
docs.text:
Choose your plugin manager:

AntidoteZinitOh-My-ZshManual 
# Add to your plugins file
echo "Data-Wise/flow-cli" >> ~/.zsh_plugins.txt

# Regenerate plugins
antidote update

# Add to ~/.zshrc
zinit light Data-Wise/flow-cli

# Clone to custom plugins
git clone https://github.com/Data-Wise/flow-cli.git \
  ${ZSH_CUSTOM:-~/.oh-my-zsh/custom}/plugins/flow-cli

# Add to plugins in ~/.zshrc
plugins=(... flow-cli)

# Clone repository
git clone https://github.com/Data-Wise/flow-cli.git ~/.flow-cli

# Add to ~/.zshrc
echo 'source ~/.flow-cli/flow.plugin.zsh' >> ~/.zshrc

docs.title: Reload Shell
docs.text:
source ~/.zshrc
# Or just restart your terminal

docs.title: Checkpoint
docs.text:
• [ ] flow --version shows version number
  • [ ] flow doctor runs without errors

docs.title: Health Check
docs.text:
Run the built-in doctor command:

flow doctor

Expected output: 

flow doctor - Health Check

Core Commands:
  ✓ work     - Start work session
  ✓ finish   - End session
  ✓ dash     - Project dashboard
  ✓ win      - Log accomplishment
  ✓ pick     - Project picker

Dispatchers:
  ✓ cc       - Claude Code
  ✓ g        - Git workflows
  ✓ r        - R package dev
  ...

Optional Tools:
  ✓ fzf      - Interactive picker
  ✓ bat      - Syntax highlighting
  ...

All checks passed!

docs.title: Fix Missing Dependencies
docs.text:
If any optional tools are missing:

# Interactive install
flow doctor --fix

# Auto-install all
flow doctor --fix -y

docs.title: Checkpoint
docs.text:
• [ ] flow doctor shows "All checks passed"
  • [ ] Core commands are available

docs.title: Part 3: Quick Test (~1 min)
docs.text:
Try the core commands:

# Start a work session
work my-project

# Log a win
win "Installed flow-cli"

# See your wins
yay

# End session
finish

docs.title: Checkpoint
docs.text:
• [ ] work starts a session
  • [ ] win logs accomplishments
  • [ ] yay shows your wins

docs.title: Installation Methods Comparison
docs.text: Method Command Best For Quick Install curl ... \| bash New users, auto-detection Antidote Add to .zsh_plugins.txt Antidote users Zinit zinit light ... Zinit users Oh-My-Zsh Clone to $ZSH_CUSTOM OMZ users Manual git clone + source Full control

docs.title: Optional: Install Recommended Tools
docs.text:
For the best experience, install these CLI tools:

# Using Homebrew (macOS)
brew install fzf eza bat zoxide fd ripgrep

# Or install from Brewfile
brew bundle --file=~/.flow-cli/setup/Brewfile
Tool Purpose Used By fzf Interactive picker pick, dash -i bat Syntax highlighting File previews eza Better ls Dashboard zoxide Smart cd Project navigation fd Better find File search ripgrep Fast grep Content search

docs.title: "command not found: flow"
docs.text:
Shell hasn't reloaded. Try:

source ~/.zshrc
# Or restart your terminal

docs.title: "command not found: work"
docs.text:
Plugin not loaded. Verify installation:

# Check if plugin file exists
ls ~/.flow-cli/flow.plugin.zsh  # Manual install
# or
ls ~/.oh-my-zsh/custom/plugins/flow-cli/  # OMZ install

# Re-source
source ~/.zshrc

docs.title: Plugin Manager Not Detected
docs.text:
Force a specific method:

INSTALL_METHOD=manual curl -fsSL .../install.sh | bash

Options: antidote, zinit, omz, manual

docs.title: Quick Update
docs.text:
# If installed via plugin manager
antidote update  # or zinit update

# If manual install
cd ~/.flow-cli && git pull

docs.title: Check for Updates
docs.text:
flow --version
# Compare with: https://github.com/Data-Wise/flow-cli/releases

docs.title: Remove Plugin
docs.text:
AntidoteZinitOh-My-ZshManual 
# Remove from ~/.zsh_plugins.txt
# Then: antidote update

# Remove zinit line from ~/.zshrc
zinit delete Data-Wise/flow-cli

rm -rf ${ZSH_CUSTOM:-~/.oh-my-zsh/custom}/plugins/flow-cli
# Remove from plugins=(...) in ~/.zshrc

rm -rf ~/.flow-cli
# Remove source line from ~/.zshrc

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
1. Quick Start: Follow Quick Start Guide for a 5-minute tutorial
  2. Learn Commands: See Command Reference
  3. Explore Dispatchers: Read Dispatcher Reference

Questions? See Troubleshooting or FAQ

docs.title: Quick Start Guide
docs.text: Get up and running with Flow CLI in 5 minutes.

docs.title: The Core Workflow
docs.text:
Flow CLI is built around a simple, ADHD-friendly workflow:

work my-project     # 1. Start a focused session
# ... do your work ...
win "Did the thing"  # 2. Log your wins
finish "Done!"       # 3. End and optionally commit

That's it! Everything else builds on this foundation.

docs.title: Step 1: Verify Installation
docs.text:
Check that flow-cli is loaded:

# Should show version
flow --version

# Should show help
flow help

If commands aren't found, ensure the plugin is sourced in your .zshrc:

# Via antidote
antidote load data-wise/flow-cli

# Or manual source
source /path/to/flow-cli/flow.plugin.zsh

docs.title: Step 2: Start Your First Session
docs.text:
# Start working on a project
work my-project

# Or use the interactive picker
work

You'll see:

━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━
📦 my-project (node)
━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━
🟢 Status: active
🎯 Focus: Implement new feature

What happened:

  • Changed to project directory
  • Started session tracking
  • Opened your editor
  • Showed project context

docs.title: Step 3: Log Your Wins
docs.text:
As you accomplish things, log them:

win "Implemented user login"
win "Fixed that annoying bug"
win --ship "Deployed to production"

Output:

🎉 WIN LOGGED! #code
Implemented user login

Keep it up! 🚀

docs.title: Win Categories
docs.text:
Wins are auto-categorized, or you can specify:

Flag Category Icon --code Code work 💻 --docs Documentation 📝 --fix Bug fix 🔧 --ship Deployed 🚀 --test Testing 🧪 --review Code review 👀

docs.title: Step 4: Check Your Progress
docs.text:
# Quick dashboard
dash

# Show recent wins
yay

# Weekly summary with graph
yay --week

docs.title: Step 5: End Your Session
docs.text:
# End session with a note
finish "Completed auth feature"

# You'll be prompted to commit if there are changes
# Commit 3 change(s)? [y/N] y
# ✓ Changes committed

docs.title: Daily Goals (Optional)
docs.text:
Set and track daily win goals:

# Set a goal of 3 wins per day
flow goal set 3

# Check progress
flow goal
# Today: ██████░░░░ 2/3 wins

docs.title: Workflow
docs.text: Command Description work [project] Start a focused session finish [note] End session, optionally commit hop <project> Quick switch (tmux) dash Project dashboard

docs.title: Capture & Celebrate
docs.text: Command Description win <text> Log an accomplishment yay Show recent wins catch <text> Quick idea capture crumb <text> Leave a breadcrumb

docs.title: Navigation
docs.text: Command Description pick Interactive project picker cc Launch Claude Code cc pick Pick project → Claude Code

docs.title: Smart Dispatchers
docs.text:
Flow CLI includes 6 domain-specific dispatchers:

Dispatcher Domain Example g Git g status, g push r R packages r test, r check qu Quarto qu preview, qu render mcp MCP servers mcp status, mcp logs obs Obsidian obs daily, obs search cc Claude Code cc, cc pick, cc yolo

Get help for any dispatcher:

g help
r help
cc help

docs.title: Tutorials (Recommended)
docs.text:
1. Your First Session - Deep dive into work
  2. Multiple Projects - Managing many projects
  3. AI-Powered Commands - Using flow ai

docs.title: Reference
docs.text:
• Command Quick Reference
  • Dispatcher Reference
  • Dopamine Features Guide

docs.title: Get Help
docs.text:
# Built-in help
flow help
dash --help
work --help

# Health check
flow doctor

docs.title: ADHD Tips
docs.text:
One Command to Start

Just type work and let the picker guide you. No need to remember project paths.

Log Wins Immediately

Don't wait - log wins as they happen. Each win gives you a dopamine boost!

Use Breadcrumbs

Before switching contexts, run crumb "was working on X" so you can pick up later.

Ready to dive deeper? Start with Tutorial 1: Your First Session.

docs.title: Troubleshooting Guide
docs.text: Common issues and solutions for Flow CLI.

docs.title: Table of Contents
docs.text:
• Installation Issues
  • Command Not Found Errors
  • Dashboard Problems
  • Project Detection Issues
  • Status Update Problems
  • Performance Issues
  • Git Integration Issues

docs.title: "zsh functions not loading"
docs.text:
Symptoms:

dash
# zsh: command not found: dash

Cause: Shell configuration not sourced

Solution:

# Reload shell configuration
source ~/.zshrc

# Or restart terminal

Verify:

# Check functions exist
ls ~/.config/zsh/functions/adhd-helpers.zsh

# Check .zshrc sources functions
grep "adhd-helpers" ~/.zshrc

docs.title: ".zshrc not found"
docs.text:
Symptoms:

source ~/.zshrc
# No such file or directory

Cause: Flow CLI installed in ~/.config/zsh/ but .zshrc not updated

Solution:

# Create/update .zshrc
echo 'source ~/.config/zsh/.zshrc' >> ~/.zshrc

# Reload
source ~/.zshrc

docs.title: "Functions work but aliases don't"
docs.text:
Symptoms:

dash  # works
rload # zsh: command not found

Cause: Alias file not sourced

Solution:

# Check if aliases.zsh exists
ls ~/.config/zsh/aliases.zsh

# Check if sourced in .zshrc
grep "aliases.zsh" ~/.config/zsh/.zshrc

# If missing, add:
echo 'source ~/.config/zsh/aliases.zsh' >> ~/.config/zsh/.zshrc
source ~/.zshrc

docs.title: "dash: command not found"
docs.text:
Quick fix:

# Option 1: Reload shell
source ~/.zshrc

# Option 2: Check function exists
type dash

# Option 3: Manually source
source ~/.config/zsh/functions/adhd-helpers.zsh

Permanent fix:

# Ensure .zshrc sources functions
cat ~/.config/zsh/.zshrc | grep adhd-helpers

# If missing, add:
echo 'source ~/.config/zsh/functions/adhd-helpers.zsh' >> ~/.config/zsh/.zshrc

docs.title: "flow: command not found"
docs.text:
Cause: Plugin not sourced in shell

Solution:

# Check if flow function exists
type flow

# If not found, ensure plugin is sourced in .zshrc:

# Via antidote (recommended)
antidote bundle data-wise/flow-cli

# Or manual source
source /path/to/flow-cli/flow.plugin.zsh

# Reload shell
source ~/.zshrc

# Verify
type flow

docs.title: "just-start: command not found"
docs.text:
Cause: Function not defined

Solution:

# Check if function exists
type just-start

# If not found, source the file
source ~/.config/zsh/functions/adhd-helpers.zsh

# Verify
type just-start

docs.title: "Dashboard won't launch"
docs.text:
Symptoms:

dash
# Error or blank output

Solutions:

# 1. Check terminal supports required features
echo $TERM  # Should be xterm-256color or similar

# 2. Check fzf is installed (for interactive mode)
which fzf
brew install fzf  # If missing

# 3. Reload plugin
source ~/.zshrc

# 4. Try different modes
dash          # Terminal dashboard
dash -i       # Interactive (requires fzf)
dash --fast   # Quick mode

docs.title: "Dashboard shows no projects"
docs.text:
Cause: No .STATUS files found

Solution:

# Create .STATUS for existing projects
cd ~/projects/your-category/your-project
flow status your-project --create

# Verify
flow status your-project --show

# Check dashboard
dash

docs.title: "Dashboard not refreshing"
docs.text:
Symptoms: Data doesn't update after changes

Solutions:

# 1. Press 'r' to refresh in dashboard

# 2. Use watch mode for live updates
dash --watch

# 3. Check .STATUS files are being updated
cat ~/projects/category/project/.STATUS

# 4. Restart terminal and reload
source ~/.zshrc
dash

docs.title: "Project type not detected"
docs.text:
Symptoms:

cd ~/projects/your-project
work .
# Project type not detected, opening in default editor

Cause: No recognized project files

Solution:

# For R packages, ensure these exist:
ls DESCRIPTION  # R package
ls package.json # Node.js
ls Cargo.toml   # Rust
ls *.qmd        # Quarto

# Or manually specify type:
flow status . --create
# Edit .STATUS file to set type manually

docs.title: "Wrong editor opens"
docs.text:
Symptoms: VS Code opens when you want RStudio

Solution:

# Check project type detection
cd ~/projects/your-project
cat .STATUS | grep type

# For R packages:
# Ensure DESCRIPTION file exists
ls DESCRIPTION

# Edit work function if needed
# (advanced - edit ~/.config/zsh/functions/work.zsh)

docs.title: "Project not appearing in dashboard"
docs.text:
Cause: No .STATUS file or wrong location

Solution:

# Check if .STATUS exists
cd ~/projects/category/project
ls -la .STATUS

# If missing, create it:
flow status project-name --create

# Check dashboard
dash

docs.title: "Status update fails"
docs.text:
Symptoms:

flow status project active P0 "Task" 80
# Error: Cannot update status

Solutions:

# 1. Check .STATUS file permissions
cd ~/projects/category/project
ls -la .STATUS

# If not writable:
chmod 644 .STATUS

# 2. Check .STATUS format
cat .STATUS
# Should have valid fields

# 3. Try creating fresh
mv .STATUS .STATUS.bak
flow status project --create

docs.title: "Interactive mode not working"
docs.text:
Symptoms: Prompts don't appear

Solution:

# Use quick mode instead:
flow status project active P1 "Task" 50

# Or check terminal:
# Ensure not in non-interactive shell
echo $-
# Should include 'i' for interactive

docs.title: "Progress not showing in dashboard"
docs.text:
Cause: .STATUS file format issue

Solution:

# Check .STATUS format
cd ~/projects/category/project
cat .STATUS

# Should have:
# progress: 80

# If missing or malformed, recreate:
flow status project active P1 "Task" 80

docs.title: "Dashboard slow to load"
docs.text:
Symptoms: Dashboard takes >2 seconds to load

Solutions:

# 1. Use fast mode
dash --fast

# 2. Filter to specific category
dash teaching
dash active

# 3. Check number of projects
ls -d ~/projects/*/* | wc -l
# If >50 projects, consider archiving old ones

# 4. Use targeted commands
dash active    # Only active projects

docs.title: "Commands feel laggy"
docs.text:
Symptoms: dash or status takes >2 seconds

Solutions:

# 1. Check filesystem speed
time ls ~/projects/*/*/.STATUS

# 2. Reduce project count
# Move completed/archived projects

# 3. Check disk space
df -h ~

# 4. Check for file sync conflicts
# (Dropbox, Google Drive, iCloud)

docs.title: "High CPU usage"
docs.text:
Symptoms: Shell processes consuming high CPU

Solutions:

# 1. Use fast mode for quick checks
dash --fast

# 2. Avoid watch mode unless needed
# dash --watch runs continuously

# 3. Check for runaway processes
ps aux | grep zsh

docs.title: "Git aliases not working"
docs.text:
Symptoms:

gst
# zsh: command not found: gst

Cause: OMZ git plugin not loaded

Solution:

# Check if plugin loaded
omz plugin list | grep git

# If not loaded, add to .zshrc:
# plugins=(git other-plugins)

# Or source manually:
source $ZSH/plugins/git/git.plugin.zsh

docs.title: "gcmsg doesn't work"
docs.text:
Symptoms:

gcmsg "message"
# zsh: command not found: gcmsg

Solution:

# Ensure git plugin loaded
grep "plugins=.*git" ~/.zshrc

# If missing, use full command:
git commit -m "message"

# Or add plugin:
# Edit ~/.zshrc, add 'git' to plugins array

docs.title: "Permissions denied"
docs.text:
Symptoms:

flow status project active P0 "Task" 80
# Error: Permission denied

Solution:

# Check file permissions
cd ~/projects/category/project
ls -la .STATUS

# Fix permissions:
chmod 644 .STATUS

# Fix directory:
chmod 755 .

docs.title: "Encoding issues (weird characters)"
docs.text:
Symptoms: Dashboard shows � or other strange characters

Solution:

# Set UTF-8 encoding
export LANG=en_US.UTF-8
export LC_ALL=en_US.UTF-8

# Add to .zshrc for permanence:
echo 'export LANG=en_US.UTF-8' >> ~/.zshrc
echo 'export LC_ALL=en_US.UTF-8' >> ~/.zshrc

docs.title: "Time zone issues"
docs.text:
Symptoms: Timestamps wrong in dashboard

Solution:

# Check system timezone
date

# Set timezone (example: US Eastern)
export TZ='America/New_York'

# Add to .zshrc:
echo 'export TZ="America/New_York"' >> ~/.zshrc

docs.title: Check Logs
docs.text:
# Enable debug mode
export FLOW_DEBUG=1
source ~/.zshrc

# Run command with debug output
dash 2>&1 | tee debug.log

# Check for shell errors
zsh -x -c 'source flow.plugin.zsh' 2>&1 | head -50

docs.title: Verify Installation
docs.text:
# Run health check
flow doctor

# Check all components
type flow work dash pick
type cc g mcp r qu

# Check plugin is sourced
grep -r "flow-cli" ~/.zshrc ~/.config/zsh/

docs.title: Reset to Defaults
docs.text:
# Backup current config
cp ~/.config/zsh/.zshrc ~/.config/zsh/.zshrc.backup

# Re-source clean config
source ~/.config/zsh/.zshrc

# If still broken, re-source the plugin:
source /path/to/flow-cli/flow.plugin.zsh

# Or reinstall via antidote:
antidote update data-wise/flow-cli

docs.title: Report Issues
docs.text:
If you can't solve the issue:

  1. Check existing docs:
  2. Quick Start
  3. Installation

  4. Tutorial 1

  5. Gather debug info:

# System info
echo "OS: $(uname -a)"
echo "Shell: $SHELL"
echo "ZSH: $ZSH_VERSION"

# Flow CLI info
flow doctor
type flow
ls -la ~/.config/zsh/functions/
  1. Create issue file:
# Create detailed bug report
cat > ~/FLOW-CLI-ISSUE.md <<EOF
## Issue Description
[Describe what's wrong]

## Steps to Reproduce
1. Command I ran: ...
2. What happened: ...
3. What I expected: ...

## Environment
OS: $(uname -a)
Shell: $SHELL
ZSH Version: $ZSH_VERSION

## Error Output
[Paste error messages]

## What I've Tried
- Tried X: didn't work
- Tried Y: same error
EOF

docs.title: Quick Reference
docs.text:
Most Common Fixes:

# 1. Reload shell
source ~/.zshrc

# 2. Check function exists
type dash
type flow

# 3. Manually source plugin
source /path/to/flow-cli/flow.plugin.zsh

# 4. Run health check
flow doctor

# 5. Reset dashboard
dash          # Terminal dashboard
dash --fast   # Quick mode

docs.text:

docs.title: Dopamine Features Guide
docs.text:
Motivation-boosting features for sustained productivity

Last Updated: 2025-12-26 Version: v3.5.0 Target Audience: All users wanting to stay motivated

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Flow CLI v3.5.0 introduces dopamine features - small, visible rewards that reinforce good work habits. These features are designed with ADHD users in mind but benefit everyone.

Key Concepts:

Feature Purpose Command Win Tracking Celebrate accomplishments win, yay Streak Counter Build momentum dash Daily Goals Progress visibility flow goal Categories Organized wins Auto-detected

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
# Log a win
win "Fixed the login bug"

# See your wins
yay

# Check your streak
dash

# Set a daily goal
flow goal set 3

docs.title: Logging Wins
docs.text:
The win command logs accomplishments with automatic categorization:

# Basic usage
win "Implemented user authentication"

# With explicit category
win --category ship "Deployed v3.5.0 to production"

# Short form
win "Fixed bug #123"

docs.title: Win Categories
docs.text:
Wins are automatically categorized based on keywords:

Category Icon Trigger Words code 💻 implement, add, create, build, refactor docs 📝 doc, readme, guide, tutorial, comment review 👀 review, pr, feedback, approve ship 🚀 deploy, release, ship, publish, merge fix 🔧 fix, bug, issue, resolve, patch test 🧪 test, spec, coverage, passing other ✨ (default)

docs.title: Viewing Wins
docs.text:
# Recent wins (default: last 5)
yay

# Weekly summary with activity graph
yay --week

# All wins from today
yay --today

# Wins by category
yay --category code

Example Output:

🎉 Recent Wins
━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━

💻 Implemented user authentication       2h ago
🔧 Fixed the login bug                   4h ago
📝 Updated README with new features      yesterday

━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━
Total: 3 wins | Streak: 🔥 5 days

docs.title: Streak Counter
docs.text: Streaks track consecutive days with at least one work session.

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
1. Start a session → Counts toward today's streak
  2. Work consecutive days → Streak increases
  3. Miss a day → Streak resets to 0

docs.title: Viewing Your Streak
docs.text:
The streak appears in:

  • Dashboard header: 🔥 5 day streak
  • Win display: Shows at bottom of yay
  • Status output: Part of extended status
# Quick streak check
dash

# Detailed view
status --extended

docs.title: Streak Benefits
docs.text: Streak Visual Meaning 0-2 🌱 Building momentum 3-6 🔥 On a roll 7-13 🔥🔥 Strong week 14+ 🔥🔥🔥 Exceptional streak

docs.title: Daily Goals
docs.text: Set a target number of wins per day to stay motivated.

docs.title: Setting Goals
docs.text:
# Set global daily goal (applies to all projects)
flow goal set 3

# Set per-project goal (overrides global)
flow goal set 5 --project flow-cli

# View current goal and progress
flow goal

docs.title: Goal Progress
docs.text:
The goal appears in the dashboard wins section:

🎯 Daily Goal: ██████░░░░ 2/3 wins

docs.title: Per-Project Goals
docs.text:
Add to your project's .STATUS file:

## daily_goal: 5

This overrides the global goal when working in that project.

Priority Order:

  1. Project .STATUS → daily_goal field
  2. Global ~/.local/share/flow/goal.json
  3. Default: 3 wins

docs.title: Extended .STATUS Format
docs.text:
v3.5.0 adds new fields to the .STATUS file format:

## Project: my-project

## Type: node

## Status: active

## Phase: Development

## Priority: 1

## Progress: 45

## daily_goal: 3

## wins: Deployed v1.0 (2025-12-26)

## streak: 5

## last_active: 2025-12-26 14:30

## tags: typescript, api, backend

docs.title: New Fields
docs.text: Field Type Description daily_goal number Per-project win goal wins text Last win recorded streak number Current streak last_active datetime Last activity tags comma-sep Project tags for filtering

docs.title: Viewing Extended Status
docs.text:
# Show all extended fields
status --extended

# Or short form
status -e

docs.title: Dashboard Integration
docs.text:
All dopamine features appear in the dashboard:

dash

Dashboard Sections:

╭──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────╮
│  🌊 FLOW DASHBOARD ✓                     Dec 26, 2025  14:30 │
╰──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────╯

  📊 Today: 2 sessions, ⏱ 3h 45m        🔥 5 day streak

  💡 Keep it up! You're 2/3 of the way to your daily goal.

┌─ 🎉 Recent Wins ─────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│ 🎯 Daily Goal: ██████░░░░ 2/3                                │
│                                                              │
│ 💻 Implemented auth service              14:20               │
│ 🔧 Fixed login redirect bug              11:45               │
│ 📝 Updated API documentation             09:30               │
└──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

docs.title: Interactive TUI
docs.text:
The dashboard TUI (Terminal UI) now has keyboard shortcuts:

# Launch interactive dashboard
dash -i
# or
dash --interactive

docs.title: Keyboard Shortcuts
docs.text: Key Action Enter Open project Ctrl-E Edit .STATUS file Ctrl-S Show status Ctrl-W Log a win ? Show help Esc Exit

docs.title: Watch Mode
docs.text:
Auto-refresh the dashboard:

# Refresh every 5 seconds (default)
dash --watch

# Custom interval
dash --watch 10

docs.title: 1. Log Wins Immediately
docs.text:
Don't wait - log wins as soon as you complete something:

# After fixing a bug
win "Fixed the API timeout issue"

# After a code review
win "Reviewed PR #42"

docs.title: 2. Keep Goals Achievable
docs.text:
Start with a modest goal and increase:

# Start small
flow goal set 2

# Increase as you build the habit
flow goal set 3

docs.title: 3. Check Dashboard Daily
docs.text:
Make dash part of your morning routine:

# Morning check
dash

# Or use the morning command
morning

docs.title: 4. Use Categories
docs.text:
Let the system categorize, but override when needed:

# Auto-detection usually works
win "Deployed the new feature"  # → 🚀 ship

# Force category when unclear
win --category test "Wrote integration tests"

docs.title: Wins Not Showing
docs.text:
# Check wins file location
echo $FLOW_DATA_DIR/wins.log

# View raw wins file
cat ~/.local/share/flow/wins.log

docs.title: Streak Reset Unexpectedly
docs.text:
Streaks require at least one work session per day:

# Check worklog for gaps
cat ~/.local/share/flow/worklog | tail -20

docs.title: Goal Not Updating
docs.text:
# Check goal.json
cat ~/.local/share/flow/goal.json

# Check project .STATUS
cat .STATUS | grep daily_goal

docs.title: Related Commands
docs.text: Command Purpose win Log accomplishment yay View recent wins flow goal Manage daily goals dash Dashboard with wins section status -e Extended status with dopamine fields

docs.title: See Also
docs.text:
• Dashboard Quick Reference
  • Command Quick Reference
  • Workflow Quick Reference
