docs.title: Enhanced Help System - Quick Start Guide
docs.text: Date: 2025-12-14 Status: ✅ Phase 1 Complete

docs.title: What's New?
docs.text:
All 8 smart functions now have beautiful, colorized, ADHD-optimized help:

  • r - R Package Development
  • cc - Claude Code CLI
  • qu - Quarto Publishing
  • gm - Gemini CLI
  • focus - Pomodoro Focus Timer
  • note - Apple Notes Sync
  • obs - Obsidian Knowledge Base
  • workflow - Activity Logging

docs.title: Quick Demo
docs.text:
Try any of these:

r help          # Enhanced R package help
cc help         # Claude Code help
qu help         # Quarto help
gm help         # Gemini help
focus help      # Focus timer help
note help       # Notes sync help
obs help        # Obsidian help
workflow help   # Workflow logging help

Or use the short alias:

r h             # Same as r help

docs.title: What You'll See
docs.text: Each help screen now features:

docs.title: 2. Most Common Commands (🔥)
docs.text: Green section - The 3-4 commands you use 80% of the time

docs.title: 3. Quick Examples (💡)
docs.text: Yellow section - Real usage patterns you can copy/paste

docs.title: 4. Organized Sections (📋/🤖/⏱️)
docs.text: Blue sections - All commands grouped logically

docs.title: 5. Shortcuts Still Work (🔗)
docs.text: Magenta section - Your old muscle memory still works!

docs.title: 6. More Help Coming Soon (📚)
docs.text: Magenta section - Hints at future capabilities

docs.title: Colors Make Everything Better
docs.text:
• Green - Most important (Most Common)
  • Yellow - Learn by example (Quick Examples)
  • Blue - Organized sections
  • Cyan - Command names stand out
  • Magenta - Related info (shortcuts, more help)
  • Dim - Comments don't distract

docs.title: ADHD-Optimized
docs.text:
• <3 seconds to find what you need
  • Most used first - no scrolling through lists
  • Examples show usage - not just descriptions
  • Visual hierarchy - your eye knows where to go
  • No overwhelm - progressive disclosure

docs.title: Smart & Accessible
docs.text:
• NO_COLOR support - set NO_COLOR=1 to disable colors
  • Terminal detection - only uses colors in interactive terminals
  • Unicode safe - box drawing works everywhere
  • Backward compatible - nothing breaks, everything improves

docs.title: Example: r help
docs.text:
Before:

r <action> - R Package Development

CORE WORKFLOW:
  r load         Load package (devtools::load_all)
  r test         Run tests (devtools::test)
  r doc          Generate docs (devtools::document)
  ... (20+ more lines)

After:

╭─────────────────────────────────────────────╮
│ r - R Package Development                   │
╰─────────────────────────────────────────────╯

🔥 MOST COMMON (80% of daily use):
  r test             Run all tests
  r cycle            Full cycle: doc → test → check
  r load             Load package into memory

💡 QUICK EXAMPLES:
  $ r test                    # Run all tests
  $ r cycle                   # Complete development cycle
  $ r load && r test          # Quick iteration loop

📋 CORE WORKFLOW:
  r load             Load package (devtools::load_all)
  ...

Time saved: From 10 seconds scanning → <3 seconds finding what you need

docs.title: Disable Colors (If Needed)
docs.text:
# Temporarily disable colors
NO_COLOR=1 r help

# Or set in your environment
export NO_COLOR=1
r help

docs.title: What's Coming Next (Phase 2)
docs.text:
The "More Help" section hints at future modes:

# Coming soon:
r help full                # Complete reference
r help examples            # More examples
r ?                        # Interactive picker (fzf)

docs.title: Files
docs.text:
• Implementation: ~/.config/zsh/functions/smart-dispatchers.zsh
  • Backup: ~/.config/zsh/functions/smart-dispatchers.zsh.backup-phase1
  • Tests: ~/.config/zsh/tests/test-smart-functions.zsh
  • Report: ~/projects/dev-tools/flow-cli/PHASE1-IMPLEMENTATION-REPORT.md
  • Comparison: ~/projects/dev-tools/flow-cli/PHASE1-VISUAL-COMPARISON.md

docs.title: Colors don't show?
docs.text:
• Check if your terminal supports colors
  • Try echo -e "\033[0;32mGREEN\033[0m" to test
  • Set NO_COLOR=1 if colors cause issues

docs.title: Help looks weird?
docs.text:
• Your terminal might not support Unicode box drawing
  • Everything still works, just looks different
  • Try a modern terminal (iTerm2, Alacritty, etc.)

docs.title: Old shortcuts still work?
docs.text:
• ✅ Yes! All shortcuts preserved
  • rload, ccplan, qp, etc. all work exactly as before
  • Nothing breaks, everything improves

docs.title: Testing
docs.text:
All enhanced help functions have been tested:

# Run the test suite
cd ~/.config/zsh/tests
zsh test-smart-functions.zsh

# Results: 88/91 tests passing (96%)
# 3 minor text mismatches (cosmetic only)

docs.title: Feedback
docs.text:
This is Phase 1 of a multi-phase enhancement. Future phases will add:

  • Multi-mode help (quick/full/examples)
  • Search functionality
  • Interactive fzf picker

Let me know what works well and what could be better!

Enjoy your enhanced help system! 🎉

Status: ✅ Live and Ready to Use Implemented: 2025-12-14 Time: 2.5 hours Functions Enhanced: 8/8 (100%)

docs.title: 📊 Mermaid Diagrams - Quick Start Guide
docs.text: Status: Ready to implement Time to first diagram: 30 minutes Value: High (ADHD-friendly visual documentation)

docs.title: ✅ YES, Add Mermaid Diagrams!
docs.text:
Your Question: Should we include Mermaid diagrams for dash and other commands?

Answer: ⭐ Absolutely YES! Here's why:

  1. ADHD-Friendly - Visual > text for understanding flow
  2. Quick Reference - Glance at diagram vs read paragraphs
  3. Already Supported - MkDocs Material has built-in Mermaid support
  4. Low Effort - 30 min per diagram, high impact
  5. Proven Value - Other projects (GitHub, Rust) use extensively

docs.title: 1. Comprehensive Brainstorm Document
docs.text:
File: PROPOSAL-MERMAID-DIAGRAM-DOCUMENTATION.md

Contents:

  • 6 diagram type categories (flowchart, decision tree, state, sequence, etc.)
  • Multiple implementation approaches (incremental, comprehensive, hybrid)
  • Priority matrix (high/medium/low priority commands)
  • 6 creative ideas (interactive diagrams, animations, etc.)
  • Complete technical implementation guide
  • ADHD-friendly design principles
  • Success metrics and maintenance plan

Key Recommendation: Start with dash diagram today (30 min), then expand incrementally.

docs.title: 2. Example Documentation Page
docs.text:
File: EXAMPLE-dash-command-doc.md

Features:

  • ✅ Simple flowchart (quick view)
  • ✅ Detailed flowchart (expandable, 40+ nodes)
  • ✅ Text alternative (accessibility)
  • ✅ Step-by-step procedure
  • ✅ Usage examples with outputs
  • ✅ Troubleshooting section
  • ✅ Related commands
  • ✅ Best practices

Use as: Template for documenting other commands

docs.title: Option A: Quick Win (30 minutes)
docs.text:
Do right now:

  1. Copy EXAMPLE-dash-command-doc.md to docs/commands/dash.md
  2. Test rendering: mkdocs serve
  3. View at http://localhost:8000/commands/dash/
  4. Ship it!

Result: One high-quality diagram-rich command page

docs.title: Option B: Strategic Rollout (2 hours over 1 week)
docs.text:
Week 1:

  • [ ] Day 1: dash command (30 min)
  • [ ] Day 2: Command selection decision tree (20 min)
  • [ ] Day 3: pick command flowchart (20 min)
  • [ ] Day 4: work command sequence diagram (30 min)
  • [ ] Day 5: Review and user feedback (20 min)

Result: 4 diagram-rich pages, established pattern

docs.title: Option C: Comprehensive Documentation (10 hours over 1 month)
docs.text:
Phase 1 (Week 1): Core commands (4 diagrams) Phase 2 (Week 2): Smart dispatchers (6 diagrams) Phase 3 (Week 3): Advanced flows (5 diagrams) Phase 4 (Week 4): Templates and guidelines

Result: 15+ diagrams, complete visual documentation system

docs.title: 💡 Recommended Choice
docs.text:
⭐ Option A (Quick Win) + Option B (Strategic Rollout)

Why:

  • Immediate value with dash diagram
  • Low risk, high impact
  • User feedback drives priorities
  • Sustainable pace (20-30 min/day)

docs.title: 1. Flowchart Template
docs.text:
flowchart TD
    Start([User Input]) --> Process{Decision?}
    Process -->|Yes| ActionA[Action A]
    Process -->|No| ActionB[Action B]
    ActionA --> End([Done])
    ActionB --> End

    style Start fill:#4CAF50,stroke:#2E7D32,color:#fff
    style End fill:#4CAF50,stroke:#2E7D32,color:#fff

docs.title: 2. Decision Tree Template
docs.text:
graph TD
    Q1{What do you want?}
    Q1 -->|Option A| ResultA[Use: command-a]
    Q1 -->|Option B| ResultB[Use: command-b]

    style ResultA fill:#FFC107,stroke:#F57C00,color:#000
    style ResultB fill:#FFC107,stroke:#F57C00,color:#000

docs.title: 3. State Diagram Template
docs.text:
stateDiagram-v2
    [*] --> StateA
    StateA --> StateB : event
    StateB --> StateC : event
    StateC --> [*]

docs.title: 🎨 Color Scheme (Copy-Paste Ready)
docs.text:
Success/Start:  #4CAF50 (Green)
Process/Action: #2196F3 (Blue)
Decision/Choice:#FFC107 (Yellow)
Error/Block:    #F44336 (Red)
Info/Reference: #9C27B0 (Purple)
Neutral/End:    #757575 (Gray)

Usage:

style NodeName fill:#4CAF50,stroke:#2E7D32,color:#fff

docs.title: 🔍 MkDocs Configuration Check
docs.text:
Verify Mermaid is enabled:

# Check mkdocs.yml for:
cat mkdocs.yml | grep -A 5 "superfences"

Should see:

markdown_extensions:
  - pymdownx.superfences:
      custom_fences:
        - name: mermaid
          class: mermaid
          format: !!python/name:pymdownx.superfences.fence_code_format

If missing, add it!

docs.title: ✅ Quality Checklist
docs.text:
Before publishing each diagram:

  • [ ] Clarity - Can user understand flow in 30 seconds?
  • [ ] Simplicity - Is there a simpler version for quick view?
  • [ ] Accessibility - Does it have text alternative?
  • [ ] Colors - Uses consistent color scheme?
  • [ ] Labels - Are all nodes clearly labeled?
  • [ ] Testing - Renders correctly locally?

docs.title: 📊 High-Priority Commands for Diagrams
docs.text: Priority Command Reason Effort 🔥 P0 dash Complex, multi-step, high-traffic 30 min 🔥 P0 Decision tree Common user question 20 min ⭐ P1 pick Interactive, branching logic 20 min ⭐ P1 work Multiple side effects 30 min 📋 P2 cc / gm Project integration 15 min each

docs.title: 🎓 Learning Resources
docs.text:
• Mermaid Live Editor - Test diagrams interactively
  • Mermaid Docs - Full syntax reference
  • Example dash doc - Live example with diagrams

docs.title: 🚀 START HERE: 30-Minute Action Plan
docs.text:
Goal: Ship your first diagram-rich doc page

  1. Review existing example (5 min)
# See how diagrams are used in existing docs
cat docs/commands/dash.md | grep -A 10 "mermaid"
  1. Verify MkDocs config (5 min)
  2. Check mkdocs.yml has Mermaid support

  3. Add if missing

  4. Test locally (10 min)

mkdocs serve
# Open http://localhost:8000/commands/dash/
  1. Customize (10 min)
  2. Update any project-specific details
  3. Adjust examples if needed

  4. Verify diagrams render correctly

  5. Ship it! 

    git add docs/commands/dash.md
git commit -m "docs: add dash command with Mermaid diagrams"

docs.title: 💬 Get Feedback
docs.text:
After shipping first diagram:

Ask users:

  • Does the diagram help you understand the command?
  • What would make it more useful?
  • Which other commands need diagrams?

Iterate based on feedback!

docs.title: 📈 Success Metrics
docs.text:
Track these:

  • Page views on diagram pages
  • Time spent on page (should decrease!)
  • User questions about command flow (should decrease!)
  • Contributor PRs referencing diagrams

docs.title: 🎯 Summary
docs.text:
What: Add Mermaid flowcharts and diagrams to command documentation

Why: ADHD-friendly visual reference, faster comprehension

How: Start with dash command (30 min), expand incrementally

When: Start today with Option A (Quick Win)

Result: Clear, visual, scannable documentation that answers "how does this work?" at a glance

Files Created:

  1. ✅ PROPOSAL-MERMAID-DIAGRAM-DOCUMENTATION.md - Full brainstorm
  2. ✅ EXAMPLE-dash-command-doc.md - Template implementation
  3. ✅ MERMAID-DIAGRAMS-QUICK-START.md - This guide

Ready to ship? Start with the 30-minute action plan above! 🚀

docs.title: Project Management Workflow - ADHD-Friendly Tutorial
docs.text: Last Updated: 2025-12-21 (Updated for flow-cli rename and 28-alias system) Read Time: 5 minutes (lots of examples!)

docs.title: 🎯 The Four Commands You Need
docs.text:
┌──────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│                                              │
│  dash       → See all your projects          │
│  just-start → Pick one automatically         │
│  work       → Start working on it            │
│  status     → Update its status              │
│                                              │
└──────────────────────────────────────────────┘

That's it! Four commands.

docs.title: 📖 Tutorial Format
docs.text:
Each command below has:

  • 🎯 What it does (one sentence)
  • 💻 How to use it (examples)
  • ✅ When to use it (scenarios)
  • 🎨 What you'll see (output examples)

Tip: Try each command as you read!

docs.title: 🎯 What it does
docs.text: Shows all your projects with their status, priority, and progress.

docs.title: 💻 How to use it
docs.text:
# See everything
dash

# Filter by category
dash teaching        # Just teaching projects
dash research        # Just research projects
dash packages        # Just R packages
dash dev             # Just dev tools

docs.title: ✅ When to use it
docs.text:
• Morning: Start your day - see what's active
  • Mid-day: Check what needs attention
  • Context switch: Remind yourself what you're working on
  • Planning: Review all projects at once

docs.title: 🎨 What you'll see
docs.text:
╭─────────────────────────────────────────────╮
│ 🎯 YOUR WORK DASHBOARD                      │
╰─────────────────────────────────────────────╯

🔥 ACTIVE NOW (3):
  📦 mediationverse [P0] 85% - Run final simulations
  📚 stat-440 [P1] 30% - Grade assignment 3
  🔧 flow-cli [P2] 100% - Phase 1 complete

📋 READY TO START (2):
  📦 medfit [P1] 0% - Add vignette
  📊 product-of-three [P1] 60% - Review simulations

⏸️  PAUSED (1):
  📊 collider [P2] 90% - Waiting for review

💡 Quick: work <name> to start

Colors:

  • 🔥 Red = ACTIVE
  • 📋 Cyan = READY
  • ⏸️ Yellow = PAUSED
  • 🚫 Dim = BLOCKED

Priorities:

  • [P0] = Critical (red)
  • [P1] = Important (yellow)
  • [P2] = Normal (blue)

docs.title: 🎯 What it does
docs.text: Automatically picks your highest-priority project and takes you there.

docs.title: 💻 How to use it
docs.text: just-start      # That's it!

docs.title: ✅ When to use it
docs.text:
• Morning: Let it pick for you (zero decisions!)
  • After break: Resume work automatically
  • Context switch: Jump to most important thing
  • Decision paralysis: Can't decide? Let just-start decide!

docs.title: 🎨 What you'll see
docs.text:
🎲 Finding your next task...

┌─────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│ 🎯 DECISION MADE FOR YOU                    │
├─────────────────────────────────────────────┤
│ Project: 📦 mediationverse                  │
│ Type:    r-package                          │
│ Reason:  P0 priority (critical)             │
│ Next:    Run final simulations              │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────┘

💡 Quick actions:
   work .        = Start working
   status .      = Update status
   dash          = See all projects

📁 /Users/dt/projects/r-packages/active/mediationverse

How it picks:

  1. P0 + active → Highest priority
  2. P1 + active → Important work
  3. Any active → Current work
  4. Most recent → What you touched last

Zero decisions needed!

docs.title: 🎯 What it does
docs.text: Opens your editor in a project directory.

docs.title: 💻 How to use it
docs.text:
# Full project name
work mediationverse

# Short name (fuzzy match)
work med            # → mediationverse
work stat           # → stat-440

# From current directory
cd ~/projects/r-packages/active/mediationverse
work .              # Open current project

# No args (not implemented yet)
work                # Would open current project or show picker

docs.title: ✅ When to use it
docs.text:
• After just-start: Pick a project → start working
  • After dash: See all → pick one → start
  • Direct jump: You know what you want to work on
  • Resume work: Jump back to a project

docs.title: 🎨 What you'll see
docs.text:
work mediationverse

What happens:

  1. Changes to project directory
  2. Detects project type (R package, Quarto, etc.)
  3. Opens appropriate editor:
  4. R package → RStudio or Emacs
  5. Quarto → VS Code or Cursor
  6. Research → Emacs
  7. Dev tools → VS Code

Editor opens automatically!

docs.title: 🎯 What it does
docs.text: Updates a project's status, priority, task, and progress.

docs.title: 💻 How to use it
docs.text:
Interactive mode (Recommended - it guides you):

# Update specific project
status mediationverse

# What you'll see:
📋 Current status: active
   New status? (active/paused/blocked/ready): active

📊 Current priority: P0
   New priority? (P0/P1/P2): P0

📝 Current task: Run final simulations
   New task: Complete final simulations

⏱️  Current progress: 85
   New progress (0-100): 95

✅ Updated mediationverse!

Quick mode (if you know all values):

status mediationverse active P0 "Complete sims" 95

Create mode (start tracking a new project):

status newproject --create

Show mode (just view, don't update):

status mediationverse --show

docs.title: ✅ When to use it
docs.text:
• End of work session: Update progress before stopping
  • Status change: Mark as paused, blocked, or active
  • Priority change: Adjust priority as things change
  • Task complete: Update to next task
  • New project: Create .STATUS file

docs.title: 🎨 What you'll see (Interactive)
docs.text:
📋 UPDATE STATUS: mediationverse
═══════════════════════════════════════════

Current values shown in [brackets]

Status? [active]
   (active/paused/blocked/ready)
> active

Priority? [P0]
   (P0=critical, P1=important, P2=normal)
> P0

Next task? [Run final simulations]
> Complete final simulations and write up

Progress? [85]
   (0-100)
> 95

✅ Updated! Press Enter to continue...

Fields explained:

  • Status: What stage is the project in?
  • active = Currently working on
  • ready = Ready to start
  • paused = On hold

  • blocked = Waiting for something

  • Priority: How urgent?

  • P0 = Critical (do today!)
  • P1 = Important (this week)

  • P2 = Normal (when you can)

  • Task: What's the next action?

  • Be specific: "Run simulation" not "Work on it"

  • Progress: How far along? (0-100%)

docs.title: Morning Routine
docs.text:
# 1. See what's active
dash

# 2. Let it pick for you
just-start

# 3. Start working
work .

Time: <30 seconds Decisions: Zero

docs.title: Check In During Day
docs.text:
# Quick status check
dash

# See specific category
dash teaching

# Jump to a project
work stat-440

Time: <10 seconds

docs.title: End of Work Session
docs.text:
# Update status before leaving
status mediationverse

> Status: paused
> Priority: P0
> Task: Resume tomorrow - almost done
> Progress: 95

✅ Updated!

Time: <30 seconds Benefit: You'll remember where you left off!

docs.title: Starting a New Project
docs.text:
# Create .STATUS file
cd ~/projects/r-packages/active/newpackage
status newpackage --create

# It creates:
project: newpackage
type: r-package
status: ready
priority: P2
progress: 0
next: Define first task
updated: 2025-12-14
category: r-packages

# Now appears in dashboard!
dash

docs.title: Project Switching
docs.text:
# See all projects
dash

# Notice something urgent
# Jump to it
work mediationverse

# Update its status
status mediationverse active P0 "Critical fix" 0

docs.title: 📊 Command Cheat Sheet
docs.text: Command Does Example dash Show all projects dash dash teaching Filter by category dash research just-start Auto-pick project just-start work <name> Start working work mediationverse work med Fuzzy match work stat status <name> Update (interactive) status medfit status <name> ... Quick update status medfit active P1 "Task" 50 status <name> --create Create .STATUS status newproject --create status <name> --show Just view status medfit --show

docs.title: Tip 1: Use Short Names
docs.text:
# Instead of:
work mediationverse

# Type:
work med

docs.title: Tip 2: Morning + Evening Routine
docs.text:
# Morning:
dash && just-start && work .

# Evening:
status . paused P0 "Resume here tomorrow" 90

docs.title: Tip 3: Categories for Focus
docs.text:
# Teaching time
dash teaching

# Research time
dash research

# Package work
dash packages

docs.title: Tip 4: Combine with win command
docs.text:
# After accomplishing something
win "Completed Phase 1 of help system"

# See today's wins
wins

docs.title: Tip 5: Use Dispatchers
docs.text:
# Smart context-aware commands:
cc               # Claude Code (project-aware)
gm               # Gemini (project-aware)
peek <file>      # Smart file viewer
qu               # Quarto operations

docs.title: ❓ Common Questions
docs.text:
Q: Where is my project data stored? A: In each project's .STATUS file.

Q: What if I don't have a .STATUS file? A: Use status <project> --create to create one.

Q: Can I edit .STATUS manually? A: Yes, but use status command - it's easier!

Q: What if I have many projects? A: Use category filters: dash teaching

Q: How does just-start pick? A: Priority order: P0 active → P1 active → any active → most recent

Q: Can I use this with my existing workflow? A: Yes! It works with work, r, cc, qu, etc.

docs.title: 🎨 Visual Summary
docs.text:
YOUR DAY WITH THESE COMMANDS
════════════════════════════

Morning:
  dash          → See overview
    ↓
  just-start    → Pick project
    ↓
  work .        → Start working

During Day:
  dash teaching → Check teaching projects
    ↓
  work stat-440 → Switch to one
    ↓
  status .      → Update progress

Evening:
  status .      → Update before leaving
    ↓
  win "..."     → Log your win
    ↓
  wins          → Feel good about progress!

docs.title: 🚦 Traffic Light System
docs.text:
Projects are color-coded by status:

  • 🔥 ACTIVE (red) = Working on now
  • 📋 READY (cyan) = Ready to start
  • ⏸️ PAUSED (yellow) = On hold
  • 🚫 BLOCKED (dim) = Waiting for something

Priorities are color-coded:

  • [P0] (red) = Do today!
  • [P1] (yellow) = This week
  • [P2] (blue) = When you can

Scan in 3 seconds!

docs.title: ✅ Quick Start Checklist
docs.text:
• [ ] Run dash to see current projects
  • [ ] Create .STATUS for projects without one: status <name> --create
  • [ ] Update statuses: status <name>
  • [ ] Try just-start to auto-pick
  • [ ] Use work to jump to projects
  • [ ] Check dash throughout the day

docs.title: 📚 Related Commands
docs.text:
These work great together:

Command Purpose why Show current context win "..." Log an accomplishment wins See today's wins gm Morning routine focus 25 Start focus timer

docs.title: 🎉 That's It!
docs.text:
You now know:

  • ✅ dash - See everything
  • ✅ just-start - Auto-pick
  • ✅ work - Start working
  • ✅ status - Update projects

Try it now:

dash

See your projects! 🚀

For detailed docs, see: WORKFLOW-IMPLEMENTATION-SUMMARY.md For quick reference: WORKFLOW-QUICK-REFERENCE.md

docs.title: 🧠 ADHD-Friendly Workflows - Quick Wins Guide
docs.text:
Focus: Top 10 highest-impact workflows for daily R package development

Read Time: 5 minutes | Apply Time: Immediate Last Updated: 2025-12-21 (Updated for 28-alias system)

docs.title: 📋 Table of Contents
docs.text:
# Workflow Time Load Use When 1 Quick Test 5 min 🟢 Made code changes 2 Load + Test 5 min 🟢 Fresh start on package 3 Doc + Test 8 min 🟢 Changed function docs 4 Full Check 60 min 🟡 Before git commit 5 Quick Commit 3 min 🟢 Ready to save work 6 Fix Failing Tests varies 🟡 Tests are red 7 Context Check 30 sec 🟢 Lost context 8 Focus Mode setup 🟢 Need concentration 9 Start Feature 2 min 🟢 Beginning new work 10 Emergency Recovery varies 🔴 Something broke 11 Git Feature Workflow 2 min 🟢 Feature branches 12 Worktrees 1 min 🟢 Parallel development

Cognitive Load: 🟢 Easy | 🟡 Medium | 🔴 Hard

docs.title: 1️⃣ Quick Test Cycle
docs.text: When: You made code changes and want quick feedback Time: ~5 minutes | Load: 🟢 Easy | Safety: 🟢 Safe

docs.title: Commands
docs.text: rtest                # Run all tests

docs.title: Visual Flow
docs.text: Code changes → rtest → 2-4 min wait → ✅ Green or ❌ Red

docs.title: Decision Points
docs.text:
• ✅ All green → Continue coding
  • ❌ Some red → Fix and re-run rtest
  • 🔴 Many red → Run rload then rtest to reload + test

docs.title: Pro Tips
docs.text: 💡 Set a 5-min timer while tests run (use focus 5) 💡 Tests too slow? Focus on specific test files 💡 Leave tests running and switch tasks (ADHD-friendly!)

docs.title: What Could Go Wrong?
docs.text:
• Tests hang → Ctrl+C to cancel, check for infinite loops
  • All tests fail → Run rpkg to verify you're in right package

docs.title: 2️⃣ Load + Test (Atomic)
docs.text: When: Fresh start, want to verify everything loads and works Time: ~5 minutes | Load: 🟢 Easy | Safety: 🟢 Safe

docs.title: Commands
docs.text: rload && rtest       # Load then test

docs.title: Visual Flow
docs.text: Start work → rload && rtest → Package loads → Tests run → ✅ or ❌

docs.title: Why This Works (ADHD-Optimized)
docs.text:
• Automated sequence → No decision fatigue
  • Clear output → Green = go, Red = stop
  • Verifies everything → Load + tests in one go

docs.title: When to Use
docs.text:
• 🌅 Morning start → Verify yesterday's work still works
  • 🔄 After git pull → Check if team changes broke anything
  • 🧹 After cleanup → Confirm nothing broke

docs.title: Pro Tips
docs.text: 💡 Combine with coffee break - perfect timing! 💡 First command of the day ritual 💡 Bookmark this as your "good morning" command

docs.title: 3️⃣ Document + Test
docs.text: When: You changed function documentation (roxygen comments) Time: ~8 minutes | Load: 🟢 Easy | Safety: 🟢 Safe

docs.title: Commands
docs.text: rdoc && rtest        # Document then test

docs.title: Visual Flow
docs.text: Change @param docs → rdoc && rtest → Docs regenerate → Tests run → ✅

docs.title: What This Does
docs.text:
1. ⏱️ [3-5s] Regenerates .Rd files from roxygen
  2. ⏱️ [3-5s] Updates NAMESPACE exports
  3. ⏱️ [2-4min] Runs all tests

docs.title: Common Scenario
docs.text:
You: Added new function parameter
You: Updated @param documentation
Run: rdoc && rtest
Result: Documentation updated + tests verify it works

docs.title: Pro Tips
docs.text: 💡 Always run after changing ANY roxygen comment 💡 Catches missing @export tags early 💡 Faster than full rcheck

docs.title: Safety Checks
docs.text:
• 🟢 Safe - only regenerates docs
  • Auto-backs up NAMESPACE (devtools handles this)

docs.title: 4️⃣ Full Check (Before Commit)
docs.text: When: Ready to commit, need to verify everything is perfect Time: ~60 minutes | Load: 🟡 Medium | Safety: 🟢 Safe

docs.title: Commands
docs.text:
rcycle               # Full cycle: doc → test → check
# OR (step by step)
rdoc && rtest && rcheck

docs.title: Visual Flow
docs.text: Ready to commit → rcycle → 60 min wait → ✅ 0 errors/warnings/notes

docs.title: What This Does
docs.text:
1. ⏱️ [5s] Documents package
  2. ⏱️ [2-4min] Runs tests
  3. ⏱️ [30-60min] Full R CMD check

docs.title: ADHD Strategy for Long Wait
docs.text:
• ⏰ Set timer → focus 60 for focus timer
  • 🎯 Switch context → Work on different package
  • ☕ Take break → Perfect time for lunch/walk
  • 📧 Other tasks → Email, admin work

docs.title: Decision Points
docs.text:
• ✅ 0 errors, 0 warnings, 0 notes → COMMIT! 🎉
  • ⚠️ Warnings/notes → Investigate (might be OK)
  • ❌ Errors → Fix, run rcheck again

docs.title: Pro Tips
docs.text: 💡 Run this before ANY git commit 💡 Use rcheckfast for quicker check (skips examples/vignettes) 💡 NEVER commit with errors

docs.title: What Could Go Wrong?
docs.text:
• Check fails → Read error messages carefully
  • Takes forever → Normal! R CMD check is thorough
  • Interrupted → Just re-run to continue

docs.title: 5️⃣ Quick Commit Workflow
docs.text: When: Tests pass, ready to save work to git Time: ~3 minutes | Load: 🟢 Easy | Safety: 🟢 Safe

docs.title: Commands
docs.text:
# Option 1: Quick (if already checked)
git add . && git commit -m "message"

# Option 2: Safe (docs + tests + commit)
rdoc && rtest && git add . && git commit -m "message"

# Option 3: Ultra-safe (full check + commit)
rdoc && rtest && rcheck && git add . && git commit -m "message"

docs.title: Visual Flow
docs.text: Code ready → git commit → Done in 30s

docs.title: Commit Message Templates
docs.text:
# Feature
git commit -m "feat: add sensitivity analysis function"

# Bug fix
git commit -m "fix: handle NA values in mediation estimate"

# Documentation
git commit -m "docs: update README with new examples"

# Tests
git commit -m "test: add tests for interaction effects"

# Refactor
git commit -m "refactor: simplify bootstrap algorithm"

docs.title: Decision Tree
docs.text:
Did you run rcheck?
├─ Yes → git add . && git commit -m "message"
├─ No → rdoc && rtest then commit (safer)
└─ Not sure → Full check first (safest)

docs.title: Pro Tips
docs.text: 💡 Commit often (every 30-60 min of work) 💡 Small commits = easier to undo 💡 Use clear messages (future you will thank you!)

docs.title: Safety Checks
docs.text:
• Always run tests before committing
  • Can undo with git reset HEAD~1 if needed

docs.title: 6️⃣ Fix Failing Tests
docs.text: When: Tests are red, need to debug Time: Varies | Load: 🟡 Medium | Safety: 🟢 Safe

docs.title: Step 1: Identify the Problem (2 min)
docs.text:
rtest                # Run tests, read error messages

Look for:

  • Which test file failed? (test-*.R)
  • Which expectation failed? (expect_equal, etc.)
  • What was expected vs actual?

docs.title: Step 2: Run Single Test (1 min)
docs.text:
# Run specific test file in R:
devtools::test_file("tests/testthat/test-myfunction.R")

docs.title: Step 3: Interactive Debugging (varies)
docs.text:
rload                # Load package
# Then in R console:
# debug(myfunction)
# Run test interactively

docs.title: Step 4: Fix and Verify (2 min)
docs.text:
# Fix the code
rtest                # Re-run all tests

docs.title: Common Test Failures
docs.text:
1. "Error: object not found"

  • Cause: Function not exported or loaded
  • Fix: Add @export tag, run rdoc && rtest

2. "Expected X but got Y"

  • Cause: Logic error or outdated test
  • Fix: Check function logic or update test

3. "Test times out"

  • Cause: Infinite loop or very slow code
  • Fix: Add timeout or optimize code

docs.title: ADHD-Friendly Debug Loop
docs.text:
1. Read error (30s)
2. Hypothesize fix (1 min)
3. Make ONE small change
4. Test immediately with `rtest`
5. Repeat until green

docs.title: Pro Tips
docs.text: 💡 Only fix ONE test at a time 💡 Use browser() for interactive debugging 💡 Take breaks if frustrated

docs.title: 7️⃣ Where Am I? (Context Check)
docs.text: When: Lost context, can't remember what you were doing Time: ~30 seconds | Load: 🟢 Easy | Safety: 🟢 Safe

docs.title: Commands
docs.text:
pwd                  # Show current directory
rpkg                 # Package info & status
git status           # Check git status

docs.title: Visual Output
docs.text:
rpkg → Shows:
- 📦 R package name + version
- 📊 Package description
- 🔧 Git branch

docs.title: Quick Recovery Checklist
docs.text:
• [ ] Run pwd → See where you are
  • [ ] Run rpkg → Package information
  • [ ] Run git status → Check git status
  • [ ] Check .STATUS file for next action

docs.title: Common Scenarios
docs.text:
"I forgot what I was working on"

pwd                  # Current directory
rpkg                 # Package info
cat .STATUS          # Check status file

"I don't remember what this package does"

rpkg                 # Package info
cat DESCRIPTION      # Read full description

"Did I make changes?"

git status           # Git status
git diff             # See changes

docs.title: Pro Tips
docs.text: 💡 Start every session with rpkg 💡 Keep .STATUS file updated 💡 Use git status frequently

docs.title: 8️⃣ Focus Mode (Deep Work)
docs.text: When: Need concentration, minimize distractions Time: Setup < 1 min | Load: 🟢 Easy | Safety: 🟢 Safe

docs.title: Commands
docs.text:
focus                # Minimize distractions
focus 25             # Focus + 25-min timer (Pomodoro)
unfocus              # Restore notifications

docs.title: What focus Does
docs.text:
1. ✅ Turns off macOS notifications
  2. ✅ Closes Slack, Mail, Messages
  3. ✅ Starts optional timer
  4. ✅ Announces when session ends

docs.title: Visual Flow
docs.text: Need focus → focus 25 → Work uninterrupted → Timer alert → Break

docs.title: Recommended Focus Workflows
docs.text:
Pomodoro (25 min)

f25                  # 25-minute focus timer
# Work for 25 min
# Timer alerts when done
# Take 5-min break

Deep Work (50 min)

f50                  # 50-minute deep work timer
# Work for 50 min
# Timer alerts when done
# Take 10-15 min break

Custom Duration

focus 90             # Custom 90-minute session
# Work until timer ends

docs.title: Pro Tips
docs.text: 💡 Use f25 or f50 aliases for common durations 💡 Use during rcheck 60-min wait 💡 Take regular breaks to maintain focus

docs.title: After Focus Session
docs.text:
# Update status and commit progress
git add . && git commit -m "Progress on X"

docs.title: 9️⃣ Start New Feature
docs.text: When: Beginning new function or feature Time: ~2 minutes | Load: 🟢 Easy | Safety: 🟢 Safe

docs.title: [ ] 1. Context Setup (30s)
docs.text:
pwd                  # Verify location
rpkg                 # Check package info
git status           # Check git status

docs.title: [ ] 2. Create Function File (30s)
docs.text:
# Create R/myfunction.R manually
# OR use usethis:
usethis::use_r("myfunction")

docs.title: [ ] 3. Create Test File (30s)
docs.text:
# Create tests/testthat/test-myfunction.R
# OR use usethis:
usethis::use_test("myfunction")

docs.title: [ ] 4. Document Template (30s)
docs.text:
Add roxygen skeleton:

#' Function Title
#'
#' @param x Description
#' @return Description
#' @export
#' @examples
#' myfunction(x = 1)
myfunction <- function(x) {
  # TODO: Implement
}

docs.title: [ ] 5. First Test (30s)
docs.text:
test_that("myfunction works", {
  result <- myfunction(x = 1)
  expect_true(!is.null(result))
})

docs.title: [ ] 6. Verify Setup
docs.text:
rload && rtest       # Load + test
# Should load successfully, test might fail (that's OK!)

docs.title: Quick Start Template
docs.text:
# Create files, then verify:
rload && rtest

docs.title: Pro Tips
docs.text: 💡 Start with test first (TDD approach) 💡 Make smallest working version 💡 Commit early: git commit -m "feat: add myfunction skeleton"

docs.title: 🔟 What Did I Break? (Emergency Recovery)
docs.text: When: Something broke and you're not sure what Time: Varies | Load: 🔴 Hard | Safety: 🟡 Careful

docs.title: Step 1: Assess Damage
docs.text:
pwd                  # Where am I?
git status           # What changed?
rtest                # Do tests pass?

docs.title: Step 2: Identify Problem
docs.text:
Tests failing?

rtest                # Run tests
# Read error messages carefully
# Jump to workflow #6 (Fix Failing Tests)

Package won't load?

rload                # Try to load
# Read error messages
# Common: syntax error, missing dependency

Git issues?

git status           # Git status
git log --oneline -5 # Recent commits

docs.title: Option A: Recent Changes (Most Common)
docs.text:
# Undo last commit (keeps changes)
git reset HEAD~1
# Fix the issue
rtest                # Verify tests pass
git add . && git commit -m "fix: ..."

docs.title: Option B: Code Error
docs.text:
# Use editor to fix syntax error
# Then:
rload                # Try loading again
rtest                # Run tests

docs.title: Option C: Clean Build (Last Resort)
docs.text:
# Clean and rebuild
rm -rf man/ NAMESPACE
rdoc && rtest        # Regenerate docs + test

docs.title: Prevention Checklist
docs.text:
• ✅ Run tests before commits
  • ✅ Commit frequently (small changes)
  • ✅ Use version control
  • ✅ Test after major changes

docs.title: Pro Tips
docs.text: 💡 Don't panic - almost everything is reversible 💡 Read error messages slowly (pause before acting) 💡 Ask for help: cc (Claude Code) or colleagues

docs.title: When to Ask for Help
docs.text:
• 🔴 Spent > 30 min stuck
  • 🔴 Don't understand error message
  • 🔴 Afraid of making it worse

docs.title: 🎯 Quick Decision Tree
docs.text:
Use this when you're not sure what to do:

What do you want to do?

├─ Just made code changes
│  └─ Run: rtest
│
├─ Starting work on package
│  └─ Run: rload && rtest
│
├─ Changed documentation
│  └─ Run: rdoc && rtest
│
├─ Ready to commit
│  ├─ Did full check? → git add . && git commit -m "msg"
│  └─ Not sure → rcheck then commit
│
├─ Tests are failing
│  └─ See workflow #6 (Fix Failing Tests)
│
├─ Don't know where I am
│  └─ Run: rpkg
│
├─ Need to focus
│  └─ Run: f25 or f50
│
├─ Starting new feature
│  └─ See workflow #9 (Start New Feature)
│
└─ Something broke
   └─ See workflow #10 (Emergency Recovery)

docs.title: ⏱️ Time-Based Quick Reference
docs.text:
"I have 5 minutes"

  • Run rtest (quick test)
  • Check rpkg (context)
  • Review .STATUS file

"I have 15 minutes"

  • Run rload && rtest
  • Fix one failing test
  • Quick commit

"I have 30 minutes"

  • Run rdoc && rtest
  • Start new feature
  • Focus session with f25

"I have 60+ minutes"

  • Run full rcheck
  • Deep work with f50 or focus 90
  • Multiple test-fix cycles

docs.title: Managing Wait Times
docs.text:
• Tests running (2-4 min)? → Perfect for coffee/bathroom
  • R CMD check (60 min)? → Switch to different task
  • Stuck debugging? → Take a 5-min break

docs.title: Preventing Context Loss
docs.text:
• Start every session: Check rpkg and .STATUS
  • End every session: Update .STATUS file
  • Commit frequently: Small commits = less to lose

docs.title: Reducing Decision Fatigue
docs.text:
• Use command chains: rload && rtest, rdoc && rtest
  • Follow workflows: Don't invent, follow the guide
  • Set timers: f25, f50, or focus commands

docs.title: Building Habits
docs.text:
• Morning ritual: rpkg → rload && rtest → check output
  • Before commit: rcheck → wait → commit
  • After break: rpkg → review .STATUS → resume

docs.title: 🚨 Common Mistakes & Fixes
docs.text: Mistake Why Bad Fix Skip testing Breaks accumulate Always run rtest No documentation Future you confused Run rdoc && rtest after changes Large commits Hard to debug Commit every 30-60 min Commit with errors Broken code in history Always test first Work without breaks Burnout, mistakes Use f25 or f50 timers Ignore .STATUS Lose context Update .STATUS regularly

docs.title: Connects to .STATUS Files
docs.text:
• Keep .STATUS updated with current progress
  • Check .STATUS at start of each session
  • Use for context when switching projects

docs.title: Works with Help System
docs.text:
• Forgot command? Check the alias reference card
  • Need reminder? Review this quick wins guide
  • Full reference → See ALIAS-REFERENCE-CARD.md

docs.title: Pairs with Focus Tools
docs.text:
• f25 / f50 → Pomodoro/deep work timers
  • focus <min> → Custom duration focus sessions
  • win → Log accomplishments

docs.title: 🎉 Success Patterns
docs.text:
Morning Start (5 min)

rpkg → rload && rtest → Coffee while tests run → Review results → Code

Quick Feature (30 min)

f25 → Create files → Code → rdoc && rtest

Pre-Commit (65 min)

rcheck → f60 focus session → Switch tasks → Check results → commit

End of Day (5 min)

rtest → git commit -m "wip: progress on X" → Update .STATUS for tomorrow

docs.title: 1️⃣1️⃣ Git Feature Branch Workflow (v4.1.0+)
docs.text: When: Working on new features, hotfixes, or any code changes Time: ~2 minutes | Load: 🟢 Easy | Safety: 🟢 Safe

docs.title: Commands
docs.text:
# Start a feature
g feature start auth-improvements

# Work on your feature...
g add . && g commit "Add OAuth2 support"

# Stay synced with dev
g feature sync

# Finish: push + create PR
g feature finish

docs.title: Visual Flow
docs.text: Start → feature start → code → commit → sync → finish → PR → merge

docs.title: Quick Reference
docs.text: Command What It Does g feature start <name> Create feature branch from dev g feature sync Rebase feature onto dev g feature list List feature/hotfix branches g feature finish Push + create PR to dev g promote Create PR: feature → dev g release Create PR: dev → main g feature prune Delete merged branches

docs.title: Workflow Guard
docs.text:
The workflow guard blocks direct pushes to protected branches:

# Blocked ❌
git checkout main && g push   # Direct push to main blocked

# Allowed ✅
g feature start my-fix        # Create feature branch
g push                        # Push feature branch OK
g promote                     # Create PR instead

docs.title: Pro Tips
docs.text: 💡 Run g feature sync daily to avoid merge conflicts 💡 Use g feature finish to push + create PR in one step 💡 Clean up with g feature prune weekly

docs.title: 1️⃣2️⃣ Parallel Development with Worktrees (v4.1.0+)
docs.text: When: Need to work on multiple features simultaneously Time: ~1 minute | Load: 🟢 Easy | Safety: 🟢 Safe

docs.title: Commands
docs.text:
# Create worktree for a branch
wt create feature/auth

# List all worktrees
wt list

# Navigate to worktrees folder
wt

# Clean up stale worktrees
wt clean

docs.title: Visual Flow
docs.text: Main work → wt create feature/b → Parallel work → wt clean

docs.title: Claude Code + Worktrees
docs.text:
Launch Claude in a dedicated worktree:

# Launch Claude in worktree (creates if needed)
cc wt feature/auth

# Pick from existing worktrees
cc wt pick

# Worktree + YOLO mode
cc wt yolo feature/risky

# Worktree + Plan mode
cc wt plan feature/complex

docs.title: Aliases
docs.text: Alias Expands To Description ccw cc wt Worktree + Claude ccwy cc wt yolo Worktree + YOLO mode ccwp cc wt pick Worktree picker

docs.title: When to Use Worktrees
docs.text:
• 🔀 Parallel features - Work on feature-a while feature-b runs tests
  • 👀 Code review - Review PR in isolated directory
  • 🧪 Experiments - Try risky changes without affecting main work
  • ⚡ Quick fixes - Hotfix while feature work continues

docs.title: Pro Tips
docs.text: 💡 Each worktree is completely isolated - no stashing needed 💡 Worktrees persist after Claude exits 💡 Use wt clean regularly to remove stale worktrees

docs.title: v4.3.0 Completed Features
docs.text:
• cc wt status - Shows worktrees with Claude session info (green/yellow/white indicators)
  • g feature prune --force - Adds confirmation prompt by default, --force to skip
  • g feature prune --older-than - Filter branches by age (30d, 1w, 2m)

docs.title: cc wt status (~1 hour)
docs.text:
Purpose: Show all worktrees with Claude session information.

User Story: As a developer, I want to see which worktrees have active Claude sessions so I can manage my parallel work contexts.

Implementation:

# In lib/dispatchers/cc-dispatcher.zsh

_cc_worktree_status() {
    local worktree_dir="${FLOW_WORKTREE_DIR:-$(_flow_find_project_root)/.worktrees}"

    echo "🌳 Worktree Status"
    echo "━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━"

    # Get all worktrees
    git worktree list --porcelain | while read line; do
        if [[ "$line" == worktree\ * ]]; then
            local wt_path="${line#worktree }"
            local branch=$(git -C "$wt_path" branch --show-current 2>/dev/null)

            # Check for Claude session
            local session_info=""
            if [[ -f "$wt_path/.claude/session.json" ]]; then
                local last_active=$(jq -r '.last_active // empty' "$wt_path/.claude/session.json" 2>/dev/null)
                local model=$(jq -r '.model // "unknown"' "$wt_path/.claude/session.json" 2>/dev/null)
                session_info="🤖 $model (${last_active:-unknown})"
            fi

            printf "  %-30s %s\n" "$branch" "$session_info"
        fi
    done
}

Tests to add: - test_cc_wt_status_shows_worktrees - test_cc_wt_status_shows_claude_sessions - test_cc_wt_status_handles_no_sessions

docs.title: cc wt clean (~45 min)
docs.text:
Purpose: Remove worktrees for merged branches.

User Story: As a developer, I want to clean up worktrees for branches that have been merged so I don't accumulate stale directories.

Implementation:

# In lib/dispatchers/cc-dispatcher.zsh

_cc_worktree_clean() {
    local dry_run=false
    [[ "$1" == "-n" || "$1" == "--dry-run" ]] && dry_run=true

    echo "🧹 Cleaning merged worktrees..."

    # Get merged branches
    local merged_branches=$(git branch --merged dev 2>/dev/null | grep -E "^\s*feature/" | tr -d ' ')

    git worktree list --porcelain | while read line; do
        if [[ "$line" == worktree\ * ]]; then
            local wt_path="${line#worktree }"
            local branch=$(git -C "$wt_path" branch --show-current 2>/dev/null)

            if echo "$merged_branches" | grep -q "^$branch$"; then
                if $dry_run; then
                    echo "  Would remove: $wt_path ($branch)"
                else
                    echo "  Removing: $wt_path ($branch)"
                    git worktree remove "$wt_path" 2>/dev/null
                fi
            fi
        fi
    done

    # Also run g feature prune
    if ! $dry_run; then
        g feature prune
    fi
}

Integration: Combines with g feature prune for complete cleanup.

docs.title: g feature prune --force (~30 min)
docs.text:
Purpose: Skip confirmation for non-interactive use.

User Story: As a developer using CI/automation, I want to prune branches without interactive prompts.

Implementation:

# In lib/dispatchers/g-dispatcher.zsh, modify _g_feature_prune()

_g_feature_prune() {
    local force=false
    local dry_run=false
    local clean_remote=false

    # Parse flags
    while [[ $# -gt 0 ]]; do
        case "$1" in
            --force|-f) force=true; shift ;;
            -n|--dry-run) dry_run=true; shift ;;
            --all|-a) clean_remote=true; shift ;;
            *) shift ;;
        esac
    done

    # ... existing logic ...

    # Skip confirmation if force is set
    if ! $force && ! $dry_run; then
        echo -n "Delete ${#to_delete[@]} branches? [y/N] "
        read -r confirm
        [[ "$confirm" != [yY]* ]] && return 0
    fi

    # ... delete logic ...
}

Tests: - test_g_feature_prune_force_skips_confirmation - test_g_feature_prune_force_with_dry_run

docs.title: g feature prune --older-than (~1 hour)
docs.text:
Purpose: Filter branches by age.

User Story: As a developer, I want to only prune branches older than a certain age to avoid accidentally removing recent work.

Implementation:

# Add to _g_feature_prune()

# Parse duration: 30d → 30 days, 1w → 7 days, 2m → 60 days
_parse_duration() {
    local duration="$1"
    case "$duration" in
        *d) echo "${duration%d}" ;;
        *w) echo "$((${duration%w} * 7))" ;;
        *m) echo "$((${duration%m} * 30))" ;;
        *) echo "0" ;;
    esac
}

_g_feature_prune() {
    local max_age_days=0

    # Parse --older-than flag
    while [[ $# -gt 0 ]]; do
        case "$1" in
            --older-than)
                max_age_days=$(_parse_duration "$2")
                shift 2
                ;;
            # ... other flags ...
        esac
    done

    # Filter by age
    local now=$(date +%s)
    local cutoff=$((now - max_age_days * 86400))

    for branch in $merged_branches; do
        local commit_time=$(git log -1 --format=%ct "$branch" 2>/dev/null)
        if [[ $max_age_days -eq 0 ]] || [[ $commit_time -lt $cutoff ]]; then
            to_delete+=("$branch")
        fi
    done
}

Usage: 

g feature prune --older-than 30d  # Only branches > 30 days old
g feature prune --older-than 1w   # Only branches > 1 week old
g feature prune --older-than 2m   # Only branches > 2 months old

docs.title: g feature status (~45 min)
docs.text:
Purpose: Show overview of all feature branches with their status.

User Story: As a developer, I want to see which feature branches are merged, unmerged, and how old they are.

Implementation:

# In lib/dispatchers/g-dispatcher.zsh

_g_feature_status() {
    local base_branch="${1:-dev}"

    echo "📊 Feature Branch Status"
    echo "━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━"

    echo ""
    echo "🧹 Stale branches (merged to $base_branch):"
    git branch --merged "$base_branch" 2>/dev/null | while read branch; do
        branch="${branch#* }"
        [[ "$branch" == feature/* || "$branch" == hotfix/* ]] || continue
        local age=$(git log -1 --format="%cr" "$branch" 2>/dev/null)
        printf "  %-40s %s\n" "$branch" "($age)"
    done

    echo ""
    echo "⚠️  Active branches (not merged to $base_branch):"
    git branch --no-merged "$base_branch" 2>/dev/null | while read branch; do
        branch="${branch#* }"
        [[ "$branch" == feature/* || "$branch" == hotfix/* ]] || continue
        local commits=$(git rev-list --count "$base_branch".."$branch" 2>/dev/null)
        local age=$(git log -1 --format="%cr" "$branch" 2>/dev/null)
        printf "  %-40s %d commits ahead (%s)\n" "$branch" "$commits" "$age"
    done

    echo ""
    echo "💡 Tip: Run 'g feature prune' to clean up merged branches"
}

Output example: 

📊 Feature Branch Status
━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━

🧹 Stale branches (merged to dev):
  feature/old-feature                      (3 weeks ago)
  feature/completed-task                   (5 days ago)

⚠️  Active branches (not merged to dev):
  feature/work-in-progress                 12 commits ahead (2 hours ago)
  feature/new-feature                      3 commits ahead (1 day ago)

💡 Tip: Run 'g feature prune' to clean up merged branches

docs.title: wt prune (~1 hour)
docs.text:
Purpose: Combined cleanup for worktrees and branches.

User Story: As a developer, I want one command to clean up both stale worktrees and merged branches.

Implementation:

# In lib/dispatchers/wt-dispatcher.zsh

_wt_prune() {
    local branches_only=false
    local worktrees_only=false
    local dry_run=false

    while [[ $# -gt 0 ]]; do
        case "$1" in
            --branches-only) branches_only=true; shift ;;
            --worktrees-only) worktrees_only=true; shift ;;
            -n|--dry-run) dry_run=true; shift ;;
            *) shift ;;
        esac
    done

    echo "🧹 Pruning worktrees and branches..."
    echo ""

    # Prune stale worktrees
    if ! $branches_only; then
        echo "Pruning stale worktrees..."
        if $dry_run; then
            git worktree prune --dry-run
        else
            git worktree prune
        fi
    fi

    # Prune merged branches
    if ! $worktrees_only; then
        echo ""
        echo "Pruning merged branches..."
        if $dry_run; then
            g feature prune -n
        else
            g feature prune --force
        fi
    fi

    echo ""
    echo "✅ Cleanup complete"
}

Usage: 

wt prune                  # Clean both worktrees and branches
wt prune --branches-only  # Only clean branches
wt prune --worktrees-only # Only clean worktrees
wt prune -n               # Dry run

docs.title: wt status (~30 min)
docs.text:
Purpose: Show worktree health and disk usage.

User Story: As a developer, I want to see disk usage and health of my worktrees.

Implementation:

# In lib/dispatchers/wt-dispatcher.zsh

_wt_status() {
    echo "🌳 Worktree Status"
    echo "━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━"

    local total_size=0

    git worktree list --porcelain | while read line; do
        if [[ "$line" == worktree\ * ]]; then
            local wt_path="${line#worktree }"
            local branch=$(git -C "$wt_path" branch --show-current 2>/dev/null || echo "detached")
            local size=$(du -sh "$wt_path" 2>/dev/null | cut -f1)
            local status=""

            # Check if branch is merged
            if git branch --merged dev 2>/dev/null | grep -q "$branch"; then
                status="🧹 merged"
            elif [[ ! -d "$wt_path/.git" && ! -f "$wt_path/.git" ]]; then
                status="⚠️  stale"
            else
                status="✅ active"
            fi

            printf "  %-30s %-10s %-6s %s\n" "$branch" "$status" "$size" "$wt_path"
        fi
    done

    echo ""
    echo "💡 Run 'wt prune' to clean up stale worktrees"
}

docs.title: Priority 4: Remote & Team Features (Future)
docs.text: These are longer-term features that require more design work.

docs.title: Remote State Sync
docs.text:
Concept: Optional cloud backup for session state, wins, and goals.

Considerations: - Privacy: User data should be encrypted - Conflict resolution: How to handle multi-device edits - Storage: Where to store (GitHub Gist? Private repo? Cloud service?)

docs.title: Multi-Device Support
docs.text:
Concept: Sync flow-cli state across multiple machines.

Considerations: - Real-time sync vs. manual sync - Merge conflicts for .STATUS files - Session handoff between devices

docs.title: Shared Templates
docs.text:
Concept: Team-wide project templates and configurations.

Considerations: - Template repository format - Versioning and updates - Private vs. public templates

docs.title: Key Learnings from v4.2.0
docs.text:
1. ZSH path array conflict: In ZSH, local path shadows the global path array (tied to PATH). Always use local result_path or similar naming.

  2. Test isolation: Create temporary git repos for tests to avoid polluting real repos.

  3. Mode chaining pattern: When implementing mode flags (yolo, plan, opus), parse them first, then pass remaining args to the action.

docs.title: Testing Strategy
docs.text:
• Unit tests for individual functions
  • E2E tests with mock claude() function
  • Interactive dogfooding tests for UX validation

docs.title: Documentation Updates
docs.text: When implementing new features: 1. Update lib/dispatchers/*-dispatcher.zsh 2. Update help function _<cmd>_help() 3. Add tests in tests/ 4. Update docs/reference/DISPATCHER-REFERENCE.md 5. Update docs/reference/COMMAND-QUICK-REFERENCE.md 6. Update CLAUDE.md roadmap section

docs.title: Automated Extraction Template
docs.text:
#!/usr/bin/env zsh
# extract-function.sh - Extract function ranges from adhd-helpers.zsh

SOURCE_FILE="$HOME/.config/zsh/functions/adhd-helpers.zsh"
TARGET_DIR="$HOME/.config/zsh/functions/helpers"

extract_function() {
    local func_name="$1"
    local start_line="$2"
    local end_line="$3"
    local target_file="$4"

    echo "Extracting $func_name (lines $start_line-$end_line) to $target_file"

    # Extract function
    sed -n "${start_line},${end_line}p" "$SOURCE_FILE" >> "$target_file"
    echo "" >> "$target_file"  # Add blank line after function
}

# Example usage:
# extract_function "just-start" 24 157 "$TARGET_DIR/energy-helpers.zsh"

docs.title: CC Dispatcher Reference
docs.text:
Claude Code workflows with smart project selection

Location: lib/dispatchers/cc-dispatcher.zsh

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
cc                # Launch Claude HERE (current dir, acceptEdits)
cc pick           # Pick project → Claude
cc flow           # Direct jump to flow-cli → Claude
cc yolo           # Launch HERE in YOLO mode (skip all permissions)
cc yolo pick      # Pick project → YOLO mode
cc resume         # Resume previous Claude conversation

docs.title: Usage
docs.text: cc [subcommand|project-name] [options]

docs.title: Key Insight
docs.text:
• cc always starts a NEW Claude session
  • Use cc resume to continue a previous Claude conversation
  • Project selection inherits pick's smart behaviors (direct jump, resume)

docs.title: Launch Modes
docs.text: Command Description cc Launch Claude HERE (current dir, acceptEdits) cc pick Pick project → Claude cc <project> Direct jump → Claude cc pick <project> Direct jump via pick → Claude cc yolo Launch HERE in YOLO mode (skip permissions) cc yolo pick Pick project → YOLO mode cc yolo <project> Direct jump → YOLO mode cc yolo pick <project> Direct jump via pick → YOLO cc plan Launch HERE in Plan mode cc plan pick Pick project → Plan mode cc plan <project> Direct jump → Plan mode cc plan pick <project> Direct jump via pick → Plan

docs.title: Permission Modes
docs.text: Mode Flag Use Case acceptEdits --permission-mode acceptEdits Default, confirms edits YOLO --dangerously-skip-permissions No confirmations plan --permission-mode plan Planning mode

docs.title: Session Management
docs.text:
Command Description cc resume Show Claude session picker, resume selected cc continue Resume most recent Claude conversation

Shortcuts: cc r = resume, cc c = continue

docs.title: Quick Actions
docs.text:
Command Description cc ask <question> Quick question (print mode, non-interactive) cc file <file> Analyze a file with Claude cc diff Review uncommitted git changes cc rpkg R package context helper (reads DESCRIPTION) cc print <prompt> Print mode (non-interactive output)

Shortcuts: cc a = ask, cc f = file, cc d = diff, cc pr = print

docs.title: Model Selection
docs.text:
Command Description cc opus Launch HERE with Opus model cc opus pick Pick project → Opus model cc opus <project> Direct jump → Opus cc opus pick <project> Direct jump via pick → Opus cc haiku Launch HERE with Haiku model cc haiku pick Pick project → Haiku model cc haiku <project> Direct jump → Haiku cc haiku pick <project> Direct jump via pick → Haiku

Shortcuts: cc o = opus, cc h = haiku

docs.title: Worktree Integration
docs.text:
Launch Claude in isolated git worktrees for parallel development.

Command Description cc wt List current worktrees cc wt <branch> Launch Claude in worktree for branch cc wt pick Pick worktree → Claude (fzf) cc wt yolo <branch> Worktree → YOLO mode cc wt plan <branch> Worktree → Plan mode cc wt opus <branch> Worktree → Opus model cc wt haiku <branch> Worktree → Haiku model

Shortcuts: cc w = wt, cc worktree = wt

docs.title: Aliases
docs.text: Alias Expands To Description ccw cc wt Quick worktree access ccwy cc wt yolo Worktree + YOLO mode ccwp cc wt pick Worktree picker

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
# Create/use worktree and launch Claude
cc wt feature/auth       # Creates worktree if needed, launches Claude

# Use fzf to pick existing worktree
cc wt pick               # Interactive selection

# Worktree with YOLO mode
cc wt yolo bugfix/issue-42

# Worktree with specific model
cc wt opus feature/refactor

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
1. If worktree exists for branch → cd to it → launch Claude
  2. If no worktree → create one using wt create → launch Claude
  3. Mode flags (yolo, plan, opus, haiku) apply to the Claude session

docs.title: Smart Project Selection
docs.text: The cc dispatcher inherits all of pick's smart behaviors:

docs.title: Direct Jump
docs.text:
cc flow           # → cd to flow-cli → NEW Claude session
cc med            # → cd to mediationverse → NEW Claude session

docs.title: Smart Resume (via pick)
docs.text:
When you run cc with no args:

  1. pick shows the resume prompt (if recent session exists)
  2. Press Enter to resume last project, Space to browse
  3. After selection, Claude launches in NEW session

docs.title: Explicit Claude Resume
docs.text:
cc resume         # Resume previous Claude conversation (with picker)
cc continue       # Resume most recent Claude conversation

docs.title: Daily Workflow
docs.text:
# Start fresh session in a project
cc flow           # Direct jump → Claude

# Continue where you left off (Claude conversation)
cc resume         # Pick previous conversation

# Quick question without full session
cc ask "how do I handle NA values in R?"

# Review changes before committing
cc diff

docs.title: Different Modes
docs.text:
# Careful mode (default)
cc                # acceptEdits - confirms changes

# YOLO mode for trusted tasks
cc yolo           # Skip all confirmations

# Planning mode
cc plan           # No code execution

docs.title: Model Selection
docs.text:
# Use Opus for complex tasks
cc opus flow      # flow-cli + Opus model

# Use Haiku for quick tasks
cc haiku          # Pick project + Haiku model

docs.title: Shortcuts Summary
docs.text:
Full Short Description yolo y YOLO mode plan p Plan mode resume r Resume session picker continue c Continue most recent ask a Quick question file f Analyze file diff d Review git diff opus o Opus model haiku h Haiku model print pr Print mode wt w Worktree mode

Note: cc now is deprecated. Just use cc (default is current dir).

docs.text:
• Uses pick for project selection (inherits direct jump, smart resume)
  • Uses Claude CLI (claude) for all operations
  • Works with wt dispatcher for worktree management

docs.title: Research: Status/State Management in Developer Tools
docs.text: Date: 2025-12-14 Purpose: Find better alternatives to confusing status command Current Problem: status does 3 things (show/update/create) - unclear what action it performs

docs.title: The Core Problem
docs.text:
Your status command suffers from action ambiguity:

  • No arguments = interactive update (NOT show!)
  • --show flag = show current status
  • --create flag = create new .STATUS file
  • 5+ arguments = quick update

The confusion: Users expect status (noun) to show state, not change it.

docs.title: Key Finding
docs.text: Best practice: Separate commands by action (verbs) > Combined commands with modes

docs.title: 1. Git - The Gold Standard
docs.text:
Command Structure:

git status              # NOUN - Shows current state (read-only)
git add                 # VERB - Modifies state
git commit              # VERB - Modifies state
git show                # VERB - Shows something
git config --get        # VERB + flag for action
git config --set        # VERB + flag for action

Pattern: VERB-first commands with nouns as objects

  • status is READ-ONLY (the exception - it's a noun that only reads)
  • All state changes are VERBS (add, commit, push, pull, merge)
  • When verbs have multiple modes, flags clarify (--get vs --set)

Key Insight: The word "status" has been claimed by Git to mean "show current state, read-only"

ADHD Score: 9/10

  • Clear verbs = clear actions
  • git status is universally understood as "show me what's happening"
  • No ambiguity about what will change

docs.title: 2. GitHub CLI (gh) - Resource-Based
docs.text:
Command Structure:

gh pr view              # RESOURCE + ACTION
gh pr create            # RESOURCE + ACTION
gh pr edit              # RESOURCE + ACTION
gh issue list           # RESOURCE + ACTION
gh repo view            # RESOURCE + ACTION

Pattern: RESOURCE + VERB (noun + verb)

  • First word = what you're working with (pr, issue, repo)
  • Second word = what you're doing to it (view, create, edit, list)

ADHD Score: 8/10

  • Two-word structure is longer but very clear
  • Auto-complete friendly
  • Scales well (many resources, many actions)

docs.title: 3. npm/yarn - Mixed Patterns
docs.text:
Command Structure:

npm install             # VERB
npm run                 # VERB
npm list                # VERB
npm view                # VERB
npm config get          # NOUN + VERB
npm config set          # NOUN + VERB

Pattern: Mix of VERB-first and RESOURCE + VERB

  • Simple commands are verbs (install, run, list)
  • Complex subsystems use resource+verb (config get/set)

ADHD Score: 7/10

  • Mostly consistent
  • config get/set is clear but longer
  • Some verbs are non-obvious (view vs show vs list)

docs.title: 4. tmux - Verbose but Clear
docs.text:
Command Structure:

tmux show-options       # VERB-NOUN (show what?)
tmux set-option         # VERB-NOUN (set what?)
tmux display-message    # VERB-NOUN
tmux list-sessions      # VERB-NOUN

Pattern: VERB-NOUN compounds (hyphenated)

  • Very explicit
  • Self-documenting
  • Long but unambiguous

ADHD Score: 6/10

  • Very clear what each command does
  • Too long for frequent use
  • Excellent for discoverability

docs.title: 5. cargo (Rust) - Verb-First
docs.text:
Command Structure:

cargo build             # VERB
cargo test              # VERB
cargo run               # VERB
cargo update            # VERB
cargo check             # VERB

Pattern: Pure VERB commands

  • All actions are verbs
  • Short and memorable
  • Context (Rust project) provides the noun

ADHD Score: 9/10

  • Ultra-clear action words
  • Short commands
  • No ambiguity

docs.title: 6. kubectl - Resource-Based with Complexity
docs.text:
Command Structure:

kubectl get pods        # VERB + RESOURCE
kubectl describe pod    # VERB + RESOURCE
kubectl edit pod        # VERB + RESOURCE
kubectl apply           # VERB (resource in file)
kubectl delete pod      # VERB + RESOURCE

Pattern: VERB + RESOURCE (opposite of gh)

  • Verb first (what to do)
  • Resource second (what to do it to)

ADHD Score: 8/10

  • Clear action verbs
  • Flexible resource types
  • Can be verbose

docs.title: 7. Task Management Tools
docs.text:
taskwarrior:

task add                # VERB
task list               # VERB
task done               # VERB
task modify             # VERB

todo.txt:

todo.sh add             # VERB
todo.sh list            # VERB
todo.sh do              # VERB

Pattern: VERB commands for actions

ADHD Score: 9/10 (taskwarrior), 8/10 (todo.txt)

  • Simple verbs
  • Memorable
  • Clear intent

docs.title: Pattern Summary Table
docs.text: Tool Pattern Show Command Update Command ADHD Score Git VERB-first git status git add/commit 9/10 GitHub CLI RESOURCE+VERB gh pr view gh pr edit 8/10 npm Mixed npm list npm install 7/10 tmux VERB-NOUN tmux show-options tmux set-option 6/10 cargo Pure VERB (build shows) cargo update 9/10 kubectl VERB+RESOURCE kubectl get kubectl edit 8/10 taskwarrior VERB task list task modify 9/10

docs.title: 1. Action Clarity
docs.text:
Good:

  • show - I will see something
  • update - I will change something
  • create - I will make something new

Bad:

  • status - Will it show or change? Unclear!
  • manage - Too vague
  • handle - What does this do?

docs.title: 2. Verb > Noun for Actions
docs.text:
Good:

  • update-status (verb first)
  • show-status (verb first)

Bad:

  • status --update (noun first, action hidden in flag)
  • status (noun, action unclear)

docs.title: 3. Consistency Wins
docs.text:
• If you use show-X, use update-X (not change-X)
  • If you use get-X, use set-X (not put-X)
  • Parallel structure aids memory

docs.title: 4. Short Commands for Frequent Use
docs.text:
• Daily use: 1-4 characters ideal (js, dash, work)
  • Weekly use: 4-8 characters acceptable
  • Rare use: Longer is OK if self-documenting

docs.title: 5. Avoid Multi-Mode Commands
docs.text:
Bad pattern:

status            # Interactive update
status --show     # Show
status --create   # Create

Better pattern:

pshow             # Project show (or: dash)
pupdate           # Project update
pcreate           # Project create

docs.title: Current Problem Analysis
docs.text:
Your status command:

status mediationverse              # → Interactive UPDATE (unexpected!)
status mediationverse --show       # → Show (expected, but needs flag)
status mediationverse --create     # → Create (unexpected from "status")
status medfit active P1 "Task" 60  # → Quick UPDATE (reasonable)

Why it's confusing:

  1. Default behavior is UPDATE, not SHOW (violates Git's status convention)
  2. Name is a NOUN, but primary action is a VERB (update)
  3. Multi-mode with hidden actions
  4. Requires flags to do the "obvious" thing (show)

docs.title: Solution Option A: Pure VERB Commands
docs.text:
Separate everything:

pshow <project>                    # Show status (or use existing 'dash')
pupdate <project>                  # Interactive update
pset <project> <status> <pri>...   # Quick update
pinit <project>                    # Create new .STATUS

Pros:

  • Crystal clear action words
  • No ambiguity
  • Follows Git/cargo pattern
  • Easy to remember (all start with 'p')

Cons:

  • More commands to remember
  • pshow duplicates dash functionality

ADHD Score: 9/10

docs.title: Solution Option B: Keep Short, Split Actions
docs.text:
Use your existing pattern of ultra-short commands:

dash [project]                     # KEEP - Show status (already exists)
pup <project>                      # Project update (interactive)
pup <project> <status> <pri>...    # Project update (quick)
pinit <project>                    # Project init (create .STATUS)

Pros:

  • dash already handles "show" perfectly
  • pup = "project update" (clear verb)
  • Only 2 new commands (pup, pinit)
  • Follows your 1-char to 4-char philosophy

Cons:

  • "pup" might be too cute
  • Could conflict with Python's pip

ADHD Score: 8/10

docs.title: Solution Option C: Resource-Based (gh style)
docs.text:
Use 'project' as the resource:

proj show <name>                   # Show status
proj update <name>                 # Interactive update
proj set <name> <status> <pri>...  # Quick update
proj init <name>                   # Create .STATUS

Pros:

  • Follows GitHub CLI pattern (familiar)
  • Self-documenting
  • Expandable (could add proj list, proj search, etc.)
  • Clear namespace

Cons:

  • Two-word commands (longer)
  • Duplicates dash for show

ADHD Score: 7/10 (clear but verbose)

docs.title: Solution Option D: Hybrid (Recommended)
docs.text:
Keep best of current, minimize changes:

dash [project]                     # KEEP - Show all or one project
up <project>                       # Update status (interactive)
up <project> <status> <pri>...     # Update status (quick)
pinit <project>                    # Create .STATUS (rare operation)

Changes from current:

  • Rename status → up (ultra-short verb)
  • Remove status --show (use dash instead)
  • Keep status --create as pinit (project init)

Pros:

  • Minimal disruption (status → up)
  • up is clear verb (update)
  • Ultra-short for daily use (2 chars!)
  • Leverages existing dash command
  • Only one command to change

Cons:

  • up might conflict with uptime or other tools
  • Not as self-documenting as longer names

ADHD Score: 9/10 ⭐ RECOMMENDED

docs.title: Solution Option E: Context-Aware Single Command
docs.text:
Make behavior obvious from arguments:

set <project>                      # Interactive update (no other args)
set <project> <status> <pri>...    # Quick update (has args)
init <project>                     # Create .STATUS (different command)
# For show: use existing 'dash'

Pros:

  • set is universally understood (Git uses it)
  • Clear verb for changing state
  • Context determines mode (interactive vs quick)
  • Only 2 commands total

Cons:

  • Can't show with same command (but dash handles this)

ADHD Score: 8/10

docs.title: Comparison Matrix
docs.text: Solution Show Update Create Total Commands ADHD Score Current status --show status status --create 1 (multi-mode) 5/10 Option A pshow pupdate pinit 3 9/10 Option B dash pup pinit 2 new 8/10 Option C proj show proj update proj init 1 (multi-mode) 7/10 Option D ⭐ dash up pinit 2 new 9/10 Option E dash set init 2 new 8/10

docs.title: Primary Recommendation: Ultra-Short Verbs
docs.text:
# SHOW - Use existing command
dash                               # Show all projects
dash mediationverse                # Show one project

# UPDATE - New ultra-short verb
up <project>                       # Interactive update
up medfit active P1 "Docs" 60      # Quick update

# CREATE - Rare operation, can be longer
pinit <project>                    # Project init (create .STATUS)

Why this wins:

  1. Leverages existing dash (no duplication)
  2. up is 2 chars (ultra-fast for daily use)
  3. up clearly means "update" (verb)
  4. pinit is rare, longer name is fine
  5. Minimal migration (one command rename)

docs.title: Alternative: Slightly More Explicit
docs.text:
If up feels too short, consider:

dash [project]                     # Show (existing)
pset <project> ...                 # Project set (like git config set)
pinit <project>                    # Project init

docs.title: Alternative: Match Your Workflow
docs.text:
Look at your other workflow commands:

work <name>                        # Start work (verb)
finish [msg]                       # End work (verb)
js                                 # Just start (verb)
dash                              # Dashboard (noun, but read-only)

Pattern: Your successful commands are mostly VERBS!

Match this pattern:

dash [project]                     # Keep (exception: noun, read-only)
track <project>                    # Track project status (update)
start <project>                    # Start new project (create)

docs.title: Step 1: Add Aliases (Test Period)
docs.text:
alias up='status'                  # Test new name
alias pinit='status --create'      # Test create

docs.title: Step 2: Use Both for 1 Week
docs.text:
• Keep status working
  • Try up in daily workflow
  • Gather feedback from muscle memory

docs.title: Step 3: Deprecate Old Name
docs.text:
status() {
    echo "⚠️  'status' is deprecated. Use 'up' or 'dash' instead."
    echo "  dash $@     # Show status"
    echo "  up $@       # Update status"
}

docs.title: Step 4: Remove (After 2 Weeks)
docs.text:
• Delete status function
  • Keep up and pinit
  • Update all documentation

docs.title: From Your Own System (What Works)
docs.text:
Already excellent:

  • js - Just start (clear action, ultra-short)
  • dash - Dashboard (noun OK because read-only)
  • work - Start working (clear verb)
  • finish - End session (clear verb)

The pattern: Short verbs for frequent actions!

docs.title: From Git (Why It Works)
docs.text:
git add                # Verb: add files
git commit             # Verb: commit changes
git push               # Verb: push to remote
git status             # Exception: noun, but universally read-only

The lesson: If you use status, make it read-only like Git!

docs.title: The Problem
docs.text:
status violates user expectations:

  • Looks like a noun (read-only)
  • Acts like a verb (modifies state)
  • Default action is UPDATE (not show)

docs.title: The Solution
docs.text:
Recommended: Option D

dash [project]         # Show status (existing, keep)
up <project> [args]    # Update status (new, ultra-short verb)
pinit <project>        # Project init (new, rare use)

docs.title: Why This Works
docs.text:
1. Action clarity: up = update (verb)
  2. ADHD-friendly: 2 characters for daily use
  3. Consistent: Matches your js, work, finish pattern
  4. Leverages existing: Uses dash for show
  5. Minimal migration: One command rename

docs.title: Implementation
docs.text:
1. Rename status() → up()
  2. Remove --show flag logic (use dash instead)
  3. Move --create logic → pinit()
  4. Update help text and docs
  5. Add deprecation warning for status

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• Git command conventions: Verb-first, except status (read-only noun)
  • GitHub CLI: Resource + Verb pattern (gh pr view)
  • cargo/npm: Pure verb commands for actions
  • Your successful patterns: js, work, finish (all verbs!)

Next Steps:

  1. Decide on preferred option (recommend D)
  2. Test with aliases for 1 week
  3. Migrate incrementally
  4. Update all documentation

docs.title: Muscle Memory Development (Week 1)
docs.text:
• Focus on 5 commands: flow status, work, finish, pick, rload
  • Use aliases over full commands: rtest vs Rscript -e "devtools::test()"
  • Practice daily: Repetition builds muscle memory

docs.title: Advanced Usage (Week 2+)
docs.text:
• Combine commands: rload && rdoc && rtest or use rcycle
  • Use filters: pick r instead of scrolling through all projects
  • Monitor metrics: flow status -v to track productivity trends

docs.title: Performance Optimization
docs.text:
• Use fast mode when appropriate: pick --fast skips git checks
  • Leverage caching: Project scanning is cached for 1 hour
  • Prefer ZSH functions: <10ms vs ~100ms for Node.js CLI

docs.title: Dispatcher Reference - flow-cli
docs.text: Last Updated: December 30, 2025 Version: flow-cli v4.4.0

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Dispatchers are smart command routers that provide context-aware workflows for specific tools. Each dispatcher provides a unified interface with smart defaults and common subcommands.

Location: ~/projects/dev-tools/flow-cli/lib/dispatchers/

docs.title: 1. g - Git Workflows
docs.text:
File: g-dispatcher.zsh Purpose: Smart Git command shortcuts with feature branch workflow Updated: December 29, 2025 (v4.1.0)

Common Commands:

g status          # Git status
g commit "msg"    # Git commit with message
g push            # Git push (with workflow guard)
g pull            # Git pull
g log             # Git log
g help            # Show help

Feature Branch Workflow (v4.1.0+):

# Feature development
g feature start <name>   # Create feature/<name> from dev
g feature sync           # Rebase feature onto dev
g feature list           # List feature/hotfix branches
g feature finish         # Push + create PR to dev

# Promotion flow
g promote                # Create PR: feature → dev
g release                # Create PR: dev → main

# Status & cleanup (v4.2.0+)
g feature status             # Show merged vs active branches
g feature prune              # Delete merged feature branches
g feature prune --all        # Also delete remote branches
g feature prune -n           # Dry run (preview only)
g feature prune --force      # Skip confirmation (v4.3.0)
g feature prune --older-than 30d  # Only branches older than 30 days (v4.3.0)

Workflow Guard:

  • Blocks direct push to main and dev branches
  • Shows helpful message with correct workflow
  • Override with GIT_WORKFLOW_SKIP=1 g push

Workflow Diagram:

feature/* ──► dev ──► main
     └── g promote    └── g release

Branch Cleanup (v4.2.0):

The g feature prune command safely cleans up merged branches: - Only deletes branches merged to dev (or main) - Never deletes: main, master, dev, develop - Never deletes current branch - Only targets: feature/*, bugfix/*, hotfix/*

Features:

  • Smart defaults for common operations
  • ADHD-friendly quick commands
  • Feature branch workflow enforcement
  • Workflow guards for protected branches
  • Context-aware suggestions
  • Safe branch cleanup with prune

See also: G-DISPATCHER-REFERENCE.md
