docs.title: 4. qu - Quarto Publishing
docs.text:
File: qu-dispatcher.zsh Purpose: Quarto document and presentation workflows Restored: December 25, 2025

Common Commands:

# Smart defaults
qu                # Render → preview → open browser

# Core commands
qu preview        # Live preview with browser
qu render         # Render document/project
qu check          # Check Quarto installation
qu clean          # Remove output files
qu publish        # Publish to web

# Format-specific
qu pdf            # Render to PDF
qu html           # Render to HTML
qu docx           # Render to Word

# Project creation
qu new <name>     # Create new project
qu article <name> # Create article project
qu present <name> # Create presentation project

# Workflow
qu commit         # Render and commit changes

Smart Default Workflow:

  1. Renders current Quarto document
  2. Starts preview server (--no-browser)
  3. Auto-opens browser at http://localhost:4200
  4. Skips preview if render fails

Features:

  • One-command render and preview
  • Format-specific rendering (PDF, HTML, DOCX)
  • Project scaffolding
  • Integrated commit workflow

See also: QU-DISPATCHER-REFERENCE.md

docs.title: 5. r - R Package Development
docs.text:
File: r-dispatcher.zsh Purpose: R package development workflows Restored: December 25, 2025

Common Commands:

# Console
r                 # Launch R console (radian/R)

# Core workflow
r load            # devtools::load_all()
r test            # devtools::test()
r doc             # devtools::document()
r check           # devtools::check()
r build           # devtools::build()
r install         # devtools::install()

# Combined workflows
r cycle           # doc → test → check (full cycle)
r quick           # load → test (quick iteration)

# Quality checks
r cov             # covr::package_coverage()
r spell           # spelling::spell_check_package()

# Documentation
r pkgdown         # pkgdown::build_site()
r preview         # pkgdown::preview_site()

# CRAN checks
r cran            # check --as-cran
r fast            # Fast check (skip examples/tests/vignettes)
r win             # check_win_devel()

# Version bumps
r patch           # Bump patch version (0.0.X)
r minor           # Bump minor version (0.X.0)
r major           # Bump major version (X.0.0)

# Cleanup
r clean           # Remove .Rhistory, .RData
r deep            # Deep clean (man/, NAMESPACE, docs/)
r tex             # Remove LaTeX build files

# Workflow
r commit          # Document, test, and commit
r info            # Package info summary
r tree            # Package structure tree

Features:

  • Full R package development cycle
  • Combined workflows for efficiency
  • CRAN-ready checks
  • Automated version bumping
  • Multiple cleanup levels
  • Integrated documentation

See also: R-DISPATCHER-REFERENCE.md

docs.title: 6. cc - Claude Code Workflows
docs.text:
File: cc-dispatcher.zsh Purpose: Smart Claude Code project workflows Added: December 26, 2025 Updated: December 29, 2025 (v4.2.0 - worktree integration)

Common Commands:

# Launch modes (default = current directory)
cc                # Launch Claude HERE (acceptEdits mode)
cc pick           # Pick project → Claude (acceptEdits)
cc flow           # Direct jump → Claude
cc yolo           # Launch HERE in YOLO mode (skip permissions)
cc yolo pick      # Pick project → YOLO mode
cc yolo flow      # Direct jump → YOLO mode
cc plan           # Launch HERE in Plan mode
cc plan pick      # Pick project → Plan mode

# Session management
cc resume         # Resume with Claude session picker
cc continue       # Resume most recent conversation

# Quick actions
cc ask "query"    # Quick question (print mode)
cc file <file>    # Analyze a file
cc diff           # Review git changes
cc rpkg           # R package context helper

# Model selection (default = current directory)
cc opus           # Launch HERE with Opus model
cc opus pick      # Pick project → Opus model
cc haiku          # Launch HERE with Haiku model
cc haiku pick     # Pick project → Haiku model

# Worktree integration (v4.2.0)
cc wt                   # List current worktrees
cc wt <branch>          # Launch Claude in worktree
cc wt pick              # Pick worktree → Claude (fzf)
cc wt yolo <branch>     # Worktree + YOLO mode
cc wt plan <branch>     # Worktree + Plan mode
cc wt opus <branch>     # Worktree + Opus model

Features:

  • Default launches Claude in current directory (no picker)
  • Use pick subcommand to select project first
  • Direct jump with project name (e.g., cc flow)
  • Multiple permission modes (acceptEdits, YOLO, plan)
  • Session resume with Claude's built-in picker
  • Quick actions for common tasks
  • Model selection shortcuts
  • Worktree integration for parallel development (v4.2.0)

Shortcuts: y=yolo, p=plan, r=resume, c=continue, a=ask, f=file, d=diff, o=opus, h=haiku, w=wt

Aliases: ccy, ccp, ccr, ccc, cca, ccf, ccd, cco, cch, ccw, ccwy, ccwp

See also: CC-DISPATCHER-REFERENCE.md

docs.title: 7. wt - Git Worktree Management
docs.text:
File: wt-dispatcher.zsh Purpose: Git worktree management for parallel development Added: December 29, 2025 (v4.1.0)

Common Commands:

wt                    # Navigate to worktrees folder
wt list               # List all worktrees
wt create <branch>    # Create worktree for branch
wt move               # Move current branch to worktree
wt remove <path>      # Remove a worktree
wt clean              # Prune stale worktrees
wt help               # Show help

# Status & cleanup (v4.3.0)
wt status             # Show worktree health and disk usage
wt prune              # Comprehensive cleanup (worktrees + merged branches)
wt prune --branches   # Also delete merged feature branches
wt prune --force      # Skip confirmation
wt prune --dry-run    # Preview only

Aliases:

  • wt ls → wt list
  • wt add / wt c → wt create
  • wt mv → wt move
  • wt rm → wt remove
  • wt st → wt status

Configuration:

# Set custom worktree directory (default: ~/.git-worktrees)
export FLOW_WORKTREE_DIR="$HOME/worktrees"

Passthrough:

Unknown commands pass through to git worktree:

wt lock <path>     # → git worktree lock <path>
wt unlock <path>   # → git worktree unlock <path>

Features:

  • Organized worktree storage by project
  • Protected branch validation (can't move main/dev)
  • Smart branch detection (creates new or uses existing)
  • Automatic directory structure creation

See also: WT-DISPATCHER-REFERENCE.md

docs.title: 8. tm - Terminal Manager
docs.text:
File: tm-dispatcher.zsh Purpose: Terminal management via aiterm integration Added: December 30, 2025 (v4.4.0)

Common Commands:

# Shell-native (instant, no Python)
tm title <text>       # Set tab/window title (OSC 2)
tm profile <name>     # Switch iTerm2 profile
tm var <key> <val>    # Set iTerm2 status bar variable
tm which              # Show detected terminal

# Aiterm delegation
tm ghost              # Ghostty status
tm ghost theme        # List/set Ghostty themes
tm ghost font         # Get/set Ghostty font
tm switch             # Apply terminal context
tm detect             # Detect project context
tm doctor             # Check terminal health
tm compare            # Compare terminal features
tm features           # Show terminal features
tm help               # Show help

Shortcuts:

  • t = title, p = profile, v = var, w = which
  • g = ghost, s = switch, d = detect

Aliases:

  • tmt → tm title
  • tmp → tm profile
  • tmv → tm var
  • tmw → tm which
  • tmg → tm ghost
  • tms → tm switch
  • tmd → tm detect

Terminal Detection:

Automatically detects: iTerm2, Ghostty, WezTerm, Kitty, Alacritty, VS Code, Terminal.app

Requirements:

  • aiterm (ait) for rich features (optional for shell-native commands)
  • Install: brew install data-wise/tap/aiterm or pip install aiterm-dev

Features:

  • Shell-native commands for instant response (no Python overhead)
  • Delegates complex operations to aiterm Python CLI
  • Auto-detects terminal emulator
  • chpwd hook integration for auto-context switching

See also: TM-DISPATCHER-REFERENCE.md

docs.title: Integration with Flow
docs.text:
All dispatchers integrate with the main flow command namespace:

# Can also use:

flow build                # Context-aware build
flow preview              # Context-aware preview
flow doctor               # Health check

docs.title: Creating New Dispatchers
docs.text:
Template Structure:

# my-dispatcher.zsh - Tool Name Dispatcher

my_dispatcher() {
    # Help check
    if [[ "$1" == "help" || "$1" == "-h" || "$1" == "--help" ]]; then
        _my_dispatcher_help
        return 0
    fi

    local cmd="${1:-default}"
    shift 2>/dev/null || true

    case "$cmd" in
        command1)
            # Implementation
            ;;
        command2)
            # Implementation
            ;;
        help)
            _my_dispatcher_help
            ;;
        *)
            echo "Unknown command: $cmd"
            return 1
            ;;
    esac
}

_my_dispatcher_help() {
    cat << 'EOF'
# Help text here
EOF
}

Location: Place in lib/dispatchers/my-dispatcher.zsh Auto-loading: Automatically loaded by flow.plugin.zsh

# Manually source
source ~/projects/dev-tools/flow-cli/lib/dispatchers/<name>.zsh

docs.title: Existing System Summary - Flow CLI

docs.title: 🧹 How to Use This as a Cleanup Tool
docs.text:
This document doubles as an interactive cleanup checklist:

  1. Mark items for deletion: Change - [ ] to - [x] for any alias/function/category you want to remove
  2. Ask Claude to process: Say "Process checked items for deletion"
  3. Review the plan: Claude will show all files and lines to be modified
  4. Approve: Claude executes the deletions safely (with backups)
  5. Reload shell: source ~/.zshrc to apply changes

Safety: Backups created before deletion. Dependency checking. User approval required.

  • 8 project categories (r, dev, q, teach, rs, app, mgmt)
  • 5 keybinds in pick command (Enter, Ctrl-W, Ctrl-O, Ctrl-S, Ctrl-L)

--bind="ctrl-l:execute-silent(echo log > $action_file)+accept"
Keybind Action Description Implementation Enter cd Navigate to directory Default fzf behavior Ctrl-W work Start work session (calls work command) Lines 2026-2031 Ctrl-O code Open in VS Code (code .) Lines 2032-2037 Ctrl-S status View .STATUS file (bat/cat) Lines 2038-2053 Ctrl-L log View git log (tig/git) Lines 2054-2064

docs.title: 🏗️ Project Detection System
docs.text: From adhd-helpers.zsh:1667-1699, _proj_detect_type() function:

docs.title: Detection Order
docs.text:
1. Path-based (highest priority):
  2. */projects/teaching/* → "teaching"

  3. */projects/research/* → "research" (with sub-types)

  4. File-based:

  5. DESCRIPTION file → "r" (R package)
  6. package.json → "node"
  7. _quarto.yml or index.qmd → "quarto"
  8. setup.py or pyproject.toml → "python"
  9. .Rproj → "r"

  10. Makefile → "make"

  11. Fallback: "generic"

docs.title: Mnemonic Naming
docs.text:
• Single letter - Ultra-high frequency (t, c, q)
  • 2-letter pairs - Common sequences (lt, dt)
  • Prefix-based - Logical grouping:
  • r* - R package commands (rload, rtest, rdoc)
  • cc* - Claude Code commands (ccc, ccl, cch)
  • g* - Git commands (gs, ga, gc)
  • pick* - Project picker filters (pickr, pickdev, pickq)

docs.title: ADHD-Optimized Principles
docs.text:
From design docs:

  1. Reduce cognitive load - One command does one thing clearly
  2. Minimal keystrokes - Single letters for frequent actions
  3. Visual feedback - Icons, colors, clear output
  4. Context preservation - .STATUS files, session tracking
  5. Undo-friendly - Easy to reverse (gundo, qcommit safety)

docs.title: Management Category
docs.text:
• NOT implemented: mgmt project type
  • NOT implemented: Management section in pick
  • NOT implemented: PROJ_MANAGEMENT array
  • Proposed: Show meta/coordination projects first in pick

  • NOT implemented: Recent section in pick
  • NOT implemented: Time-based sorting
  • Proposed: Add "Recently Used" section

docs.title: AI Assistant Keybinds
docs.text:
• NOT implemented: Ctrl-C (claude) or Ctrl-G (gemini)
  • REJECTED: User feedback - don't add without approval
  • Existing: Ctrl-W (work), Ctrl-O (code) already handle editor launching

docs.title: Additional Aliases
docs.text:
• NOT implemented: pm (pick mgmt)
  • NOT implemented: pickcc (pick with claude)
  • REJECTED: Don't add aliases without approval

docs.title: What Works Well (Keep These Patterns)
docs.text:
1. Filter system - pick <category> is established and works
  2. Keybind pattern - Ctrl-W/O/S/L are known and used
  3. Icon system - Emojis for visual hierarchy (📦 🔧 🎓 🔬)
  4. Mnemonic aliases - Short + memorable = high adoption
  5. Session tracking - PROJ_SESSION_FILE infrastructure exists

docs.title: What to Avoid
docs.text:
1. New keybinds - Existing Ctrl-W/O/S/L sufficient
  2. New aliases - Need user approval first
  3. Breaking changes - Must be backward compatible
  4. Over-engineering - KISS principle (keep it simple)

docs.title: Opportunities
docs.text:
1. Reuse filter system - pick mgmt follows existing pattern
  2. Leverage session file - Can track recent projects
  3. Extend category array - PROJ_MANAGEMENT parallel to PROJ_CATEGORIES
  4. Use existing icons - ⚙️ for management type
  5. Follow help patterns - ah workflow for documentation

docs.title: PROPOSAL-PICK-ENHANCEMENTS.md (Management Section)
docs.text:
Fits existing patterns:

  • ✅ Uses existing filter system (pick mgmt)
  • ✅ Follows category icon pattern (⚙️ )
  • ✅ Parallels PROJ_CATEGORIES structure
  • ✅ No new keybinds needed (uses existing Ctrl-W/O/S/L)
  • ✅ Backward compatible (adds section, doesn't change existing)

Requires:

  • New PROJ_MANAGEMENT array (5 projects)
  • Modify _proj_list_all() to output management first
  • Add "mgmt" to category normalization

Estimated complexity: Medium (2-3 hours)

docs.title: PROPOSAL-PICK-RECENT-SECTION.md (Recently Used)
docs.text:
Fits existing patterns:

  • ✅ Uses existing session tracking (PROJ_SESSION_FILE)
  • ✅ Follows section display pattern (like management)
  • ✅ Can reuse icon system (🕐 for time)
  • ✅ Natural evolution of worklog infrastructure

Requires:

  • New PROJ_ACCESS_LOG file (~/.project-access-log)
  • New _proj_recent() function
  • Modify _proj_list_all() to output recent first
  • Add access tracking on every pick action

Estimated complexity: Medium-High (3-4 hours for basic, +2-3 for smart ranking)

Recommendation order:

  1. Implement management section FIRST (simpler, high value)
  2. Collect usage data (which management projects used most?)
  3. Implement recent section SECOND (builds on management)

docs.title: G Dispatcher Reference
docs.text:
Smart Git command shortcuts with feature branch workflow

Location: lib/dispatchers/g-dispatcher.zsh

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
g                     # Quick status (short)
g add .               # Stage all changes
g commit "message"    # Commit with message
g push                # Push to remote

docs.title: Usage
docs.text: g [command] [args]

docs.title: Key Insight
docs.text:
• g provides shortcuts for the most common git operations
  • Feature workflow enforces feature/* → dev → main pattern
  • Workflow guard blocks direct push to protected branches
  • Unknown commands pass through to git

docs.title: Status & Info Commands
docs.text: Command Shortcut Description g - Quick status (git status -sb) g status g s Full status g diff g d Show unstaged diff g ds / g staged - Show staged diff g log g l Pretty log (20 commits) g loga g la Log all branches g blame <file> g bl Blame file

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
g                  # Quick status
g d                # See unstaged changes
g ds               # See staged changes
g l                # Recent commits
g la               # All branches

docs.title: Staging & Commits
docs.text: Command Shortcut Description g add <files> g a Add files g aa - Add all (git add --all) g commit g c Commit (opens editor) g commit "msg" - Commit with message g amend - Amend last commit (no edit) g amendm "msg" - Amend with new message

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
g aa                    # Add all changes
g commit "fix: bug"     # Commit with message
g amend                 # Amend without editing message
g amendm "new message"  # Amend with new message

docs.title: Branch Commands
docs.text: Command Shortcut Description g branch g b List branches g ba - All branches (local + remote) g checkout <branch> g co Checkout branch g cob <branch> - Create and checkout branch g switch <branch> g sw Switch branch g swc <branch> - Switch, create if new g main g m Checkout main (or master)

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
g b                     # List local branches
g ba                    # List all branches
g co feature/auth       # Checkout existing branch
g cob feature/new       # Create and checkout new branch
g main                  # Go back to main

docs.title: Remote Operations
docs.text: Command Shortcut Description g push g p Push (with workflow guard) g pushu g pu Push with upstream (-u origin HEAD) g pull g pl Pull g fetch g f Fetch g fa - Fetch all

docs.title: Workflow Guard
docs.text:
Direct push to main or dev is blocked by default:

g push   # On main → BLOCKED
# ⛔ Direct push to 'main' blocked
# Workflow: feature/* → dev → main
# Use instead:
#   g feature start <name>
#   g promote

# Override (use sparingly):
GIT_WORKFLOW_SKIP=1 git push

docs.title: Stash Commands
docs.text: Command Shortcut Description g stash g st Stash changes g stash <args> - Stash with arguments g pop g stp Pop stash g stl - List stashes

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
g st                    # Quick stash
g stash push -m "WIP"   # Stash with message
g stl                   # List stashes
g pop                   # Apply and remove top stash

docs.title: Reset & Undo Commands
docs.text: Command Description g undo Undo last commit (keeps changes, soft reset) g unstage <file> Unstage file g discard <file> Discard changes to file g clean Remove untracked files g reset <args> Git reset with args

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
g undo                  # Undo last commit (keep changes)
g unstage src/main.ts   # Unstage specific file
g discard src/main.ts   # Discard changes to file
g clean                 # Remove untracked files

docs.title: Rebase & Merge Commands
docs.text: Command Shortcut Description g rebase g rb Rebase g rbc - Rebase continue g rba - Rebase abort g merge g mg Merge

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
g rb dev                # Rebase onto dev
g rbc                   # Continue after resolving conflicts
g rba                   # Abort rebase
g mg feature/auth       # Merge feature/auth

docs.title: Feature Workflow
docs.text:
The feature workflow enforces a clean branching pattern:

feature/* ──► dev ──► main
hotfix/*  ────┴───────┘
bugfix/*  ────┘

docs.title: Feature Commands
docs.text: Command Description g feature start <name> Create feature/<name> from dev g feature sync Rebase current feature onto dev g feature list List all feature/hotfix/bugfix branches g feature finish Push and create PR to dev g feature status Show merged vs active branches g feature prune Delete merged feature branches

docs.title: Workflow Example
docs.text:
# 1. Start new feature
g feature start auth
# → Creates feature/auth from dev

# 2. Work on feature
# ... make changes ...
g aa && g commit "feat: add auth"

# 3. Keep in sync with dev
g feature sync
# → Rebases feature/auth onto dev

# 4. Complete feature
g feature finish
# → Pushes and creates PR to dev

# 5. After PR merged, cleanup
g feature prune
# → Deletes merged branches

docs.title: Promotion Commands
docs.text:
Command Description g promote Create PR: feature/* → dev g release Create PR: dev → main 
# On feature/auth branch
g promote    # Creates PR to dev

# On dev branch
g release    # Creates PR to main

docs.title: Feature Prune
docs.text:
Clean up merged feature branches:

g feature prune              # Delete merged (with confirmation)
g feature prune --force      # Skip confirmation
g feature prune --all        # Also delete remote branches
g feature prune --dry-run    # Preview only
g feature prune --older-than 30d  # Only branches >30 days old

docs.title: Options
docs.text: Option Short Description --force -f Skip confirmation prompts --all -a Also prune remote branches --dry-run -n Show what would be deleted --older-than <d> - Only prune older branches

docs.title: Duration Format
docs.text:
• 30d → 30 days
  • 1w → 1 week (7 days)
  • 2m → 2 months (60 days)

docs.title: Safety
docs.text:
• Only deletes merged branches
  • Never deletes: main, master, dev, develop
  • Never deletes current branch
  • Only targets: feature/*, bugfix/*, hotfix/*

docs.title: Feature Status
docs.text:
Show which branches are merged and which are active:

g feature status

Sample output:

📊 Feature Branch Status
━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━

🧹 Stale branches (merged to dev):
  • feature/old-auth                    (3 weeks ago)
  • bugfix/typo-fix                     (5 days ago)

⚠️  Active branches (not merged to dev):
  • feature/new-dashboard               4 commits ahead (2 days ago)
  • feature/api-refactor                12 commits ahead (1 hour ago)

━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━
Summary: 2 stale, 2 active
💡 Tip: Run g feature prune to clean up merged branches

docs.title: Passthrough
docs.text:
Unknown commands pass directly to git:

g remote -v        # → git remote -v
g cherry-pick abc  # → git cherry-pick abc
g reflog           # → git reflog
g tag v1.0.0       # → git tag v1.0.0

docs.title: Daily Workflow
docs.text:
# Start of day
g fetch --all
g main && g pull

# Start feature
g feature start new-dashboard
# ... work ...
g aa && g commit "feat: add dashboard"
g push

# Keep updated
g feature sync

# Complete
g feature finish

docs.title: Quick Fix
docs.text:
g                       # Check status
g aa                    # Stage all
g commit "fix: typo"    # Commit
g push                  # Push

docs.title: Undo Mistakes
docs.text:
g undo                  # Undo last commit
g unstage file.ts       # Unstage file
g discard file.ts       # Discard changes

docs.title: Cleanup
docs.text:
g feature status        # See what needs cleaning
g feature prune -n      # Preview cleanup
g feature prune         # Do cleanup

docs.title: With WT Dispatcher
docs.text:
Use worktrees for parallel feature development:

wt create feature/auth   # Create worktree
cd ~/.git-worktrees/project/feature-auth
g feature sync           # Keep in sync

docs.title: With CC Dispatcher
docs.text:
Launch Claude in a feature branch:

g feature start auth
cc                       # Launch Claude in feature

docs.title: "Direct push to 'main' blocked"
docs.text:
This is the workflow guard. Use the proper workflow:

g feature start <name>   # Start feature
g promote                # Create PR to dev
g release                # Create PR to main (from dev)

# Or override (not recommended):
GIT_WORKFLOW_SKIP=1 git push

docs.title: "Not on a feature branch"
docs.text:
Some commands require being on a feature branch:

g feature start myfeature   # Create one first
g feature sync              # Then sync

docs.title: "Uncommitted changes"
docs.text:
Stash or commit before switching:

g st              # Stash changes
# or
g aa && g commit "WIP"

docs.title: Related
docs.text:
• DISPATCHER-REFERENCE.md - All dispatchers
  • WT-DISPATCHER-REFERENCE.md - Worktree management
  • Tutorial: Git Feature Workflow

Last Updated: 2025-12-30 Version: v4.3.0+ Status: ✅ Fully implemented

docs.title: MCP Dispatcher Reference
docs.text:
MCP (Model Context Protocol) server management

Location: lib/dispatchers/mcp-dispatcher.zsh

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
mcp                   # List all servers with status
mcp cd shell          # Navigate to server directory
mcp test docling      # Test server runs
mcp pick              # Interactive server picker

docs.title: Usage
docs.text: mcp [command] [args]

docs.title: Key Insight
docs.text:
• mcp with no arguments lists all servers with configuration status
  • Shows both Desktop/CLI and Browser extension configuration
  • Interactive picker (mcp pick) for quick navigation
  • Test command validates servers actually run

docs.title: Core Commands
docs.text: Command Shortcut Description mcp mcp list, mcp ls, mcp l List all servers with status mcp cd <name> mcp goto, mcp g Navigate to server directory mcp test <name> mcp t Test server runs mcp edit <name> mcp e Edit in $EDITOR mcp pick mcp p Interactive picker (fzf)

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
mcp                   # List all servers
mcp cd shell          # Navigate to shell server
mcp test docling      # Test docling server
mcp edit shell        # Open in VS Code
mcp pick              # Interactive selection

docs.title: Info Commands
docs.text: Command Shortcut Description mcp status mcp s Show configuration status mcp readme <name> mcp r, mcp doc View server README mcp help mcp h Show help

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
mcp status            # Show Desktop/Browser config status
mcp readme docling    # View docling README
mcp help              # Show all commands

docs.title: Server List Output
docs.text:
Running mcp shows each server with:

● statistical-research
  📁 ~/projects/dev-tools/mcp-servers/statistical-research
  ✓ Desktop/CLI configured
  ✓ Browser configured
  📖 README available

● shell
  📁 ~/projects/dev-tools/mcp-servers/shell
  ✓ Desktop/CLI configured
  ○ Browser not configured

Total: 3 server(s)

ℹ  Quick access: cd ~/mcp-servers/<name>
ℹ  Interactive:  mcp pick

docs.title: Configuration Status
docs.text:
Running mcp status shows:

MCP Configuration Status

Desktop/CLI:
  ✓ ~/.claude/settings.json
  Configured servers:
    • filesystem
    • statistical-research
    • shell

Browser Extension:
  ✓ ~/projects/dev-tools/claude-mcp/MCP_SERVER_CONFIG.json
  Configured servers:
    • filesystem
    • statistical-research

docs.title: Interactive Picker
docs.text:
mcp pick (alias: mcpp) provides:

  1. fzf selection with README preview
  2. Action menu after selection:
  3. Navigate to server (cd)
  4. Edit in $EDITOR
  5. View README
  6. Test server
  7. Show in Finder

docs.title: Example
docs.text: mcpp                  # Quick picker alias

docs.title: Testing Servers
docs.text:
The test command validates a server can start:

mcp test statistical-research

Behavior: - Detects runtime (bun, node, uv) - Starts server with 3-second timeout - Reports success/failure - Shows any error output

Supported runtimes: - statistical-research → bun - shell, project-refactor → node - docling → uv (Python)

docs.title: Configuration Locations
docs.text: Config Path Servers ~/projects/dev-tools/mcp-servers/ Symlinks ~/mcp-servers/<name> Desktop/CLI ~/.claude/settings.json Browser ~/projects/dev-tools/claude-mcp/MCP_SERVER_CONFIG.json

docs.title: Shortcuts Summary
docs.text:
Full Short Description list ls, l List servers cd goto, g Navigate test t Test server edit e Edit server status s Config status readme r, doc View README pick p Interactive picker help h Show help

Alias: mcpp = mcp pick

docs.title: Daily Workflow
docs.text:
# Check what's configured
mcp status

# Navigate to work on a server
mcp cd statistical-research

# Test after changes
mcp test statistical-research

docs.title: Quick Navigation
docs.text:
# Interactive selection
mcpp

# Or direct navigation
mcp cd shell

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text:
# Check server runs
mcp test docling

# View documentation
mcp readme docling

# Edit configuration
mcp edit docling

docs.title: With CC Dispatcher
docs.text:
Launch Claude with MCP context:

mcp cd statistical-research
cc                    # Claude in MCP server dir

docs.title: With aiterm (Rich Features)
docs.text:
For advanced MCP management, aiterm provides enhanced capabilities:

ait mcp list          # Rich table view with status indicators
ait mcp validate      # Full JSON validation with error details
ait mcp test-all      # Batch health checking with timing
ait mcp info <name>   # Detailed config with masked secrets

When to use aiterm: - Validating MCP configuration before deployment - Debugging server connection issues - Getting detailed timing and health metrics

Documentation: aiterm MCP Integration Guide

docs.title: "MCP servers directory not found"
docs.text:
Set the directory:

export MCP_SERVERS_DIR="$HOME/projects/dev-tools/mcp-servers"

docs.title: "fzf not installed"
docs.text:
Install fzf for interactive picker:

brew install fzf

docs.title: "Server failed to start"
docs.text:
Check requirements: - statistical-research needs bun - shell needs node - docling needs uv (Python)

# Install runtimes
brew install node
brew install bun
brew install uv

docs.title: Related
docs.text:

  • CC-DISPATCHER-REFERENCE.md - Claude Code launcher

docs.title: OBS Dispatcher Reference
docs.text:
Obsidian vault management with AI-powered graph analysis

Location: lib/dispatchers/obs.zsh

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
obs                   # List registered vaults
obs stats <vault>     # Show vault statistics
obs discover <path>   # Find vaults in directory
obs analyze <vault>   # Analyze vault graph

docs.title: Usage
docs.text: obs [command] [options]

docs.title: Key Insight
docs.text:
• obs with no arguments lists registered vaults
  • Uses Python CLI for heavy lifting (graph analysis, AI features)
  • Manages Obsidian vaults stored in iCloud by default
  • AI features require API key configuration

docs.title: Core Commands
docs.text: Command Description obs List registered vaults obs stats [vault] Show vault statistics obs discover <path> Find vaults in directory obs vaults List all registered vaults

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
obs                           # Quick vault list
obs stats                     # Stats for all vaults
obs stats personal            # Stats for specific vault
obs discover ~/Documents      # Find new vaults

docs.title: Graph Analysis
docs.text: Command Description obs analyze <vault_id> Analyze vault graph metrics

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
obs analyze personal

Output includes: - Note count and link density - Orphan notes (unlinked) - Hub notes (highly connected) - Cluster analysis - Graph health score

docs.title: AI Features
docs.text:
AI-powered analysis requires API keys.

Command Description obs ai status Show AI provider status obs ai setup Interactive AI setup wizard obs ai test Test all AI providers obs ai similar <note> Find similar notes obs ai analyze <note> Analyze note with AI obs ai duplicates <vault> Find duplicate notes

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
# Setup
obs ai status                 # Check API key status
obs ai setup                  # Configure AI providers
obs ai test                   # Verify providers work

# Usage
obs ai similar my-note        # Find related notes
obs ai analyze my-note        # AI analysis of note
obs ai duplicates personal    # Find duplicates in vault

docs.title: Vault Discovery
docs.text:
Find Obsidian vaults in a directory:

obs discover ~/Documents
obs discover ~/Library/Mobile\ Documents/iCloud~md~obsidian/Documents

With scan flag:

obs discover ~/Documents --scan

Scans recursively for .obsidian folders.

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text: Setting Default iCloud path ~/Library/Mobile Documents/iCloud~md~obsidian/Documents Database ~/.config/obs/obsidian_vaults.db Last vault ~/.config/obs/last_vault

docs.title: Verbose Mode
docs.text:
Enable detailed output:

obs --verbose stats personal
obs -v analyze personal

docs.title: Daily Workflow
docs.text:
# Check your vaults
obs

# View specific vault stats
obs stats work

# Analyze graph health
obs analyze work

docs.title: Finding New Vaults
docs.text:
# Discover vaults in iCloud
obs discover

# Discover in custom location
obs discover ~/Documents/notes

docs.title: AI Analysis
docs.text:
# Setup AI first
obs ai setup

# Find similar notes
obs ai similar project-ideas

# Find duplicates
obs ai duplicates work

docs.title: With CC Dispatcher
docs.text:
Work on Obsidian tooling:

cd ~/projects/dev-tools/obsidian-cli-ops
cc                    # Claude with obs context

docs.title: "Python CLI not found"
docs.text:
The obs dispatcher requires the Python CLI:

# Check Python is available
which python3

# Verify CLI location
ls -la ~/projects/dev-tools/obsidian-cli-ops/src/python/

docs.title: "Vault ID required"
docs.text:
Get vault IDs first:

obs vaults            # List all vault IDs
obs stats <vault_id>  # Use the ID

docs.title: AI features not working
docs.text:
Check provider status:

obs ai status         # See API key status
obs ai setup          # Configure keys
obs ai test           # Verify connection

docs.title: Version
docs.text:
Current version: 3.0.0-dev

Check version:

obs version

docs.title: Related
docs.text: • DISPATCHER-REFERENCE.md - All dispatchers

docs.title: Full Documentation
docs.text:
The obs dispatcher is part of the obsidian-cli-ops project. For comprehensive documentation:

Resource URL User Guide data-wise.github.io/obsidian-cli-ops AI Setup See obs ai setup for configuration wizard Graph Analysis Deep dive in obsidian-cli-ops docs Source Code github.com/data-wise/obsidian-cli-ops

Note: This reference covers the flow-cli dispatcher integration. For advanced features, vault management strategies, and AI configuration, refer to the obsidian-cli-ops documentation.

docs.title: Pick Command Reference
docs.text:
Interactive project picker with fuzzy search, smart resume, and direct jump

Location: commands/pick.zsh

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
pick              # Smart resume or browse all projects
pick flow         # Direct jump to flow-cli (no picker)
pick r            # Show only R packages
pick -a           # Force full picker (bypass resume)

docs.title: Usage
docs.text: pick [options] [category|project-name]

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text: Argument Description project-name Direct jump to matching project (fuzzy) category Filter by category (r, dev, q, etc.) -a, --all Force full picker (skip direct jump) --fast Skip git status checks (faster loading)

docs.title: Direct Jump
docs.text:
Jump directly to a project without the picker:

pick flow         # → cd to flow-cli (exact match)
pick med          # → cd to mediationverse
pick stat         # → Multiple matches? Shows filtered picker

docs.title: Session-Aware Resume
docs.text:
When you run pick with no args and have a recent session:

╔════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════╗
║  🔍 PROJECT PICKER                                         ║
╚════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════╝

  💡 Last: flow-cli (2h ago)
  [Enter] Resume  │  [Space] Browse all  │  Type to search...
Key Action Enter Resume last project Space Force full picker (bypass resume) Type Filter projects as before

Sessions expire after 24 hours.

docs.title: Worktree Integration (v4.6.1)
docs.text:
By default, pick shows both projects AND worktrees:

flow-cli             🔧 dev
mediationverse       📦 r
medrobust            📦 r
flow-cli (feature-x) 🌳 wt   🟢 2h
aiterm (bugfix)      🌳 wt   🟡 old

Key features:

  • 🌳 icon indicates a git worktree
  • Session indicators show Claude Code activity:
  • 🟢 Recent session (within 24h) with time since last activity
  • 🟡 Old session (>24h ago)
  • Sorted by recency - most recently used worktrees appear first

Worktree-only view:

pick wt              # Show only worktrees
pick wt flow         # Filter worktrees for "flow" project

Requirements:

Worktrees must be organized under ~/.git-worktrees (default):

~/.git-worktrees/
├── flow-cli/
│   ├── feature-x/       # worktree for feature-x branch
│   └── bugfix/          # worktree for bugfix branch
└── aiterm/
    └── develop/         # worktree for develop branch

To create a worktree: wt create <branch> or git worktree add ~/.git-worktrees/<project>/<branch> <branch>

docs.title: Categories
docs.text:
All category names are case-insensitive and support multiple aliases:

Category Aliases Description r r, R, rpack, rpkg R packages dev dev, Dev, DEV, tool, tools Development tools q q, Q, qu, quarto Quarto projects teach teach, teaching Teaching courses rs rs, research, res Research projects app app, apps Applications wt wt, worktree, worktrees Git worktrees

docs.title: Interactive Keys
docs.text: Key Action Description Enter cd Change to selected project (or resume) Space browse Force full picker (bypass resume prompt) Ctrl-S status View .STATUS file (with bat/cat) Ctrl-L log View git log (with tig/git) Ctrl-C cancel Exit without action

docs.title: Display Format
docs.text:
project-name         icon type
────────────────────────────────
flow-cli    🔧 dev
mediationverse       📦 r
medrobust            📦 r
apple-notes-sync     🔧 dev

Note: Git status display was removed for simplicity and reliability. A --git flag may be added in future versions to optionally show branch and status information.

docs.title: Icons by Category
docs.text:
• 📦 - R packages (r)
  • 🔧 - Dev tools (dev)
  • 📝 - Quarto projects (q)
  • 📚 - Teaching courses (teach)
  • 🔬 - Research projects (rs)
  • 📱 - Applications (app)
  • 🌳 - Git worktrees (wt)

docs.title: Direct Jump (NEW)
docs.text:
# Jump to project by name (fuzzy match)
pick flow         # → flow-cli
pick med          # → mediationverse
pick stat         # → Multiple matches? Shows filtered picker

# Force full picker even with name
pick -a flow      # Shows picker, pre-filtered to "flow"

docs.title: Smart Resume (NEW)
docs.text:
# If you were recently in flow-cli:
pick              # Shows: "💡 Last: flow-cli (2h ago)"
                  # Press Enter to resume, Space to browse

docs.title: Category Filtering
docs.text:
# Filter by category
pick r            # R packages only
pick dev          # Dev tools only
pick DEV          # Case-insensitive

# Fast mode with filter
pick --fast r

docs.title: Interactive Actions
docs.text:
# In the picker:
#   - Type to filter projects
#   - Press Enter to cd (or resume last)
#   - Press Space to bypass resume and browse all
#   - Press Ctrl-S to view .STATUS file
#   - Press Ctrl-L to view git log

docs.title: Aliases
docs.text:
Shortcuts available for common categories:

pickr             # Expands to: pick r
pickdev           # Expands to: pick dev
pickq             # Expands to: pick q

docs.title: ADHD-Friendly Design
docs.text:
• Color-coded status - Pre-attentive processing (see status before reading)
  • Forgiving input - Multiple aliases, case-insensitive
  • Visual hierarchy - Icons, colors, clear sections
  • Fast mode - Skip git checks when you need speed
  • Dynamic headers - Always know what you're filtering

docs.title: Technical Features
docs.text:
• Process substitution (no subshell pollution)
  • Branch name truncation (20 chars max)
  • ANSI color support with fzf --ansi flag
  • Comprehensive error handling
  • Git status caching potential

docs.title: Integration
docs.text:
Works with:

  • cc dispatcher - cc uses pick for project selection, then launches Claude
  • cc <project> - Direct jump to project + Claude (inherits pick's direct jump)
  • work command - Start work session in selected project
  • bat - Syntax-highlighted .STATUS viewing
  • tig - Interactive git log browser

docs.title: Next Phase Enhancements
docs.text:
Planned features for future releases:

  • P6A: Preview pane showing .STATUS, README, git info
  • P6B: Frecency sorting (frequency + recency)
  • P6C: Multi-select batch operations
  • P6D: Advanced actions (PR creation, deployment)
  • P6E: Smart filters (by git status, .STATUS progress)
  • P6F: Performance optimization (parallel git, caching)

docs.title: Colors not showing?
docs.text: Make sure your terminal supports ANSI colors and fzf has the --ansi flag.

docs.title: Parse error at line 49?
docs.text:
Reload the function:

source ~/.config/zsh/functions/adhd-helpers.zsh

docs.title: Formatting broken?
docs.text:
Check that ANSI escape codes use double quotes in printf:

# Correct:
printf "\033[32m✅\033[0m"

# Incorrect:
printf '\033[32m✅\033[0m'  # Single quotes don't interpret escapes

Last Updated: 2025-12-31 Status: ✅ Fully implemented (v4.6.1 - worktree integration)

docs.title: Project Detection User Guide
docs.text: Feature: Automatic project type detection Status: ✅ Available now Difficulty: Beginner-friendly

docs.title: What is Project Detection?
docs.text:
Project detection automatically identifies what type of project you're working with by looking at files in your project directory. It can detect:

  • 📦 R Packages - Projects with DESCRIPTION files
  • 📄 Quarto Projects - Projects with _quarto.yml or .qmd files
  • 🔌 Quarto Extensions - Quarto plugin projects
  • 🔬 Research Projects - Projects with LaTeX, bibliographies
  • 📁 Generic Git Projects - Any project with .git
  • ❓ Unknown - Unrecognized project types

docs.title: Using the API (JavaScript/Node.js)
docs.text:
import { detectProjectType } from 'flow-cli/cli/lib/project-detector-bridge.js'

// Detect a single project
const type = await detectProjectType('/Users/dt/projects/r-packages/stable/rmediation')
console.log(`Project type: ${type}`) // "r-package"

docs.title: Using a CLI Tool (Coming Soon)
docs.text:
# Detect current directory
zsh-config detect

# Detect specific directory
zsh-config detect ~/projects/teaching/stat-440

docs.title: R Package (r-package)
docs.text:
Detected when:

  • Project has a DESCRIPTION file
  • DESCRIPTION contains Package: field

Example:

my-r-package/
├── DESCRIPTION       ← Must have "Package: mypackage"
├── R/
│   └── functions.R
├── man/
└── NAMESPACE

Detection:

const type = await detectProjectType('/path/to/my-r-package')
// Returns: 'r-package'

docs.title: Quarto Project (quarto)
docs.text:
Detected when project has ANY of:

  • _quarto.yml file
  • _quarto.yaml file
  • index.qmd file
  • README.qmd file

Example:

my-quarto-project/
├── _quarto.yml       ← Configuration file
├── index.qmd         ← Homepage
└── chapters/
    ├── chapter1.qmd
    └── chapter2.qmd

Detection:

const type = await detectProjectType('/path/to/my-quarto-project')
// Returns: 'quarto'

docs.title: Quarto Extension (quarto-extension)
docs.text:
Detected when project has:

  • _extension.yml file OR
  • _extensions.yml file

Example:

my-quarto-extension/
├── _extension.yml    ← Extension config
└── shortcode.lua

Note: Quarto extensions are detected before regular Quarto projects, so a project with both _extension.yml and _quarto.yml will be identified as an extension.

docs.title: Research Project (research)
docs.text:
Detected when project has ANY of:

  • main.tex (LaTeX main file)
  • manuscript.tex (Manuscript file)
  • literature/ directory
  • references.bib (Bibliography)

Example:

my-research/
├── manuscript.tex
├── references.bib    ← Any of these triggers detection
├── figures/
└── literature/       ← Research papers directory

Detection:

const type = await detectProjectType('/path/to/my-research')
// Returns: 'research'

docs.title: Generic Git Project (generic)
docs.text:
Detected when:

  • Project has a .git directory
  • Doesn't match any more specific type

Example:

my-project/
├── .git/            ← Git repository
├── README.md
└── src/
    └── code.js

Detection:

const type = await detectProjectType('/path/to/my-project')
// Returns: 'generic'

docs.title: Unknown (unknown)
docs.text:
Returned when:

  • Project doesn't match any known type
  • Path doesn't exist
  • Permission denied

Example:

const type1 = await detectProjectType('/nonexistent/path')
// Returns: 'unknown'

const type2 = await detectProjectType('/random/folder')
// Returns: 'unknown' (no .git, no markers)

docs.title: 1. Detect Current Working Directory
docs.text:
import { detectProjectType } from 'flow-cli/cli/lib/project-detector-bridge.js'
import { cwd } from 'process'

const currentType = await detectProjectType(cwd())
console.log(`You're working in a ${currentType} project`)

docs.title: 2. Detect Multiple Projects
docs.text:
import { detectMultipleProjects } from 'flow-cli/cli/lib/project-detector-bridge.js'

const results = await detectMultipleProjects([
  '/Users/dt/projects/r-packages/stable/rmediation',
  '/Users/dt/projects/teaching/stat-440',
  '/Users/dt/projects/dev-tools/flow-cli'
])

// Results:
// {
//   '/Users/dt/projects/r-packages/stable/rmediation': 'r-package',
//   '/Users/dt/projects/teaching/stat-440': 'quarto',
//   '/Users/dt/projects/dev-tools/flow-cli': 'generic'
// }

docs.title: 3. Filter Projects by Type
docs.text:
import { detectMultipleProjects } from 'flow-cli/cli/lib/project-detector-bridge.js'
import { readdir } from 'fs/promises'
import { join } from 'path'

// Find all R packages in a directory
const basePath = '/Users/dt/projects/r-packages/stable'
const entries = await readdir(basePath, { withFileTypes: true })
const dirs = entries.filter(e => e.isDirectory()).map(e => join(basePath, e.name))

const types = await detectMultipleProjects(dirs)

// Filter for R packages only
const rPackages = Object.entries(types)
  .filter(([path, type]) => type === 'r-package')
  .map(([path, type]) => path)

console.log(`Found ${rPackages.length} R packages`)

docs.title: 4. Check if Type is Supported
docs.text:
import { isTypeSupported, getSupportedTypes } from 'flow-cli/cli/lib/project-detector-bridge.js'

// Check specific type
if (isTypeSupported('r-package')) {
  console.log('R packages are supported')
}

// List all supported types
const types = getSupportedTypes()
console.log('Supported types:', types)
// ['r-package', 'quarto', 'quarto-extension', 'research', 'generic', 'unknown']

docs.title: Example 1: Detect R Package
docs.text:
// Project: rmediation (R package for mediation analysis)
const type = await detectProjectType('/Users/dt/projects/r-packages/stable/rmediation')

console.log(type) // 'r-package'

// Why? Has DESCRIPTION file with:
// Package: rmediation
// Title: Parametric and Nonparametric Mediation Analysis

docs.title: Example 2: Detect Quarto Course
docs.text:
// Project: STAT 440 (Regression Analysis course)
const type = await detectProjectType('/Users/dt/projects/teaching/stat-440')

console.log(type) // 'quarto'

// Why? Has _quarto.yml:
// project:
//   type: website

docs.title: Example 3: Scan All Teaching Projects
docs.text:
import { detectMultipleProjects } from 'flow-cli/cli/lib/project-detector-bridge.js'

const teachingProjects = [
  '/Users/dt/projects/teaching/stat-440', // Regression
  '/Users/dt/projects/teaching/causal-inference', // Causal inference
  '/Users/dt/projects/teaching/S440_regression_Fall_2024' // Archive
]

const results = await detectMultipleProjects(teachingProjects)

// Results:
// {
//   '.../stat-440': 'quarto',
//   '.../causal-inference': 'quarto',
//   '.../S440_regression_Fall_2024': 'quarto'
// }

// All are Quarto projects!

docs.title: Problem: Returns 'unknown' for valid project
docs.text:
Cause: Project doesn't have the expected marker files

Solution: Check for marker files:

# R package needs DESCRIPTION with Package: field
cd /path/to/project
grep "^Package:" DESCRIPTION

# Quarto needs _quarto.yml or .qmd files
ls -la _quarto.yml *.qmd

# Research needs LaTeX or bibliography
ls -la *.tex references.bib literature/

# Git project needs .git directory
ls -la .git

If markers exist but detection still fails, check file permissions:

chmod +r DESCRIPTION _quarto.yml  # Make files readable

docs.title: Problem: "Permission denied" errors
docs.text:
Cause: Node.js process can't read project directory

Solution: Ensure read permissions:

# Check permissions
ls -la /path/to/project

# Fix permissions
chmod +r /path/to/project
chmod +rx /path/to/project  # Also need execute for directories

docs.title: Problem: Detection is slow
docs.text:
Cause: Detecting many projects sequentially

Solution: Use batch detection:

// ❌ Slow: Sequential
for (const path of allPaths) {
  const type = await detectProjectType(path) // Waits for each
}

// ✅ Fast: Parallel batch
const types = await detectMultipleProjects(allPaths) // All at once

Performance:

  • Sequential (10 projects): ~200-300ms
  • Parallel (10 projects): ~50-100ms
  • 3x faster with batch detection!

docs.title: Problem: Need to detect custom project types
docs.text:
Status: Not yet supported (coming in Phase 2)

Workaround: Use generic detection and add your own logic:

const type = await detectProjectType('/path/to/project')

// Add custom logic
if (type === 'generic') {
  // Check for custom markers
  if (existsSync(join(projectPath, 'cargo.toml'))) {
    return 'rust'
  }
  if (existsSync(join(projectPath, 'go.mod'))) {
    return 'go'
  }
}

docs.title: ✅ Do
docs.text:
• Use batch detection for multiple projects (faster)
  • Handle 'unknown' type gracefully in your application
  • Use absolute paths for reliability
  • Check isTypeSupported() before using type in logic

docs.title: ❌ Don't
docs.text:
• Don't detect sequentially when you have multiple projects
  • Don't throw errors on 'unknown' type (it's expected)
  • Don't use relative paths (may give unexpected results)
  • Don't assume types - always call the API

docs.title: API Quick Reference
docs.text:
// Import functions
import {
  detectProjectType,
  detectMultipleProjects,
  getSupportedTypes,
  isTypeSupported
} from 'flow-cli/cli/lib/project-detector-bridge.js'

// Single detection
const type = await detectProjectType('/path/to/project')

// Batch detection (parallel)
const types = await detectMultipleProjects(['/path1', '/path2'])

// Get all supported types
const allTypes = getSupportedTypes()

// Check if type is supported
if (isTypeSupported('r-package')) {
  /* ... */
}

docs.title: Build a Project Dashboard
docs.text:
import { detectMultipleProjects } from 'flow-cli/cli/lib/project-detector-bridge.js'
import { readdir } from 'fs/promises'
import { join } from 'path'

async function buildDashboard(baseDir) {
  // Scan all subdirectories
  const entries = await readdir(baseDir, { withFileTypes: true })
  const dirs = entries.filter(e => e.isDirectory()).map(e => join(baseDir, e.name))

  // Detect all types in parallel
  const types = await detectMultipleProjects(dirs)

  // Group by type
  const grouped = {}
  for (const [path, type] of Object.entries(types)) {
    if (!grouped[type]) grouped[type] = []
    grouped[type].push({
      name: path.split('/').pop(),
      path: path
    })
  }

  return grouped
}

// Usage
const dashboard = await buildDashboard('/Users/dt/projects/r-packages/stable')

console.log(`R Packages: ${dashboard['r-package']?.length || 0}`)
console.log(`Quarto Projects: ${dashboard['quarto']?.length || 0}`)

docs.title: Conditional Workflow Based on Type
docs.text:
import { detectProjectType } from 'flow-cli/cli/lib/project-detector-bridge.js'

async function runBuild(projectPath) {
  const type = await detectProjectType(projectPath)

  switch (type) {
    case 'r-package':
      console.log('Running R CMD build...')
      // R package build logic
      break

    case 'quarto':
      console.log('Running quarto render...')
      // Quarto render logic
      break

    case 'research':
      console.log('Compiling LaTeX...')
      // LaTeX compilation logic
      break

    default:
      console.log('Generic build process...')
    // Default build logic
  }
}

  • [ ] Project scanner - Recursive directory scanning

docs.text:
• Dispatcher Reference - All dispatchers
  • Contributing Guide - Development patterns

docs.title: Issues & Questions
docs.text:
• GitHub Issues: (coming soon)
  • Email: dtofighi@gmail.com
  • Or ask Claude Code: "How do I detect Quarto projects?"

docs.title: Summary
docs.text:
Key Takeaways:

  1. Automatic detection - No manual configuration needed
  2. 6 project types - R, Quarto, research, git, and more
  3. Simple API - Just call detectProjectType(path)
  4. Batch support - Detect multiple projects in parallel
  5. Graceful errors - Returns 'unknown' instead of crashing
  6. Zero dependencies - Works out of the box

Quick Start:

import { detectProjectType } from 'flow-cli/cli/lib/project-detector-bridge.js'

const type = await detectProjectType('/path/to/project')
console.log(`Project type: ${type}`)

Next Steps:

  1. Try detecting your own projects
  2. Build a project scanner using batch detection
  3. Integrate with your workflow tools
  4. Share feedback for improvements!

docs.title: QU Dispatcher Reference
docs.text:
Quarto publishing workflows with smart defaults

Location: lib/dispatchers/qu-dispatcher.zsh

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
qu                    # Render → preview → open browser
qu preview            # Live preview with hot reload
qu render             # Render document/project
qu publish            # Publish to web

docs.title: Usage
docs.text: qu [command] [args]

docs.title: Key Insight
docs.text:
• qu with no arguments runs the smart default workflow
  • Smart default: render → start preview server → open browser
  • Graceful failure: skips preview if render fails
  • ADHD-friendly: one command does everything

docs.title: Smart Default Workflow
docs.text:
Running qu with no arguments:

qu

What happens:

  1. Renders current Quarto document
  2. Starts preview server (--no-browser)
  3. Auto-opens browser at http://localhost:4200
  4. Skips preview if render fails

This is the 80% use case - see your work instantly with one command.

docs.title: Core Commands
docs.text: Command Shortcut Description qu - Smart default: render → preview → open qu preview qu p Start preview server & open browser qu render qu r Render document/project qu check qu c Check Quarto installation qu clean - Remove _site, _cache, _files qu publish - Publish to web

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
qu                    # Full workflow
qu preview            # Live preview only
qu render             # Just render
qu check              # Verify installation
qu clean              # Clean build artifacts

docs.title: Format-Specific Rendering
docs.text: Command Description qu pdf Render to PDF qu html Render to HTML qu docx Render to Word document

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
# Render to specific format
qu pdf                # Generate PDF
qu html               # Generate HTML
qu docx               # Generate Word doc

# Render specific file to format
qu pdf chapter1.qmd

docs.title: Project Creation
docs.text: Command Description qu new <name> Create new Quarto project qu article <name> Create article project qu present <name> Create presentation project qu serve Serve project (alias for preview)

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
# Create new project
qu new my-report

# Create article (for journals)
qu article my-paper

# Create presentation
qu present my-slides

docs.title: Combined Workflows
docs.text: Command Description qu commit Render and commit changes

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
# Render and commit in one step
qu commit "Update analysis section"

What happens: 1. Runs quarto render 2. Stages all changes (git add -A) 3. Commits with your message

docs.title: Daily Writing Workflow
docs.text:
# Start working
cd ~/manuscripts/my-paper
qu                    # Render and preview

# After edits, refresh
qu                    # Re-render and preview

# End of session
qu commit "Add results section"

docs.title: Multi-Format Output
docs.text:
# Render to multiple formats
qu html               # For web
qu pdf                # For submission
qu docx               # For collaborators

docs.title: Project Setup
docs.text:
# New research article
qu article collider-bias
cd collider-bias
qu                    # Preview template

docs.title: Publishing
docs.text:
# Publish to GitHub Pages
qu publish gh-pages

# Publish to Quarto Pub
qu publish quarto-pub

# Publish to Netlify
qu publish netlify

docs.title: Preview Server
docs.text:
The preview server provides live reload:

qu preview

Features: - Auto-refresh on file changes - Runs on http://localhost:4200 - Background process (&) - Auto-opens browser

docs.title: Clean Build
docs.text:
Remove all build artifacts:

qu clean

Removes: - _site/ - Generated site - *_cache/ - Knitr/Jupyter caches - *_files/ - Supporting files

docs.title: With G Dispatcher
docs.text:
Use git workflows with Quarto:

g feature start new-chapter
qu                    # Preview changes
g aa && g commit "feat: add new chapter"
g promote             # PR to dev

docs.title: With CC Dispatcher
docs.text:
Launch Claude for Quarto work:

cc                    # Claude in current dir
# Ask Claude about Quarto formatting, YAML, etc.

docs.title: "quarto: command not found"
docs.text:
Install Quarto:

# macOS
brew install --cask quarto

# Or download from quarto.org

docs.title: Preview server won't start
docs.text:
Check if port is in use:

lsof -i :4200
# Kill existing process if needed

docs.title: Render fails
docs.text:
Check Quarto installation:

qu check

Common issues: - Missing LaTeX for PDF (install tinytex: quarto install tinytex) - Missing R packages (check YAML dependencies) - Invalid YAML frontmatter

docs.title: R Dispatcher Reference
docs.text:
R package development workflows with devtools integration

Location: lib/dispatchers/r-dispatcher.zsh

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
r                     # Launch R console (radian if available)
r test                # Run tests
r cycle               # Full cycle: doc → test → check
r check               # R CMD check

docs.title: Usage
docs.text: r [command] [args]

docs.title: Key Insight
docs.text:
• r with no arguments launches R console (radian preferred)
  • All commands wrap devtools functions for consistency
  • r cycle is the most common development workflow
  • ADHD-friendly shortcuts for frequent operations

docs.title: Core Workflow Commands
docs.text: Command Shortcut Description r load r l Load package (devtools::load_all) r test r t Run tests (devtools::test) r doc r d Generate documentation (devtools::document) r check r c R CMD check (devtools::check) r build r b Build package (devtools::build) r install r i Install package (devtools::install)

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
r load                # Load package for testing
r test                # Run all tests
r doc                 # Regenerate documentation
r check               # Full R CMD check

docs.title: Combined Workflows
docs.text: Command Description r cycle Full cycle: doc → test → check r quick Quick iteration: load → test

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
# Full development cycle
r cycle

# Quick iteration loop
r quick
# or manually:
r load && r test

docs.title: Quality Commands
docs.text: Command Description r cov Coverage report (covr::package_coverage) r spell Spell check package (spelling::spell_check_package)

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
r cov                 # Generate coverage report
r spell               # Check spelling in docs

docs.title: Documentation Commands
docs.text: Command Shortcut Description r pkgdown r pd Build pkgdown site r preview r pv Preview pkgdown site

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
r pkgdown             # Build documentation site
r preview             # Preview in browser

docs.title: CRAN Checks
docs.text: Command Description r cran Check as CRAN (--as-cran flag) r fast Fast check (skip examples/tests/vignettes) r win Windows development check

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
# Before CRAN submission
r cran

# Quick syntax check
r fast

# Windows compatibility
r win

docs.title: Version Bumps
docs.text: Command Description r patch Bump patch version (0.0.X) r minor Bump minor version (0.X.0) r major Bump major version (X.0.0)

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
# Bug fix release
r patch               # 0.1.0 → 0.1.1

# New feature release
r minor               # 0.1.1 → 0.2.0

# Breaking change release
r major               # 0.2.0 → 1.0.0

docs.title: Cleanup Commands
docs.text: Command Shortcut Description r clean r cl Remove .Rhistory and .RData r deep r deepclean Deep clean (man/, NAMESPACE, docs/) r tex r latex Remove LaTeX build files r commit r save Document, test, and commit

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
# Quick cleanup
r clean

# Full cleanup (with confirmation)
r deep
# ⚠️  WARNING: This will remove man/, NAMESPACE, docs/
# Continue? (y/N)

# After LaTeX rendering
r tex

# Save work with auto-commit
r commit "Add new feature"

docs.title: Info Commands
docs.text: Command Description r info Package info summary (calls rpkginfo) r tree Package structure tree (calls rpkgtree)

docs.title: Examples

r info                # Show package metadata
r tree                # Display file structure

docs.title: R Console
docs.text:
Running r with no arguments launches the R console:

r                     # Launch R console

Behavior: - Uses radian if installed (better REPL experience) - Falls back to standard R console - Runs in quiet mode (--quiet)

docs.title: Daily Development
docs.text:

cd ~/projects/r-packages/mypackage
r load                # Load package

# Make changes, then test
r test                # Run tests
r doc                 # Update docs

r win                 # Windows compatibility
r spell               # Spell check

# Bump version
r minor               # Update version

docs.title: Quick Iteration
docs.text:
# Fast feedback loop
r quick               # load → test
# or
r load && r test

docs.title: Documentation
docs.text:
# Update and preview docs
r doc                 # Generate Rd files
r pkgdown             # Build site
r preview             # View in browser

docs.title: With G Dispatcher
docs.text:
Use git workflows with R development:

g feature start new-function
r load && r test
g aa && g commit "feat: add new function"
g promote             # PR to dev

docs.text:
Launch Claude for R package work:

cc pick               # Pick R package project

docs.title: "devtools not installed"
docs.text:
Install required packages:

install.packages(c("devtools", "usethis", "covr", "spelling", "pkgdown"))

docs.title: "radian not found"
docs.text:
Install radian for better REPL:

pip install radian

Or use standard R console (automatic fallback).

docs.text:
Ensure tests pass first:

r test                # Fix any failing tests
r cov                 # Then run coverage

docs.title: Testing Quick Reference
docs.text: flow-cli Test Suite Overview

docs.title: Quick Commands
docs.text:
# Interactive Dog Feeding Test (Most Fun!) 🐕
./tests/interactive-dog-feeding.zsh

# Automated Test Suite (Fast)
./tests/automated-test.zsh

# ZSH Configuration Tests
zsh/tests/run-all-tests.zsh

# Quick check (no performance test)
zsh/tests/run-all-tests.zsh --quick

docs.title: 1. Interactive Dog Feeding Test 🐕⭐
docs.text:
Location: tests/interactive-dog-feeding.zsh

Purpose: Gamified manual validation of all core commands

Features:

  • 👀 Shows comprehensive expected patterns
  • ▶️ Runs commands and shows actual output
  • ❓ Interactive y/n validation
  • 🐕 Feed virtual dog by confirming tests pass
  • ⭐ Earn 1-5 stars based on performance

What It Tests (7 tasks):

  1. Dashboard display (16 detailed patterns)
  2. Work session start (7 patterns)
  3. Idea capture (3 patterns)
  4. Win logging (4 patterns)
  5. Active session in dashboard (7 patterns)
  6. ADHD helper js (6 patterns)
  7. Session finish (3 patterns)

Best For:

  • First-time installation validation
  • After major changes
  • Teaching new users
  • Making testing enjoyable

Time: ~3-5 minutes (interactive)

docs.title: 2. Automated Test Suite
docs.text:
Location: tests/automated-test.zsh

Purpose: Non-interactive automated validation

What It Tests:

  • Plugin loading
  • Core commands (dash, work, finish)
  • Session tracking
  • Status parsing
  • Aliases

Tests: 16 automated checks

Time: ~10 seconds

Exit Codes:

  • 0 - All tests passed
  • 1 - Some tests failed

Best For:

  • CI/CD pipelines
  • Quick validation
  • Pre-commit checks

docs.title: 3. ZSH Configuration Tests
docs.text:
Location: zsh/tests/run-all-tests.zsh

Purpose: Validate ZSH plugin structure

What It Tests:

  • Duplicate detection
  • Dispatcher functions
  • Startup performance

Options:

# Full suite (includes performance test)
zsh/tests/run-all-tests.zsh

# Quick (skip performance)
zsh/tests/run-all-tests.zsh --quick

Best For:

  • After refactoring
  • Checking for duplicates
  • Performance regression

docs.title: Interactive Dog Feeding
docs.text:
Tasks Confirmed: 7 / 7
Final Happiness: 98%
Grade:           PERFECT!
Stars:           ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐
🐕 The dog is ECSTATIC! All tests confirmed! 😊⭐

docs.title: Automated Test
docs.text:
Tests run:    16
Passed:       16
Failed:       0
✓ All tests passed!

docs.title: ZSH Tests
docs.text:
Passed:  2
Failed:  0
Skipped: 1
OVERALL: PASS

docs.title: Grading System (Dog Feeding Test)
docs.text: Tasks Grade Stars Dog Status 7/7 PERFECT! ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐ ECSTATIC! 😊⭐ 5-6 EXCELLENT! ⭐⭐⭐⭐ Very happy! 😊 3-4 GOOD ⭐⭐⭐ Satisfied 🤔 0-2 NEEDS WORK ⭐ Still hungry 😢

docs.title: After Fresh Install
docs.text:
git clone https://github.com/data-wise/flow-cli.git
cd flow-cli
./tests/interactive-dog-feeding.zsh

docs.title: Quick CI Check
docs.text: ./tests/automated-test.zsh && echo "CI: PASS"

docs.title: After Code Changes
docs.text:
# Full validation
./tests/automated-test.zsh
zsh/tests/run-all-tests.zsh --quick
./tests/interactive-dog-feeding.zsh

docs.title: Dog Test Shows Wrong Expected Output
docs.text: Fixed in v3.0.0! Parameter parsing bug resolved.

docs.title: Command Not Found Errors
docs.text:
Make sure plugin is loaded:

source flow.plugin.zsh

docs.title: Tests Fail But Commands Work
docs.text: Check for external command dependencies (grep, head, etc.)

docs.title: Test Coverage
docs.text: Total Patterns: ~60 comprehensive expected patterns Commands Tested: dash, work, finish, catch, win, js Test Types: Interactive, Automated, Unit, Integration Pass Rate Target: 100%

docs.title: Latest Updates (Dec 25, 2025)
docs.text: ✅ Fixed parameter parsing in interactive test ✅ Added 60 comprehensive expected patterns ✅ Dashboard test upgraded: 4 → 16 patterns (+300%) ✅ All tests updated for v3.0.0 architecture ✅ ZSH configuration tests fixed for new structure

docs.title: TM Dispatcher Reference
docs.text:
Terminal management via aiterm integration

Location: lib/dispatchers/tm-dispatcher.zsh

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
tm                    # Show help
tm title "My Task"    # Set tab title (instant)
tm detect             # Detect project context
tm switch             # Apply context to terminal

docs.title: Usage
docs.text: tm <command> [args]

docs.title: Key Insight
docs.text:
• Shell-native commands (title, profile, var, which) are instant - no Python overhead
  • Complex operations delegate to aiterm Python CLI
  • Works without aiterm installed (shell-native commands still work)

docs.title: Shell-Native Commands
docs.text:
These commands execute instantly using ZSH escape sequences:

Command Description Notes tm title <text> Set tab/window title Universal OSC 2 sequence tm profile <name> Switch iTerm2 profile iTerm2 only tm var <key> <val> Set iTerm2 status bar variable iTerm2 only tm which Show detected terminal Returns: iterm2, ghostty, kitty, etc.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
# Set descriptive title for current task
tm title "Working on auth feature"
tm t "Bug fix #123"                   # Shortcut

# Switch iTerm2 profile for visual context
tm profile "Coding Dark"
tm p "Default"                        # Shortcut

# Set status bar variable (iTerm2)
tm var task "Reviewing PR"
tm v project "flow-cli"               # Shortcut

# Check which terminal you're in
tm which                              # → iterm2, ghostty, etc.
tm w                                  # Shortcut

docs.title: Aiterm Delegation
docs.text:
These commands delegate to the aiterm Python CLI:

Command Description Requires tm ghost Ghostty terminal status aiterm ≥ 0.3.9 tm ghost theme List/set Ghostty themes aiterm ≥ 0.3.9 tm ghost font Get/set Ghostty font aiterm ≥ 0.3.9 tm switch Apply terminal context aiterm tm detect Detect project context aiterm tm doctor Check terminal health aiterm tm compare Compare terminal features aiterm ≥ 0.3.9 tm features Show terminal feature matrix aiterm tm status Show terminal detection aiterm

docs.title: Ghostty Management
docs.text:
# Check Ghostty status
tm ghost

# List available themes
tm ghost theme

# Set theme
tm ghost theme tokyo-night

# Get current font
tm ghost font

# Set font
tm ghost font "JetBrains Mono"

docs.title: Context Detection
docs.text:
# Detect current project context
tm detect
# → Shows: terminal, project type, suggested profile

# Apply detected context
tm switch
# → Updates title, profile, and status bar

docs.title: Health Check
docs.text:
# Check terminal configuration
tm doctor
# → Validates: fonts, colors, integrations

docs.title: Shortcuts
docs.text: Full Short Description title t Set title profile p Switch profile var v Set variable which w Detect terminal ghost g Ghostty commands switch s Apply context detect d Detect context

docs.title: Aliases
docs.text: Alias Expands To Description tmt tm title Quick title set tmp tm profile Quick profile switch tmv tm var Quick variable set tmw tm which Quick terminal detect tmg tm ghost Ghostty commands tms tm switch Apply context tmd tm detect Detect context

docs.title: Terminal Support
docs.text:
The dispatcher auto-detects these terminals:

Terminal Detection Profiles Themes Title iTerm2 $TERM_PROGRAM ✅ ✅ ✅ Ghostty $TERM_PROGRAM - ✅ ✅ WezTerm $TERM_PROGRAM ✅ ✅ ✅ Kitty $KITTY_WINDOW_ID - ✅ ✅ Alacritty $ALACRITTY_WINDOW_ID - ✅ ✅ VS Code $TERM_PROGRAM - - ✅ Terminal.app $TERM_PROGRAM - - ✅

docs.title: Required (for full features)
docs.text:
• aiterm - Terminal optimization CLI 
    brew install data-wise/tap/aiterm  # macOS
pip install aiterm-dev              # Cross-platform

docs.title: Optional (shell-native commands work without aiterm)
docs.text: Shell-native commands (title, profile, var, which) work without aiterm installed.

docs.title: Daily Workflow
docs.text:
# Start of session - set context
tm detect                    # See what context is detected
tm switch                    # Apply it

# Working on a feature
tm title "feature/auth"      # Set descriptive title
tm profile "Coding"          # Switch to coding profile

# Quick terminal check
tm which                     # → iterm2

docs.title: Ghostty Users
docs.text:
# Browse available themes
tm ghost theme

# Try a theme
tm ghost theme catppuccin-mocha

# Check font settings
tm ghost font

docs.title: Debugging
docs.text:
# Check terminal health
tm doctor

# Compare terminal features
tm compare

docs.title: Auto-Switch on Directory Change
docs.text:
Enable automatic context switching when changing directories:

export TM_AUTO_SWITCH=1

When enabled, tm switch --quiet runs after each cd.

docs.title: Integration
docs.text:
• flow-cli - Integrated as the tm dispatcher
  • aiterm - Python CLI for rich terminal features
  • pick - Works with project picker for context

docs.title: Related Commands
docs.text: Command Purpose work <project> Start session (calls tm switch) finish End session dash Dashboard

docs.title: aiterm not found
docs.text:
# Check if installed
command -v ait

# Install
brew install data-wise/tap/aiterm
# or
pip install aiterm-dev

docs.title: Ghostty commands not working
docs.text:
# Check aiterm version
ait --version

# Ghostty support requires >= 0.3.9
brew upgrade aiterm

docs.title: Profile switching not working
docs.text:
• Profile switching only works in iTerm2
  • Ghostty uses themes instead: tm ghost theme <name>

docs.title: Related
docs.text:
• aiterm Documentation - Full aiterm docs
  • DISPATCHER-REFERENCE.md - All dispatchers
  • PyPI Package - aiterm on PyPI

Last Updated: 2025-12-30 Version: v4.4.0 Status: ✅ Fully implemented

docs.text:

docs.text:
Show all work:

Check your environment:

docs.title: 🔍 Workspace Audit Guide
docs.text:
Quick Start: Run ma for a complete daily health check

Last Updated: 2025-12-14 | Version: 1.0 | Source: zsh-claude-workflow v1.5.0

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Four new commands for maintaining workspace hygiene across all projects. Originally a standalone tool (workspace-auditor), now merged into zsh-claude-workflow for better integration.

Command Alias Purpose Frequency git-audit ga Find dirty/unpushed repos Daily file-audit fa Find large files (>50MB) Weekly activity-heat ah 7-day activity heatmap Daily morning-audit ma Full workspace check Daily

docs.title: 🔴 git-audit — Repository Health
docs.text: Scans ~/projects (depth 3) for repositories with uncommitted changes or unpushed commits.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
ga                  # Full audit with file lists
ga -q               # Quick summary only (recommended for daily use)
ga -a               # Show clean repos too
ga ~/code           # Audit specific directory

docs.title: Output Example
docs.text:
================
Git Repository Audit
================

⚠ research/mediation-planning — uncommitted changes
    M  R/analysis.R
    M  manuscript/draft.qmd
⚠ r-packages/active/medfit — uncommitted changes
    M  R/fit_model.R
    ?? tests/test-edge-cases.R
ℹ dev-tools/obsidian-cli-ops — unpushed commits
    + abc1234 feat: add new search command

Summary: 9 dirty, 1 unpushed
⚠ Consider a cleanup commit spree!

docs.title: Environment Variables
docs.text: Variable Default Description PROJECTS_DIR ~/projects Base directory to scan GIT_AUDIT_DEPTH 3 How deep to search for .git

docs.title: Integration with Workflow
docs.text:
# Morning routine
ga -q               # Quick check
# If issues found:
cd ~/projects/problem-repo
gs                  # git status
qcommit "WIP: save progress"  # Quick commit

docs.title: 🐘 file-audit — Large File Detection
docs.text: Finds files over 50MB that may need cleanup, archiving, or .gitignore entries.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
fa                  # Find files >50MB in ~/projects
fa -s 100M          # Find files >100MB
fa -s 10M ~/data    # Audit data folder with lower threshold

docs.title: Output Example
docs.text:
========================
Large File Audit (>50M)
========================

127M  r-packages/active/dataprep/inst/extdata/census.csv
 89M  research/mediation-planning/data/raw/survey_2024.rds
 67M  apps/examark/public/assets/video-tutorial.mp4

Found: 3 files
⚠ Consider archiving or adding to .gitignore

docs.title: Exclusions (Automatic)
docs.text:
These directories are always skipped:

  • .git/
  • node_modules/
  • .venv/
  • __pycache__/
  • renv/

docs.title: Color Coding
docs.text: Color File Type Yellow Data files (.csv, .parquet, .rds, .RData, .feather) Blue Archives (.zip, .tar, .gz, .7z) Magenta Media (.pdf, .png, .jpg, .mp4) White Other

docs.title: Action Items
docs.text:
When large files are found:

  1. Data files → Add to .gitignore, use Git LFS, or move to cloud storage
  2. Archives → Delete if temporary, or move to external storage
  3. Media → Consider compression or external hosting

docs.title: 🔥 activity-heat — Project Heatmap
docs.text: Visual representation of which projects have the most recent file activity.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
ah                  # Last 7 days, top 10 projects
ah -d 30            # Last 30 days
ah -n 5             # Top 5 only
ah -d 1             # Today only

docs.title: Output Example
docs.text:
==============================
Activity Heatmap (Last 7 Days)
==============================

 446 r-packages/active          ████████████████████
 197 apps/examark               ████████████████████
 170 dev-tools/zsh-claude-workflow ████████████████████
 144 r-packages/stable          ████████████████████
 141 r-packages/recovery        ████████████████████
  89 research/mediation-planning █████████████████
  45 quarto/manuscripts         █████████
  23 dev-tools/spacemacs-rstats ████

ℹ Today: 203 files modified

docs.title: Color Intensity
docs.text: Count Color Meaning 1-20 Green Normal activity 21-50 Yellow High activity 50+ Red Very high activity

docs.title: Use Cases
docs.text:
1. Identify active work — See where you've been focusing
  2. Find forgotten projects — Low activity may mean stalled work
  3. Prioritize reviews — High activity projects may need commits
  4. Time tracking — Correlate with work logs

docs.title: 🌅 morning-audit — Daily Health Check
docs.text: Orchestrates all audit commands into a single daily report.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
ma                  # Quick terminal output
ma -s               # Save markdown report to ~/logs/audit/
ma -o               # Save and open report (macOS)
ma -q               # Minimal output

docs.title: What It Runs
docs.text:
1. git-audit -q — Find dirty/unpushed repos
  2. activity-heat -n 5 — Top 5 active projects
  3. file-audit — Large files (in saved report only)
  4. obs audit — Obsidian vault structure (if obs command available)

docs.title: Report Location
docs.text: Reports are saved to: ~/logs/audit/audit_report_YYYY-MM-DD.md

docs.title: Sample Report
docs.text:
# Workspace Audit Report (2025-12-14)

Generated at: Sat Dec 14 09:45:00 PST 2025

## Git Status

⚠ research/mediation-planning — uncommitted changes

docs.title: Recommended Workflow
docs.text:
# Option 1: Quick terminal check (most common)
ma

# Option 2: Generate report for reference
ma -o

# Option 3: Add to shell startup for passive awareness
# In ~/.zshrc:
# ma -q 2>/dev/null  # Silent daily check on terminal open

docs.title: With obs (Obsidian CLI)
docs.text:
If you have obsidian-cli-ops installed, morning-audit automatically runs obs audit to check your Obsidian vault structure.

obs audit

docs.title: With Workflow Logging
docs.text:
Combine with workflow functions for comprehensive tracking:

# Start of day
ma                          # Check workspace health
startsession "morning"      # Start work session

# End of day
endsession                  # End work session

docs.title: With Claude Code
docs.text:
# Before starting Claude session
ga -q                       # Ensure clean git state
cc                          # Start Claude Code

# After Claude session

qcommit "feat: implement X" # Commit changes

docs.title: Default Paths
docs.text:
All commands default to scanning ~/projects. Override with environment variables:

# In ~/.zshrc
export PROJECTS_DIR="$HOME/code"           # Change base directory
export GIT_AUDIT_DEPTH=4                    # Search deeper
export FILE_AUDIT_SIZE="100M"               # Higher threshold
export ACTIVITY_HEAT_DAYS=14                # Longer lookback
export ACTIVITY_HEAT_TOP=15                 # More results
export AUDIT_LOG_DIR="$HOME/Documents/logs" # Different log location

docs.title: Adding to PATH
docs.text:
The commands are in ~/projects/dev-tools/zsh-claude-workflow/commands/. If not already in PATH:

# In ~/.zshrc
export PATH="$HOME/projects/dev-tools/zsh-claude-workflow/commands:$PATH"

docs.title: Aliases
docs.text:
Add to your shell for quick access:

# Already included in zsh-claude-workflow install.sh
alias ga='git-audit'
alias fa='file-audit'
alias ah='activity-heat'
alias ma='morning-audit'

docs.text: Task Command Time Daily health check ma ~5s Quick git status ga -q ~3s Find large files fa ~5s See active projects ah ~3s Generate report ma -o ~10s Deep audit (30 days) ah -d 30 ~5s

# Check PATH

# Re-run install

./install.sh
