docs.title: WT Dispatcher Reference
docs.text:
Git worktree management for parallel development

Location: lib/dispatchers/wt-dispatcher.zsh

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
wt                    # Navigate to worktrees folder
wt list               # List all worktrees
wt create feature/x   # Create worktree for branch
wt status             # Show health and disk usage

docs.title: Usage
docs.text: wt [command] [args]

docs.title: Key Insight
docs.text:
• Worktrees let you work on multiple branches simultaneously
  • Each worktree is a separate working directory
  • All share the same git history (efficient disk usage)
  • Organized under ~/.git-worktrees/<project>/

docs.title: Navigation
docs.text: Command Description wt Navigate to worktrees folder (~/.git-worktrees) wt list List all worktrees with their branches wt status Show health, disk usage, and merge status

docs.title: Creation
docs.text: Command Description wt create <branch> Create worktree for existing or new branch wt move Move current branch to its own worktree

docs.title: Cleanup
docs.text: Command Description wt remove <path> Remove a specific worktree wt clean Prune stale worktree references wt prune Comprehensive cleanup (merged branches)

docs.title: wt create
docs.text:
Create a worktree for a branch:

# For existing branch
wt create feature/auth
# → Creates ~/.git-worktrees/project/feature-auth/

# For new branch (auto-creates)
wt create feature/new-feature
# → Creates branch AND worktree

Behavior: - If branch exists → creates worktree pointing to it - If branch doesn't exist → creates new branch AND worktree - Uses project name from git root - Converts / to - in folder names

docs.title: wt move
docs.text:
Move current branch to its own worktree:

# On feature/auth branch
wt move
# → Creates worktree and shows path

Restrictions: - Cannot move main, master, or dev - Cannot move when in detached HEAD state

docs.title: wt status
docs.text:
Show comprehensive worktree health:

wt status

Output includes: - Branch name for each worktree - Status: 🏠 main, ✅ active, 🧹 merged, ⚠️ stale - Disk usage per worktree - Summary with counts - Cleanup suggestions

Sample output: 

🌳 Worktree Status
━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━

  BRANCH                              STATUS       SIZE     PATH
  ─────────────────────────────────── ──────────── ──────── ─────────────────
  main                                🏠 main      156M     ~/projects/flow-cli
  feature/add-tm-dispatcher           ✅ active    48M      ~/.git-worktrees/flow-cli/...
  feature/old-feature                 🧹 merged    32M      ~/.git-worktrees/flow-cli/...

Summary: 3 worktree(s) | 2 active | 1 merged | 0 stale

💡 Tip: Run wt prune to clean up merged worktrees

docs.title: wt prune
docs.text:
Comprehensive worktree cleanup:

wt prune              # Clean merged worktrees (with confirmation)
wt prune --branches   # Also delete merged branches
wt prune --force      # Skip confirmation
wt prune --dry-run    # Preview only

Options:

Option Short Description --branches -b Also delete the merged branches --force -f Skip confirmation prompts --dry-run -n Preview without making changes --help -h Show help

What it does: 1. Prunes stale worktree references 2. Finds worktrees for merged feature branches 3. Removes those worktrees (with confirmation) 4. Optionally deletes the merged branches

Safe by default: - Asks for confirmation before removing - Only targets merged feature/*, bugfix/*, hotfix/* - Never removes main, master, dev, develop - Never removes current branch

docs.title: wt clean
docs.text:
Simple cleanup (prunes stale references only):

wt clean
# → Runs: git worktree prune

Use this for quick cleanup. Use wt prune for comprehensive cleanup.

docs.title: wt remove
docs.text:
Remove a specific worktree:

wt remove ~/.git-worktrees/project/feature-x

Shows current worktrees if no path provided.

docs.title: Shortcuts
docs.text: Full Short Description list ls, l List worktrees create add, c Create worktree move mv Move current branch remove rm Remove worktree status st Show status

docs.title: Passthrough
docs.text:
Unknown commands pass through to git worktree:

wt lock <path>     # → git worktree lock <path>
wt unlock <path>   # → git worktree unlock <path>
wt repair          # → git worktree repair

docs.title: Worktree Directory
docs.text:
Set custom worktree storage location:

# Default
export FLOW_WORKTREE_DIR="$HOME/.git-worktrees"

# Custom
export FLOW_WORKTREE_DIR="$HOME/worktrees"

docs.title: Directory Structure
docs.text:
Worktrees are organized by project:

~/.git-worktrees/
├── flow-cli/
│   ├── feature-auth/
│   ├── feature-new-ui/
│   └── bugfix-issue-42/
├── aiterm/
│   └── feature-ghostty/
└── mediationverse/
    └── hotfix-urgent/

docs.title: Daily Workflow
docs.text:
# Start feature in worktree
wt create feature/auth
cd ~/.git-worktrees/flow-cli/feature-auth

# Work on it...
# When done, clean up
wt prune

docs.title: Parallel Development
docs.text:
# Create multiple worktrees
wt create feature/frontend
wt create feature/backend
wt create feature/tests

# Each in separate terminal
cd ~/.git-worktrees/project/feature-frontend
cd ~/.git-worktrees/project/feature-backend
cd ~/.git-worktrees/project/feature-tests

docs.title: Check Before Cleanup
docs.text:
# See what's there
wt status

# Preview cleanup
wt prune --dry-run

# Do the cleanup
wt prune --branches

docs.title: Move Existing Work
docs.text:
# On a feature branch in main repo
git checkout feature/something

# Move to worktree
wt move
# → Shows: cd ~/.git-worktrees/project/feature-something

docs.title: With CC Dispatcher
docs.text:
Launch Claude in a worktree:

cc wt feature/auth    # Claude in worktree
cc wt pick            # Pick worktree → Claude
cc wt yolo feature/x  # Worktree + YOLO mode

See CC-DISPATCHER-REFERENCE.md for details.

docs.title: With G Dispatcher
docs.text:
Clean branches after worktree cleanup:

# Clean worktrees
wt prune

# Or clean branches directly
g feature prune

docs.title: "Not in a git repository"
docs.text:
Worktree commands must be run from within a git repository.

cd ~/projects/my-project
wt create feature/x

docs.title: "Cannot move protected branch"
docs.text:
Main branches cannot be moved to worktrees:

wt move  # On main branch → Error

Switch to a feature branch first.

docs.title: Stale worktree references
docs.text:
If you manually deleted a worktree folder:

wt clean
# → Removes stale references

docs.title: Worktree path conflicts
docs.text:
If path already exists:

# Remove old worktree first
wt remove ~/.git-worktrees/project/feature-x

# Then create new
wt create feature/x

docs.title: Related
docs.text:
• DISPATCHER-REFERENCE.md - All dispatchers
  • CC-DISPATCHER-REFERENCE.md - Claude + worktrees
  • Tutorial: Worktrees - Step-by-step guide

Last Updated: 2025-12-30 Version: v4.3.0+ Status: ✅ Fully implemented

docs.title: Philosophy
docs.text: Just type zsh-clean and everything gets done. Zero decisions.

docs.title: Commands
docs.text: Command Description zsh-clean Do everything (archive junk + sync to GitHub) zsh-clean status Health check only zsh-clean undo Discard uncommitted changes zsh-clean test Run test suite zsh-clean help Show help

docs.title: Daily Maintenance (Just This!)
docs.text:
$ zsh-clean

═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
  🧹 ZSH Config Maintenance
═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

  1. Cleaning up...
  ✓ No junk to archive
  2. Syncing to GitHub...
  ✓ Committed changes
  ✓ Pushed to GitHub

───────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
  ✓ Done! Config is clean and backed up.

That's it. One command does everything:

  1. Archives any junk files (.bak, .tmp, etc.)
  2. Commits changes to git
  3. Pushes to GitHub

docs.title: Undo Changes
docs.text:
$ zsh-clean undo

═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
  ⏪ Undo Changes
═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

  Changes to discard:
    M zsh/functions/adhd-helpers.zsh

  ⚠  Discard these changes? [y/N] y
  ✓ Changes discarded

  Run 'source ~/.config/zsh/.zshrc' to reload

docs.title: Check Status
docs.text:
$ zsh-clean status

═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
  🩺 ZSH Configuration Health
═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

  📁 Config: /Users/dt/.config/zsh (1.5M)
  📦 Functions: 18 files
  ☁️  Git: synced
  🧹 Junk: none

docs.title: Recovery
docs.text: Scenario Solution Broke something just now zsh-clean undo Need older version git log --oneline → git checkout <hash> -- zsh/ Catastrophic loss Clone from GitHub or Google Drive

docs.title: Restore Specific File
docs.text:
cd ~/projects/dev-tools/flow-cli
git log --oneline zsh/functions/adhd-helpers.zsh
git checkout abc1234 -- zsh/functions/adhd-helpers.zsh
source ~/.config/zsh/.zshrc

docs.title: Backup Strategy
docs.text:
Method When History GitHub Every zsh-clean Full git history Google Drive Automatic ~30 days

No local tarballs needed — two cloud backups are enough.

docs.title: File Structure
docs.text:
~/projects/dev-tools/flow-cli/
├── zsh/                      # ← Config (symlinked from ~/.config/zsh)
│   ├── .zshrc
│   ├── .p10k.zsh
│   ├── functions/
│   │   └── zsh-clean.zsh     # This tool
│   ├── tests/
│   └── .archive/             # Junk files (local only)
├── docs/
└── README.md

docs.title: Tracked vs Ignored
docs.text:
Tracked (GitHub):

  • .zshrc, .p10k.zsh, .zsh_plugins.*
  • functions/*.zsh
  • tests/, help/

Ignored (local):

  • .archive/ — archived junk
  • .zcompdump*, .zsh_history, .zsh_sessions/
  • .zshrc.local — machine-specific

docs.title: SPEC: CI Optimization & Pick Worktree Fix
docs.text: Status: implemented Created: 2025-12-31 From Brainstorm: In-session analysis

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Two issues to address: 1. CI takes too long - PR tests taking 5+ minutes, goal is <5 minutes 2. pick wt not showing worktrees - PROJ_WORKTREE_DIR not configured

docs.title: Current State
docs.text: Job Time Notes Main branch CI ~31s Fast PR ZSH Tests 5+ min macOS tests slow PR macOS Tests 5+ min Duplicate coverage

docs.title: Root Causes
docs.text:
1. macOS runner slow startup - macOS runners take 30-60s just to start
  2. Duplicate test coverage - macOS runs same tests as Ubuntu
  3. Sequential test steps - Already optimized in latest commit
  4. Long-running optional tests - sync, AI features, etc.

docs.title: Quick Wins (< 30 min each)
docs.text: # Action Impact Effort ⚡1 Make macOS tests optional - Use continue-on-error: true for entire macOS job -3 min 5 min ⚡2 Remove macOS job entirely - ZSH is cross-platform, Ubuntu coverage sufficient -5 min 2 min ⚡3 Skip slow tests on PR - Only run full suite on main branch -2 min 10 min

docs.title: Medium Effort (1-2 hours)
docs.text: # Action Impact Effort 1 Matrix strategy with fail-fast - Run Ubuntu and macOS in parallel matrix -1 min 30 min 2 Cache mock project structure - Pre-build the mock dirs -30s 1 hr 3 Split critical vs optional - Fast critical path, slow optional path -2 min 1 hr

docs.title: Recommended Approach
docs.text:
Option A: Remove macOS job (Fastest) 

# Only keep zsh-tests job, remove macos-tests entirely
# ZSH is platform-agnostic, cross-platform stat already fixed

Option B: Make macOS non-blocking 

macos-tests:
  name: macOS Tests
  runs-on: macos-latest
  continue-on-error: true  # Don't block PR merge

Option C: Run macOS only on main 

macos-tests:
  if: github.ref == 'refs/heads/main'

docs.title: Root Cause
docs.text: PROJ_WORKTREE_DIR environment variable not set in user's shell.

docs.title: User Story
docs.text: As a user, when I run pick wt, I want to see my worktrees listed so I can quickly switch between them.

docs.title: Acceptance Criteria
docs.text:
• [ ] pick wt shows worktrees when PROJ_WORKTREE_DIR is configured
  • [ ] Clear error message when PROJ_WORKTREE_DIR is not set
  • [ ] Documentation explains how to configure worktree directory

docs.title: Fix
docs.text:
1. Add error message in pick.zsh: 

    if [[ "$category" == "wt" ]]; then
    if [[ -z "$PROJ_WORKTREE_DIR" ]]; then
        echo "Error: PROJ_WORKTREE_DIR not set"
        echo "Add to .zshrc: export PROJ_WORKTREE_DIR=~/projects/.worktrees"
        return 1
    fi
fi

  2. Update documentation:

  3. Add setup instructions to docs/getting-started/quick-start.md

  4. Add to docs/reference/PICK-REFERENCE.md

  5. User configuration: 

    # In ~/.zshrc
export PROJ_WORKTREE_DIR="$HOME/projects/.worktrees"

docs.title: Phase 1: CI Optimization (Immediate)
docs.text:
1. Remove or make macOS job optional
  2. Move optional tests to continue-on-error
  3. Verify PR CI completes in <3 minutes

docs.title: Phase 2: Pick Worktree Fix
docs.text:
1. Add error message for missing PROJ_WORKTREE_DIR
  2. Update documentation
  3. Test pick wt with configured directory

docs.title: Open Questions
docs.text:
1. Keep macOS tests at all? - Do we need platform-specific testing?
  2. Default worktree location? - Should we auto-detect or require config?

docs.title: Review Checklist
docs.text:
• [ ] CI completes in <5 minutes
  • [ ] pick wt shows helpful error when unconfigured
  • [ ] Documentation updated
  • [ ] All existing tests still pass

docs.title: History
docs.text: Date Change 2025-12-31 Initial spec from brainstorm

docs.title: SPEC: Worktree-Aware Pick
docs.text: Status: draft Created: 2025-12-30 From Brainstorm: BRAINSTORM-worktree-aware-pick-2025-12-30.md

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Enhance the pick command to recognize git worktrees as a first-class category (wt) alongside existing categories (r, dev, teach, rs, q, app). This provides unified project navigation where parallel workspaces are instantly accessible with session status visibility and smart keybindings.

docs.title: Primary User Story
docs.text: As a developer using multiple git worktrees for parallel feature work I want to navigate to worktrees using the same pick interface I use for projects So that I have a unified, fast way to switch contexts without remembering different commands

docs.title: Acceptance Criteria
docs.text:
• [ ] pick wt lists all worktrees across all projects in ~/.git-worktrees/
  • [ ] pick wt <project> filters to a specific project's worktrees
  • [ ] Worktrees display as project (branch) 🌳 wt in the picker
  • [ ] Session status indicator shows: 🟢 recent (< 24h) / 🟡 old / ⚪ none + time
  • [ ] cd to worktree displays git status (branch, modified, untracked counts)
  • [ ] Resume feature tracks worktrees (unified session file)
  • [ ] Ctrl-W toggles between projects view and worktrees view
  • [ ] Ctrl-D deletes worktree from picker (with confirmation)
  • [ ] Ctrl-R resumes Claude session if worktree has one
  • [ ] Ctrl-O launches Claude Code (cc) in selected directory
  • [ ] Ctrl-Y launches Claude Code YOLO (ccy) in selected directory
  • [ ] --no-claude flag disables Ctrl-O/Ctrl-Y (for use by cc dispatcher)
  • [ ] pickwt alias added for quick access

docs.title: 2. Quick Worktree Cleanup
docs.text:
As a developer who accumulates many worktrees I want to delete stale worktrees directly from the picker So that I can clean up without switching context

Acceptance Criteria: - [ ] Ctrl-D in picker triggers worktree deletion - [ ] Confirmation prompt before deletion (unless --force) - [ ] List refreshes after successful deletion

docs.title: 3. Claude Session Resumption
docs.text:
As a developer working on features across multiple worktrees I want to see which worktrees have active Claude sessions So that I can resume work without losing context

Acceptance Criteria: - [ ] 🟢 indicator for sessions < 24h old - [ ] 🟡 indicator for older sessions - [ ] ⚪ no indicator if no .claude/ directory - [ ] Time displayed (e.g., "2h ago", "3d ago") - [ ] Ctrl-R triggers claude --resume in selected worktree

docs.title: 4. Quick Claude Launch from Picker
docs.text:
As a developer who frequently uses Claude Code I want to launch Claude directly from the picker So that I can start coding immediately without extra commands

Acceptance Criteria: - [ ] Ctrl-O navigates to selection AND launches claude --permission-mode acceptEdits - [ ] Ctrl-Y navigates to selection AND launches claude --dangerously-skip-permissions - [ ] Works for both projects and worktrees - [ ] Session is saved before Claude launches

docs.title: API Design
docs.text: N/A - No API changes; this is a ZSH function enhancement.

docs.title: Data Models
docs.text:
Session File Enhancement (~/.current-project-session):

# Current format:
name|path|timestamp

# Enhanced format:
name|path|timestamp|type
# type = "project" | "worktree"

# Example:
live-editor-enhancements|~/.git-worktrees/scribe/live-editor-enhancements|1735600000|worktree
flow-cli|~/projects/dev-tools/flow-cli|1735599000|project

Backward Compatibility: Missing type field defaults to "project"

docs.title: Dependencies
docs.text: Dependency Required Purpose fzf Yes Interactive picker git Yes Worktree management stat Yes Session age calculation bat No Enhanced status display

docs.title: User Flow
docs.text:
User invokes pick wt
        │
        ▼
┌──────────────────────────────────┐
│ Scan ~/.git-worktrees/*/         │
│ for all worktree directories     │
└──────────────────────────────────┘
        │
        ▼
┌──────────────────────────────────┐
│ For each worktree:               │
│ - Get project name (parent dir)  │
│ - Get branch name (folder name)  │
│ - Check .claude/ for session     │
│ - Format as list entry           │
└──────────────────────────────────┘
        │
        ▼
┌──────────────────────────────────┐
│ Display in fzf with keybindings  │
│ User selects worktree            │
└──────────────────────────────────┘
        │
        ├──[Enter]─────────────────▶ cd + show status
        ├──[Ctrl-O]────────────────▶ cd + claude (cc)
        ├──[Ctrl-Y]────────────────▶ cd + claude YOLO (ccy)
        ├──[Ctrl-R]────────────────▶ cd + claude --resume
        ├──[Ctrl-W]────────────────▶ Toggle to projects view
        ├──[Ctrl-D]────────────────▶ Delete worktree (confirm)
        └──[Ctrl-C]────────────────▶ Cancel

docs.title: Wireframes (ASCII)
docs.text:
Worktree List View: 

╔════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════╗
║  🌳 WORKTREE PICKER                                        ║
╚════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════╝

  💡 Showing all worktrees from ~/.git-worktrees/
  [Enter] cd  │  [^O] cc  │  [^Y] ccy  │  [^R] Resume  │  [^W] Projects

> scribe (live-editor-enh)    🌳 wt  🟢 2h ago
  scribe (swiftui-native)     🌳 wt  🟡 old
  scribe (wonderful-wilson)   🌳 wt  ⚪
  medfit (hardcore-cerf)      🌳 wt  ⚪
  rmediation (condesc-shamir) 🌳 wt  🟡 old

  5/5 ───────────────────────────────────────────────────────

After Navigation: 

  📂 Changed to: ~/.git-worktrees/scribe/live-editor-enhancements

  🌿 Branch: live-editor-enhancements
  📊 Status: 3 modified, 1 untracked

docs.title: Accessibility Checklist
docs.text:
• [x] Keyboard-only navigation via fzf
  • [x] Clear visual indicators (icons + colors)
  • [x] Consistent with existing pick interface
  • [x] Help text visible in picker header
  • [ ] Screen reader support (fzf limitation)

docs.title: Open Questions
docs.text:
1. Performance: With 20+ worktrees, should session status be cached or computed on-demand?

  2. Recommendation: Compute on-demand; worktree count typically < 10

  3. Naming collision: What if project name matches worktree branch name?

  4. Recommendation: Always show project (branch) format, no ambiguity

  5. Ordering: How should worktrees sort?

  6. Recommendation: By project name, then by recency within project

  7. Stale worktrees: Should stale/orphaned worktrees be hidden?

  8. Recommendation: Show with ⚠️ indicator, don't hide

  9. RESOLVED: Claude keybinding conflict with cc pick

  10. Problem: cc pick calls pick && claude, so if pick has Ctrl-O/Ctrl-Y, double launch occurs
  11. Solution: Add --no-claude flag to pick; cc passes this flag
  12. See "Claude Keybinding Context Awareness" section below

docs.title: Review Checklist
docs.text:
• [ ] Primary user story is clear and testable
  • [ ] All acceptance criteria are measurable
  • [ ] Architecture diagram matches implementation plan
  • [ ] Data model changes are backward compatible
  • [ ] Keybindings don't conflict with existing fzf bindings
  • [ ] Documentation locations identified
  • [ ] Test cases defined (see below)

docs.title: Key Implementation Details
docs.text:
1. Special category handling: The wt category needs custom logic in _proj_list_all() since it scans $FLOW_WORKTREE_DIR instead of $PROJ_BASE.

  2. Session status calculation: Use find with -mtime to check for recent .claude/*.json files.

  3. Keybinding gotchas:

  4. Ctrl-C cannot be rebound (always cancels)
  5. Ctrl-W may conflict on some terminals (word delete)
  6. Ctrl-O opens file in some terminals (but usually safe in fzf)
  7. Ctrl-Y is paste in some terminals (but usually safe in fzf)
  8. Use --bind with reload for toggle functionality
  9. Use execute-silent + accept for actions that exit picker

docs.title: Claude Keybinding Context Awareness
docs.text:
Problem: cc pick and cc yolo pick already launch Claude after pick completes: 

# In cc-dispatcher.zsh:
pick "$@" && claude --permission-mode acceptEdits  # cc pick
pick "$@" && claude --dangerously-skip-permissions # cc yolo pick

If pick has Ctrl-O/Ctrl-Y keybindings, pressing them would cause double Claude launch.

Solution: Add --no-claude flag to pick that disables Ctrl-O/Ctrl-Y keybindings.

# pick() changes:
pick() {
    local no_claude_keys=0

    # Parse --no-claude flag
    if [[ "$1" == "--no-claude" ]]; then
        no_claude_keys=1
        shift
    fi

    # ... existing argument parsing ...

    # Build fzf keybindings conditionally
    local claude_bindings=""
    if [[ $no_claude_keys -eq 0 ]]; then
        claude_bindings='--bind=ctrl-o:execute-silent(echo cc > '$action_file')+accept'
        claude_bindings+=' --bind=ctrl-y:execute-silent(echo ccy > '$action_file')+accept'
    fi

    # ... fzf call with $claude_bindings ...
}

# cc-dispatcher.zsh changes:
# Before:
pick "$@" && claude --permission-mode acceptEdits

# After:
pick --no-claude "$@" && claude --permission-mode acceptEdits

Behavior Matrix:

Invocation Ctrl-O/Ctrl-Y Result pick Enabled cd + launch Claude pick wt Enabled cd + launch Claude cc pick Disabled cd only (cc handles Claude) cc yolo pick Disabled cd only (cc handles Claude) cc wt pick Disabled cd only (cc handles Claude)

Header changes based on context:

# Normal pick:
[Enter] cd  │  [^O] cc  │  [^Y] ccy  │  [^R] Resume

# pick --no-claude (called from cc):
[Enter] cd  │  [^S] Status  │  [^L] Log  │  [^W] Worktrees
  1. Format string: Use printf with fixed widths for alignment: 
    printf "%-25s %-5s %-3s %s\n" "$name" "$icon" "$type" "$session"

docs.title: Test Cases
docs.text: Test Input Expected List all worktrees pick wt Shows all worktrees from ~/.git-worktrees Filter by project pick wt scribe Shows only scribe's worktrees No worktrees pick wt (empty dir) Shows "No worktrees found" message Direct jump pick live-editor Navigates to matching worktree Session indicator worktree with .claude/ Shows 🟢/🟡 with time Delete worktree Ctrl-D on selection Confirms and removes Toggle view Ctrl-W in picker Switches to project list Launch Claude Ctrl-O on selection cd + launches claude --permission-mode acceptEdits Launch Claude YOLO Ctrl-Y on selection cd + launches claude --dangerously-skip-permissions Resume Claude Ctrl-R on selection cd + launches claude --resume No Claude keys pick --no-claude Ctrl-O/Ctrl-Y bindings not present cc pick integration cc pick pick called with --no-claude, Claude launched by cc

docs.title: 🐕 Interactive Dog Feeding Test
docs.text: The most fun way to test your flow-cli installation!

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
This gamified test validates your flow-cli setup by having you "feed a virtual dog" through confirming that commands produce expected output. The test runs each command, shows you comprehensive expected patterns, displays the actual output, and asks you to confirm if they match. Each successful confirmation earns you food to feed the dog and increases its happiness level.

Latest Version: Completely revised with comprehensive expected patterns that match flow-cli's rich, elaborate outputs (Dec 25, 2025)

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
cd /path/to/flow-cli
./tests/interactive-dog-feeding.zsh

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
For each test task:

  1. 📋 Shows the command that will run
  2. 👀 Shows comprehensive expected output patterns to look for
  3. ▶️ Runs the command and displays actual output
  4. ❓ Asks you to confirm if actual matches expected
  5. ✅ Feeds the dog if you confirm (or 😢 disappoints if not)

docs.title: What Makes This Test Special
docs.text:
Comprehensive Expected Patterns: Unlike typical tests, this shows you the FULL structure to expect:

  • Complete box borders and separators
  • All headers and sections
  • Progress bars and indicators
  • Nested structures and spacing
  • Even blank lines are documented!

Example: Dashboard test shows 16 detailed patterns covering borders, headers, sections, progress bars, and footer - matching the rich output exactly.

docs.title: What It Tests
docs.text:
The dog feeding test validates 7 core flow-cli features:

  1. Plugin Loading - Ensures flow.plugin.zsh loads correctly
  2. Dashboard Display - Tests dash command output format
  3. Work Session Start - Tests work <project> command and display
  4. Idea Capture - Tests catch <idea> command and confirmation
  5. Win Logging - Tests win <accomplishment> command
  6. Active Session Display - Verifies session shows in dashboard
  7. ADHD Helper - Tests js (just start) command
  8. Session Cleanup - Tests finish command completes cleanly

docs.title: Features
docs.text:
• 🐕 Virtual Dog - Feed and make happy by passing tests
  • 🥩 Food Rewards - Earn food for each successful task
  • ⭐ Star Rating System - Get 1-5 stars based on performance
  • 😊 Happiness Meter - Track dog happiness (0-100%)
  • 🎮 Gamification - ADHD-friendly, engaging test experience
  • 📊 Progress Tracking - See X/7 tasks completed
  • 🎨 Colorful UI - Beautiful terminal output with emojis

docs.title: Grading System
docs.text: Tasks Completed Grade Stars Dog Status 7/7 PERFECT! ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐ ECSTATIC! 😊⭐ 5-6 EXCELLENT! ⭐⭐⭐⭐ Very happy! 😊 3-4 GOOD ⭐⭐⭐ Satisfied 🤔 0-2 NEEDS WORK ⭐ Still hungry 😢

docs.title: Sample Output
docs.text:
╔════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════╗
║  🐕  INTERACTIVE DOG FEEDING TEST  🐕                     ║
╚════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════╝

Welcome to the Interactive Dog Feeding Test!

Your mission: Feed the dog by confirming flow-cli works

How it works:
  1. We show you what to expect
  2. We run a command
  3. You confirm the output matches
  4. The dog gets fed if you confirm 🥩

Each successful confirmation makes the dog happier! 😊

═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
Task: Show Project Dashboard
═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

Command to run:
  $ dash

╭─ Expected Output ────────────────────────────────────────╮
│ Look for these patterns:
╰──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────╯
  ╭── or ╔══ (border characters)
  🌊 FLOW DASHBOARD
  Date and time in header
  Project names listed

👀 Watch carefully as the command runs...

╭─ Actual Output ──────────────────────────────────────────╮
╭──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────╮
│  🌊 FLOW DASHBOARD              Dec 25, 2025  🕐 20:24   │
╰──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────╯
... (dashboard content) ...
╰──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────╯

❓ Does the output match the expected patterns?
(y/n, default: y)
> y

✅ Great! Test passed!

The dog sees all your projects! 😊
🥩 Fed the dog! 😊

docs.title: Exit Codes
docs.text:
• 0 - All tests passed (7/7)
  • 1 - Some tests failed (0-6/7)

docs.title: 1. After Fresh Installation
docs.text:
# Install flow-cli
git clone https://github.com/Data-Wise/flow-cli.git
cd flow-cli

# Validate everything works
./tests/interactive-dog-feeding.zsh

docs.title: 2. After Major Refactor
docs.text:
# Made big changes? Feed the dog!
./tests/interactive-dog-feeding.zsh

docs.title: 3. Teaching New Users
docs.text:
# Perfect onboarding experience
# Shows all major features in fun way
./tests/interactive-dog-feeding.zsh

docs.title: 4. CI/CD Integration
docs.text:
# Non-interactive mode (auto-feeds with 'yes')
yes '' | ./tests/interactive-dog-feeding.zsh

# Check exit code
echo $?  # 0 = success, 1 = failure

docs.title: ADHD-Friendly Design
docs.text:
This test is specifically designed for ADHD developers:

  • ✅ Show, Don't Tell - Shows expected output before running
  • ✅ Immediate Feedback - See actual results right after
  • ✅ Dopamine Hits - Stars and happy emojis for confirmations
  • ✅ Visual Progress - Clear X/7 task counter
  • ✅ Gamification - Feeding dog is more fun than "running tests"
  • ✅ Short Tasks - Each task is quick and focused
  • ✅ Clear Expectations - You know exactly what to look for
  • ✅ Simple Decisions - Just confirm yes/no
  • ✅ Positive Reinforcement - Dog gets happier with each confirmation
  • ✅ Forgiving - Can continue even if one test fails

docs.title: File Locations
docs.text:
• Test Script: tests/interactive-dog-feeding.zsh
  • Session File: ~/.local/share/flow/.current-session
  • Captures: ~/.local/share/flow/captures/
  • Wins Log: ~/.wins/

docs.title: Dependencies
docs.text:
• ZSH shell
  • flow-cli plugin
  • Standard terminal with emoji support

docs.title: Variables Tracked
docs.text:
HUNGER=100          # Decreases as you feed (0-100)
HAPPINESS=50        # Increases with success (0-100)
TASKS_COMPLETED=0   # Increments per task (0-7)
TOTAL_TASKS=7       # Fixed at 7

docs.title: Dog is Sad / Tests Fail
docs.text:
Check plugin loads:

source ~/projects/dev-tools/flow-cli/flow.plugin.zsh
type dash  # Should show function

Check session directory:

ls -la ~/.local/share/flow/

Run individual commands:

dash
work flow-cli
catch "test idea"
finish

docs.title: No Emoji Support
docs.text:
If emojis don't display:

  1. Use a modern terminal (iTerm2, Ghostty, Warp)
  2. Install a font with emoji support
  3. Set LANG=en_US.UTF-8

docs.title: Contributing
docs.text:
Want to add more tasks? Edit the script and:

  1. Increment TOTAL_TASKS
  2. Add a new task section following the pattern
  3. Use run_test helper function
  4. Give appropriate food reward (5-20 points)

Example:

run_test \
    "New Feature Test" \
    "your-command 2>&1" \
    "${GREEN}Success message ${STAR}${NC}" \
    15  # Food reward

docs.text: Date: 2025-12-25 Features: Dashboard UI, Session Tracking, Interactive Mode

docs.text:
The most fun way to test flow-cli!

./tests/interactive-dog-feeding.zsh

This gamified test validates:

  • Plugin loading
  • Dashboard display (with comprehensive pattern matching)
  • Session management (work/finish)
  • Capture commands (catch/win)
  • ADHD helpers (js)
  • Active session display
  • User interactive validation

Features:

  • 🐕 Feed a virtual dog by confirming commands work
  • 👀 Shows comprehensive expected patterns (60+ patterns total!)
  • ✅ Interactive y/n validation

Latest Update (Dec 25, 2025):

  • ✅ Added comprehensive expected patterns for all 7 tests

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
# Reload the plugin
source ~/.config/zsh/.zshenv
# OR
source ~/projects/dev-tools/flow-cli/flow.plugin.zsh

docs.title: Test 1: Basic Dashboard
docs.text:
Goal: Verify dashboard displays correctly with all sections

dash

Expected Output:

  • [ ] Header shows date and current time (🕐)
  • [ ] "Today:" stats row visible
  • [ ] "ACTIVE NOW" section shows flow-cli (if session active)
  • [ ] "QUICK ACCESS" shows 5 projects with active (🟢) first
  • [ ] "BY CATEGORY" shows progress bars and "X active / Y" format
  • [ ] Footer with tips visible

Screenshot the output for reference.

docs.title: Test 2: Category Expansion
docs.text:
Goal: Verify category drill-down works

dash dev

Expected Output:

  • [ ] Header shows "🔧 DEV-TOOLS"
  • [ ] Active projects (🟢) listed first
  • [ ] Each project shows progress bar (████░░)
  • [ ] Focus text shown below project name
  • [ ] Footer says "← 'dash' to return to summary"

Try other categories:

dash r          # R packages
dash research   # Research projects
dash teach      # Teaching

docs.title: 3a: Check Current Session
docs.text:
# View session file directly
cat ~/.local/share/flow/.current-session

Expected: Shows project, start timestamp, date

docs.title: 3b: End Current Session
docs.text:
finish "testing session tracking"

Expected Output:

  • [ ] Shows "Session ended: Xm" (duration)
  • [ ] Session file deleted

Verify:

cat ~/.local/share/flow/.current-session
# Should say: No such file or directory

docs.title: 3c: Start New Session
docs.text:
work atlas

Expected:

  • [ ] Shows project context (📗 atlas)
  • [ ] Status info displayed
  • [ ] Session file created

Verify:

cat ~/.local/share/flow/.current-session
# Should show: project=atlas, start=..., date=...

docs.title: 3d: Check Dashboard Shows Active Session
docs.text:
dash

Expected:

  • [ ] "ACTIVE NOW" section shows atlas
  • [ ] Elapsed time displayed (⏱ Xm)

docs.title: Test 4: Interactive Mode
docs.text:
Goal: Test fzf-based project picker

dash -i

Expected:

  • [ ] fzf picker opens
  • [ ] Projects listed with icons (🔧📦🔬🎓)
  • [ ] Status icons visible (🟢🟡⚪)
  • [ ] Preview pane shows .STATUS content on right
  • [ ] Header shows keybindings

Actions to test:

  1. [ ] Arrow keys - Navigate up/down
  2. [ ] Type - Filter projects (try typing "med")
  3. [ ] Enter - Select project (should run work)
  4. [ ] Esc - Cancel without action
  5. [ ] Ctrl-C - Cancel

Note: Ctrl-D was intended for category expansion but may not work in all fzf versions.

docs.title: Test 5: Dual Format Parsing
docs.text: Goal: Verify both .STATUS formats are parsed

docs.title: 5a: Markdown Format (dev-tools projects)
docs.text:
head -5 ~/projects/dev-tools/flow-cli/.STATUS

Expected: Uses ## Status: format

docs.title: 5b: YAML Format (research projects)
docs.text:
head -5 ~/projects/research/collider/.STATUS

Expected: Uses status: format (lowercase, no ##)

docs.title: 5c: Dashboard Shows Both
docs.text:
dash research

Expected:

  • [ ] Research projects show correct status icons
  • [ ] Progress bars display (from progress: field)
  • [ ] Focus text shown (from next: field)

docs.title: 6a: Complete Multiple Sessions
docs.text:
# End current session
finish "session 1"

# Start and end a quick session
work mcp-servers
sleep 2
finish "session 2"

# Start another
work flow-cli
sleep 2
finish "session 3"

docs.title: 6b: Check Worklog
docs.text:
tail -10 ~/.local/share/flow/worklog

Expected: Each END line shows duration (e.g., "END 0m")

docs.title: 6c: Dashboard Shows Accumulated Time
docs.text:
dash

Expected:

  • [ ] "Today: X sessions" count is correct
  • [ ] "⏱ Xm" shows total time (sum of sessions)

docs.title: 7a: No Active Session
docs.text:
# Make sure no session is active
finish 2>/dev/null
dash

Expected:

  • [ ] No "ACTIVE NOW" section displayed
  • [ ] Dashboard still works

docs.title: 7b: Project Without .STATUS
docs.text:
dash dev

Look for projects with ⚪ icon - these have no .STATUS file

Expected:

  • [ ] Shows ⚪ icon (unknown status)
  • [ ] No progress bar
  • [ ] No focus text

docs.title: 7c: Work on Project Without .STATUS
docs.text:
work zsh-claude-workflow

Expected:

  • [ ] Session starts successfully
  • [ ] Basic context shown (no status info)

docs.title: Test 8: Aliases
docs.text:
# Short alias for dash
d

# Interactive alias
di

Expected: Both work as shortcuts

docs.title: Test 9: Help
docs.text:
dash --help

Expected:

  • [ ] Shows usage info
  • [ ] Lists all options (-a, -i, -f, -h)
  • [ ] Shows category list
  • [ ] Shows legend for status icons

docs.text: Test Pass Fail Notes 1. Basic Dashboard 2. Category Expansion 3. Session Tracking 4. Interactive Mode 5. Dual Format Parsing 6. Time Accumulation 7. Edge Cases 8. Aliases 9. Help

docs.text:

finish "testing complete"

# Verify clean state
dash

docs.title: Testing Guide
docs.text: Comprehensive testing documentation for flow-cli's pure ZSH test suite.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: flow-cli uses a pure ZSH testing framework with 150+ tests covering all 8 dispatchers, core commands, and integration scenarios.

docs.title: Test Philosophy
docs.text:
1. Pure ZSH: No external dependencies (no Jest, no Node.js)
  2. Fast Feedback: Tests run in seconds
  3. CI Integration: All tests run on every PR (Ubuntu + macOS)
  4. ADHD-Friendly: Interactive "dog feeding" test for manual validation

docs.title: Current Status (v4.4.3)
docs.text: Category Tests Files Status Dispatcher Tests 85+ 8 ✅ All in CI Core Command Tests 40+ 4 ✅ Passing Integration Tests 30+ 3 ✅ Passing Interactive Tests 2 2 Manual

Dispatcher Test File Tests CI Status cc test-cc-dispatcher.zsh 24 ✅ Required g test-g-feature.zsh 14 ✅ Required wt test-wt-dispatcher.zsh 17 ✅ Required r test-r-dispatcher.zsh 16 ✅ Required qu test-qu-dispatcher.zsh 17 ✅ Required mcp test-mcp-dispatcher.zsh 21 ✅ Required tm test-tm-dispatcher.zsh 19 ⚠️ Optional* obs test-obs-dispatcher.zsh 12 ✅ Required

*TM tests require aiterm, which may not be installed on CI runners.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
# Run a specific dispatcher test
zsh tests/test-cc-dispatcher.zsh

# Run all dispatcher tests
for f in tests/test-*-dispatcher.zsh; do zsh "$f"; done

# Interactive validation (recommended for first-time setup)
./tests/interactive-dog-feeding.zsh

docs.title: Automated CLI Tests
docs.text: bash tests/cli/automated-tests.sh

docs.title: Helper Functions
docs.text: Function Purpose log_test "description" Print test name pass Mark test passed, increment counter fail "reason" Mark test failed with reason setup Initialize test environment

docs.title: Test Template
docs.text:
#!/usr/bin/env zsh
# Test script for [component]

# Framework (copy from existing test)
TESTS_PASSED=0
TESTS_FAILED=0
# ... colors, pass/fail functions

# Setup
setup() {
    local project_root="${0:A:h:h}"
    source "$project_root/lib/dispatchers/my-dispatcher.zsh"
}

# Tests
test_function_exists() {
    log_test "my_function is defined"
    if typeset -f my_function > /dev/null; then
        pass
    else
        fail "my_function not defined"
    fi
}

test_help_output() {
    log_test "help shows commands"
    local output=$(my_command help 2>&1)
    if [[ "$output" == *"Commands:"* ]]; then
        pass
    else
        fail "Commands section not found"
    fi
}

test_error_handling() {
    log_test "invalid input shows error"
    local output=$(my_command invalid 2>&1)
    if [[ "$output" == *"Unknown"* ]] || [[ "$output" == *"Error"* ]]; then
        pass
    else
        fail "Error message not shown"
    fi
}

# Run
setup
test_function_exists
test_help_output
test_error_handling

# Summary
echo ""
echo "════════════════════════════════════════"
echo "Summary"
echo "────────────────────────────────────────"
echo "  Passed: ${GREEN}$TESTS_PASSED${NC}"
echo "  Failed: ${RED}$TESTS_FAILED${NC}"

[[ $TESTS_FAILED -eq 0 ]] && echo "${GREEN}✓ All tests passed!${NC}" || echo "${RED}✗ Some tests failed${NC}"
exit $TESTS_FAILED

docs.title: Test Categories
docs.text:
1. Function Existence - Verify functions are defined
  2. Help Output - Verify help shows expected sections
  3. Command Behavior - Verify commands produce expected output
  4. Error Handling - Verify invalid input is handled gracefully
  5. Integration - Verify components work together

docs.title: GitHub Actions Workflow
docs.text: Tests run automatically on: - Every push to main or dev branches - Every pull request

docs.title: Platforms
docs.text: Platform Job Name Tests Ubuntu ZSH Plugin Tests All 8 dispatchers + core macOS macOS Tests All 8 dispatchers + core

docs.title: CI Configuration
docs.text:
# .github/workflows/test.yml
name: CI Tests

on:
  push:
    branches: [main, dev]
  pull_request:
    branches: [main, dev]

jobs:
  zsh-tests:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v6
      - name: Install zsh
        run: sudo apt-get update && sudo apt-get install -y zsh
      - name: Run dispatcher tests
        run: zsh ./tests/test-cc-dispatcher.zsh
      # ... more test steps

docs.title: Optional Tests
docs.text:
Some tests use continue-on-error: true:

Test Reason TM dispatcher Requires aiterm (external tool) AI features Requires API keys Sync tests Requires specific environment

docs.title: Dog Feeding Test 🐕
docs.text:
The fastest way to validate your installation:

./tests/interactive-dog-feeding.zsh

Features: - Shows expected output for each command - Runs command and displays actual output - Asks you to confirm if they match - Feeds a virtual dog for each success - Earn 1-5 stars based on performance

Perfect for: - First-time installation validation - After major refactoring - Teaching new users - Making testing fun!

docs.title: Manual Validation
docs.text:
# Quick smoke test
cc help        # Should show Claude Code help
g help         # Should show git workflow help
mcp            # Should list MCP servers
r help         # Should show R package help

docs.title: "Cannot find project root"
docs.text:
Run tests from the project directory:

cd ~/projects/dev-tools/flow-cli
zsh tests/test-cc-dispatcher.zsh

docs.title: "Function not defined"
docs.text:
Ensure the dispatcher is sourced:

source lib/dispatchers/cc-dispatcher.zsh

docs.title: Tests pass locally but fail in CI
docs.text:
Check if the test requires: - External tools (aiterm, obs, etc.) - Specific environment variables - Mock project structure

CI creates mock directories in ~/projects/ - your test may need adjustment.

docs.title: Adding Tests to CI
docs.text:
When adding a new dispatcher:

  1. Create test file: tests/test-<name>-dispatcher.zsh
  2. Add to Ubuntu job in .github/workflows/test.yml: 
    - name: Run <name> dispatcher tests
  run: |
    cd ~/projects/dev-tools/flow-cli
    zsh ./tests/test-<name>-dispatcher.zsh
  3. Add to macOS job (combined or separate step)
  4. Use continue-on-error: true if test requires external tools

docs.text:
The workflow includes performance tracking:

## 📊 ZSH Tests Performance

| Metric | Value |
|--------|-------|
| Total Duration | 28s |
| Platform | Ubuntu |

### Expected Baselines
- Plugin source: <150ms
- Help commands: <200ms
- Total CI job: <120s

docs.title: Related Documentation
docs.text:
• COMMAND-QUICK-REFERENCE.md - Command reference
  • DISPATCHER-REFERENCE.md - Dispatcher documentation
  • CONTRIBUTING.md - Contribution guidelines

Last Updated: 2025-12-30 Test Count: 150+ tests Version: v4.4.3

docs.title: Tutorial: Your First Flow Session
docs.text:
What you'll build: Track and complete your first focused work session using Flow CLI

Time: ~15 minutes | Level: Beginner

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
Before starting, you should:

  • [ ] Have Flow CLI installed (~/.config/zsh/ directory exists)
  • [ ] Have at least one project in ~/projects/
  • [ ] Know how to use terminal and ZSH

Verify your setup:

# Check Flow CLI is installed
ls ~/.config/zsh/functions/adhd-helpers.zsh

# Check you have projects
ls ~/projects/

docs.title: What You'll Learn
docs.text:
By the end of this tutorial, you will:

  1. Start a focused work session on a project
  2. Track your progress during the session
  3. Use project context commands
  4. End the session and save your work

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Flow CLI helps you stay focused by tracking work sessions. Here's the workflow:

┌────────────────┐     ┌────────────────┐     ┌────────────────┐
│  Pick Project  │ --> │   Work on It   │ --> │  End Session   │
│  (just-start)  │     │   (commands)   │     │   (finish)     │
└────────────────┘     └────────────────┘     └────────────────┘

docs.title: Step 1.1: Check What's Available
docs.text:
Let's see what projects you can work on:

dash

What happened: You see a dashboard showing all your projects organized by status (Active, Ready, Paused, Blocked).

Example output:

╭─────────────────────────────────────────────╮
│ 🎯 YOUR WORK DASHBOARD                      │
╰─────────────────────────────────────────────╯

🔥 ACTIVE NOW (2):
  📦 flow-cli [P0] 95% - Documentation improvements
  📚 stat-440 [P1] 60% - Grade assignments

📋 READY TO START (1):
  📊 research-project [P2] 20% - Literature review

docs.title: Step 1.2: Let Flow Pick For You
docs.text:
Instead of deciding, let Flow choose based on priority:

just-start

What happened: Flow automatically selects your highest-priority active project and shows you the details:

🎲 Finding your next task...

┌─────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│ 🎯 DECISION MADE FOR YOU                    │
├─────────────────────────────────────────────┤
│ Project: 📦 flow-cli                        │
│ Type:    dev-tools                          │
│ Reason:  P0 priority (critical)             │
│ Next:    Documentation improvements         │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────┘

💡 Quick actions:
   work .        = Start working
   status .      = Update status
   dash          = See all projects

📁 /Users/dt/projects/dev-tools/flow-cli

Note: Flow picks based on: P0 active → P1 active → any active → most recent

docs.title: Step 1.3: Start Working
docs.text:
Now open the project in your editor:

work .

What happened: Flow detects the project type and opens the appropriate editor (VS Code, RStudio, Emacs, etc.).

docs.title: Checkpoint
docs.text:
At this point, you should have:

  • [x] Viewed your dashboard
  • [x] Let Flow pick a project
  • [x] Opened the project in your editor

Verify:

pwd
# Expected: You're in the project directory

docs.title: Step 2.1: Start a Timed Session
docs.text:
Now set a focus timer to stay on track:

f25

What happened: A 25-minute Pomodoro timer starts. Your terminal shows a countdown.

Example output:

🍅 Pomodoro Timer Started!
⏱️  25:00 remaining...

[Terminal shows countdown in prompt]

Tip: Use f50 for a 50-minute deep work session instead

docs.title: Step 2.2: Check Your Context
docs.text:
If you forget what you're working on:

why

What happened: Shows your current project context:

📍 CURRENT CONTEXT

Project:  flow-cli
Type:     dev-tools
Location: /Users/dt/projects/dev-tools/flow-cli
Status:   ACTIVE (P0)
Task:     Documentation improvements
Progress: 95%

Active since: 14 minutes ago

docs.title: Step 2.3: Work on Your Task
docs.text:
Now do your actual work! For example:

  • Edit files in your editor
  • Run tests
  • Write documentation
  • Code features

Project-specific commands:

# For R packages
rload        # Load package
rtest        # Run tests
rdoc         # Generate docs

# For development projects
npm test     # Run tests
npm run build # Build project

# Git workflow
gst          # Check status (git status)
ga .         # Stage changes (git add .)
gcmsg "msg"  # Commit (git commit -m "msg")

docs.title: Step 2.4: Log Your Wins
docs.text:
When you accomplish something:

win "Completed first Flow tutorial"

What happened: Your accomplishment is logged to track progress.

docs.title: Checkpoint
docs.text:
At this point, you should have:

  • [x] Started a focus timer
  • [x] Checked your context
  • [x] Done actual work
  • [x] Logged at least one win

Verify:

wins
# Expected: See your logged wins for today

docs.title: Step 3.1: Update Your Progress
docs.text:
Before ending, update the project status:

status .

What happened: Flow asks for updates interactively:

📋 UPDATE STATUS: flow-cli
═══════════════════════════════════════════

Current values shown in [brackets]

Status? [active]
   (active/paused/blocked/ready)
> active

Priority? [P0]
   (P0=critical, P1=important, P2=normal)
> P0

Next task? [Documentation improvements]
> Complete tutorial files

Progress? [95]
   (0-100)
> 100

✅ Updated! Press Enter to continue...

Tip: Press Enter to keep current values, only type when you want to change something

docs.title: Step 3.2: Commit Your Changes
docs.text:
If you made code changes, commit them:

gst          # Check what changed
gaa          # Stage all changes
gcmsg "docs: add first session tutorial"
gp           # Push to remote

docs.title: Step 3.3: View Today's Wins
docs.text:
See what you accomplished:

wins

What happened: Lists all wins you logged today:

🎉 TODAY'S WINS (2025-12-24)
═══════════════════════════════════════════
1. ✅ Completed first Flow tutorial
2. ✅ Updated project documentation

💪 Great work today!

docs.title: Understanding Session Tracking
docs.text:
Flow CLI tracks your work sessions in ~/.config/zsh/.worklog:

Field Meaning project Current project name start_time When you started working duration How long you've been working task What you're currently doing

This helps you:

  • Remember where you left off
  • Track time spent on projects
  • Generate progress reports

docs.title: Putting It All Together
docs.text:
Here's the complete workflow you just learned:

# Morning: Start your day
dash                    # See all projects
just-start             # Auto-pick highest priority
work .                 # Open in editor

# During work
f25                    # Start 25-min timer
# ... do your work ...
win "Completed feature X"

# Check context if needed
why                    # Where am I? What am I doing?

# End of session
status .               # Update progress
gaa && gcmsg "msg"     # Commit changes
wins                   # See accomplishments

Time: <3 minutes to start/end, focused time in between

docs.title: Exercises
docs.text: Practice what you learned with these challenges:

docs.title: Exercise 1: Start a Session on a Different Project
docs.text:
Try starting a session on a different project.

Hint Use `work ` to switch projects, or `pick` for fuzzy search. Solution 
# Option 1: Direct name
work research-project

# Option 2: Fuzzy search
pick
# Type partial name, select with arrows, press Enter

# Option 3: Use dashboard
dash research        # Filter by category
work research-project

docs.title: Exercise 2: Update Multiple Projects
docs.text:
Update the status of 2-3 projects.

Solution 
status flow-cli active P0 "Next task" 100
status research-project paused P2 "Resume next week" 20
status stat-440 active P1 "Grade final exams" 80

# Verify
dash

docs.title: Exercise 3: Create a New Project
docs.text:
Create a .STATUS file for a new project.

Solution 
# Navigate to project
cd ~/projects/your-category/new-project

# Create .STATUS file
status new-project --create

# Answer prompts or use quick mode
status new-project ready P2 "Initial setup" 0

# Verify it appears in dashboard
dash

docs.title: "command not found: dash"
docs.text:
Cause: Flow CLI functions not loaded in your shell

Fix:

# Reload your shell configuration
source ~/.zshrc

# Or check if functions exist
ls ~/.config/zsh/functions/adhd-helpers.zsh

docs.title: "No projects found"
docs.text:
Cause: Projects not in expected locations or missing .STATUS files

Fix:

# Create .STATUS for existing projects
cd ~/projects/your-project
status your-project --create

# Check project structure
ls ~/projects/

docs.title: "Editor didn't open"
docs.text:
Cause: Project type not detected or editor not in PATH

Fix:

# Check project type
cd ~/projects/your-project
ls -la

# Manually open editor
code .     # VS Code
rstudio .  # RStudio
emacs .    # Emacs

docs.title: Summary
docs.text:
In this tutorial, you learned:

Concept What You Did Dashboard Viewed all projects with dash Auto-pick Let Flow choose with just-start Start work Opened project with work Focus timer Used f25 for Pomodoro Track wins Logged accomplishments with win Update status Used status to track progress Check context Used why to see current state

Key commands:

dash           # View all projects
just-start     # Auto-pick project
work .         # Open project
f25            # Start 25-min timer
why            # Check context
win "msg"      # Log accomplishment
wins           # See today's wins
status .       # Update progress

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
Continue your learning:

  1. Tutorial 2: Tracking Multiple Projects — Manage multiple active projects
  2. Tutorial 3: Using Status Visualizations — Understand progress bars and charts
  3. Workflow Quick Reference — Daily workflows

docs.title: Quick Reference
docs.text:
┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│  FIRST SESSION WORKFLOW                             │
├─────────────────────────────────────────────────────┤
│  dash          View all projects                    │
│  just-start    Auto-pick highest priority           │
│  work .        Open in editor                       │
│  f25           Start 25-min timer                   │
│  why           Check current context                │
│  win "..."     Log accomplishment                   │
│  status .      Update progress                      │
│  wins          See today's wins                     │
├─────────────────────────────────────────────────────┤
│  Workflow: dash → just-start → work → f25 → status │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

docs.title: Tutorial: Tracking Multiple Projects
docs.text:
What you'll build: Manage and switch between multiple active projects efficiently

Time: ~20 minutes | Level: Intermediate

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
Before starting, you should:

  • [ ] Completed: Tutorial 1: Your First Flow Session
  • [ ] Have 3+ projects in ~/projects/
  • [ ] Understand basic dash and status commands

Verify your setup:

# Check you have multiple projects
dash | grep -E "ACTIVE|READY"

# Should see at least 2-3 projects

docs.title: What You'll Learn
docs.text:
By the end of this tutorial, you will:

  1. Organize projects by category and priority
  2. Switch between projects efficiently
  3. Use filtering to focus on specific work
  4. Balance multiple projects without overwhelm

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Managing multiple projects is common - you might have:

  • Teaching + Research + Package development
  • Multiple client projects
  • Personal projects + Work projects

Flow CLI helps you juggle these without losing track:

┌──────────────┐     ┌──────────────┐     ┌──────────────┐
│  All Projects│ --> │Filter Category│ --> │ Work on One │
│   (dash)     │     │  (dash X)     │     │   (work X)   │
└──────────────┘     └──────────────┘     └──────────────┘

docs.title: Step 1.1: View All Projects
docs.text:
Start by seeing everything:

dash

What happened: You see projects grouped by status:

╭─────────────────────────────────────────────╮
│ 🎯 YOUR WORK DASHBOARD                      │
╰─────────────────────────────────────────────╯

🔥 ACTIVE NOW (5):
  📦 mediationverse [P0] 85% - Final simulations
  📚 stat-440 [P0] 60% - Grade midterms
  🔧 flow-cli [P1] 95% - Documentation
  📊 collider [P1] 90% - Waiting for review
  📦 medfit [P2] 30% - Add vignettes

📋 READY TO START (3):
  📊 product-of-three [P1] 60% - Review simulations
  📦 rmediation [P2] 0% - Add new feature
  📚 causal-inference [P2] 0% - Prep next semester

Note: Too many active projects? This is common - we'll fix it!

docs.title: Step 1.2: Filter by Category
docs.text:
Focus on one type of work:

# Teaching projects only
dash teaching

What happened: Shows only teaching-related projects:

╭─────────────────────────────────────────────╮
│ 🎯 TEACHING PROJECTS                        │
╰─────────────────────────────────────────────╯

🔥 ACTIVE (2):
  📚 stat-440 [P0] 60% - Grade midterms
  📚 causal-inference [P2] 0% - Prep next semester

Other category filters:

dash research      # Research projects only
dash packages      # R packages only
dash dev           # Development tools

docs.title: Step 1.3: Prioritize What Matters
docs.text:
Identify which projects should be active:

# View by priority
dash | grep P0     # Critical projects
dash | grep P1     # Important projects
dash | grep P2     # Normal projects

docs.title: Checkpoint
docs.text:
At this point, you should have:

  • [x] Viewed all projects
  • [x] Filtered by category
  • [x] Identified priorities

Verify:

# Count active projects
dash | grep "ACTIVE NOW" -A 20 | grep -c "%"
# Expected: Number of your active projects (should be 2-4 ideally)

docs.title: Step 2.1: Context-Based Switching
docs.text:
Switch based on what you're doing:

# Morning: Teaching focus
dash teaching
work stat-440

# Afternoon: Research focus
dash research
work collider

# Evening: Package development
dash packages
work mediationverse

docs.title: Step 2.2: Priority-Based Switching
docs.text:
Let Flow pick based on priority:

just-start

What happened: Flow selects the highest-priority project automatically:

🎲 Finding your next task...

┌─────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│ 🎯 DECISION MADE FOR YOU                    │
├─────────────────────────────────────────────┤
│ Project: 📚 stat-440                        │
│ Type:    teaching                           │
│ Reason:  P0 priority + active               │
│ Next:    Grade midterms                     │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────┘

How it picks:

  1. P0 + active (most urgent)
  2. P1 + active (important)
  3. Any active (current work)
  4. Most recent (what you touched last)

docs.title: Step 2.3: Manual Project Selection
docs.text:
Use the project picker for fuzzy search:

pick

What happened: Interactive fuzzy finder shows all projects. Type to filter:

> med_
  📦 mediationverse
  📦 medfit
  📦 rmediation
  📚 mediation-planning

Use arrow keys to select, press Enter to navigate.

docs.title: Step 2.4: Quick Navigation
docs.text:
For projects you know:

# Full name
work mediationverse

# Partial name (fuzzy match)
work med           # → mediationverse
work stat          # → stat-440
work coll          # → collider

docs.title: Checkpoint
docs.text:
At this point, you should have:

  • [x] Switched between categories
  • [x] Used priority-based selection
  • [x] Tried the project picker
  • [x] Navigated by name

Verify:

pwd
# Expected: You're in a different project than you started

docs.title: Step 3.1: Pause Projects
docs.text:
Too many active projects? Pause the less urgent ones:

# Pause a project
status medfit

Interactive prompt:

Status? [active]
> paused

Priority? [P2]
> P2

Next task? [Add vignettes]
> Resume when time allows

Progress? [30]
> 30

✅ Updated!

Or quick mode:

status medfit paused P2 "Resume later" 30

docs.title: Step 3.2: Reactivate Projects
docs.text:
When ready to resume:

status medfit active P1 "Add package vignettes" 30

docs.title: Step 3.3: Mark Projects as Blocked
docs.text:
If waiting on something:

status collider blocked P1 "Waiting for reviewer comments" 90

What happened: Project moves to BLOCKED section in dashboard:

🚫 BLOCKED (1):
  📊 collider [P1] 90% - Waiting for reviewer comments

docs.title: Step 3.4: Set Realistic Priorities
docs.text:
Review and adjust priorities:

# Critical (do today)
status mediationverse active P0 "Final simulations" 85

# Important (this week)
status product-of-three active P1 "Review sims" 60

# Normal (when you can)
status medfit paused P2 "Resume later" 30

Priority guidelines:

Priority Meaning How many? P0 Critical, urgent 1-2 max P1 Important 2-3 P2 Normal Unlimited

Warning: More than 2 P0 projects = everything is urgent = nothing is urgent

docs.title: Checkpoint
docs.text:
At this point, you should have:

  • [x] Paused at least one project
  • [x] Updated priorities realistically
  • [x] Marked a blocked project (if applicable)

Verify:

dash
# Expected: Fewer ACTIVE projects, some PAUSED/BLOCKED

docs.title: Workflow 1: Morning Routine (Teaching Day)
docs.text:
# 1. See teaching work
dash teaching

# 2. Auto-select highest priority
just-start

# 3. Start working
work .

# 4. Set focus timer
f25

Time: <30 seconds Result: Working on most important teaching task

docs.title: Workflow 2: Research Block
docs.text:
# 1. Filter research projects
dash research

# 2. Pick specific project
work collider

# 3. Long focus session
f50

# 4. Work, then update
status . active P1 "Completed analysis" 95

Time: <20 seconds Result: Focused research session

docs.title: Workflow 3: Package Development
docs.text:
# 1. View R packages
dash packages

# 2. Select by name
work mediationverse

# 3. R package workflow
rload
rtest
rdoc

# 4. Commit progress
gaa && gcmsg "feat: add new mediator"
status . active P0 "Testing complete" 90

Time: Varies by development Result: Incremental package progress

docs.title: Workflow 4: Weekly Review
docs.text:
# 1. See everything
dash

# 2. Review each category
dash teaching
dash research
dash packages

# 3. Update all statuses
status stat-440 active P0 "Grade finals" 80
status collider blocked P1 "Waiting" 90
status mediationverse active P0 "Almost done" 95

# 4. Pause what you can't do this week
status medfit paused P2 "Next week" 30

Time: 5-10 minutes weekly Result: Realistic priorities set

docs.title: Workflow 5: Context Switching
docs.text:
When interrupted:

# 1. Update current project
status . paused P0 "Resume after meeting" 75

# 2. Switch to urgent task
just-start

# 3. Work on it
work .
f25

# 4. Return to original
work mediationverse
status . active P0 "Resume work" 75

docs.title: Exercise 1: Balance Your Projects
docs.text:
Review your active projects and balance them.

Goal: 2-4 active projects max, rest paused/ready

Hint Run `dash`, count active projects. Pause anything not P0/P1 or not immediately actionable. Solution 
# 1. View current state
dash

# 2. Pause low-priority active projects
status medfit paused P2 "Do later" 30
status causal-inference paused P2 "Next semester" 0

# 3. Keep only critical/important active
status mediationverse active P0 "Final push" 85
status stat-440 active P0 "Urgent grading" 60
status flow-cli active P1 "Documentation" 95

# 4. Verify
dash
# Should see 2-4 active, rest paused

docs.title: Exercise 2: Category-Based Day
docs.text:
Plan a day focusing on one category.

Solution 
# Morning: Teaching focus
dash teaching
work stat-440
f50
# ... work ...
status . active P0 "Graded 20 exams" 70

# Afternoon: Research focus
dash research
work collider
f50
# ... work ...
status . active P1 "Finished analysis" 95

# Evening: Package development
dash packages
work mediationverse
f25
# ... work ...
status . active P0 "All tests pass" 90

docs.title: Exercise 3: Emergency Project
docs.text:
Handle an urgent new project without losing track of current work.

Solution 
# 1. Pause current project
cd ~/projects/current-project
status . paused P1 "Emergency interrupt - resume ASAP" 60

# 2. Create new urgent project
cd ~/projects/urgent-project
status urgent-project --create
status urgent-project active P0 "Critical fix" 0

# 3. Work on it
work .
# ... fix the issue ...
status . active P0 "Fixed critical bug" 100

# 4. Mark complete and return
status . ready P2 "Done - archive if needed" 100

# 5. Resume original work
work current-project
status . active P1 "Resume work" 60

docs.title: "Too many active projects"
docs.text:
Cause: Everything marked as active

Fix:

# Pause non-urgent projects
dash | grep ACTIVE
# Pick 2-3 most important
# Pause the rest
status project-name paused P2 "Do later" X

docs.title: "Can't decide what to work on"
docs.text:
Cause: Unclear priorities

Fix:

# Let Flow decide
just-start

# Or filter and pick
dash teaching      # Focus on one category
work stat-440      # Pick the urgent one

docs.title: "Switching too frequently"
docs.text:
Cause: No time blocks

Fix:

# Set category-based time blocks
# Morning: Teaching
dash teaching && work . && f50

# Afternoon: Research
dash research && work . && f50

# Use timers to enforce focus

docs.title: Summary
docs.text:
In this tutorial, you learned:

Concept What You Did Filtering Used dash <category> to focus Switching Used work, pick, just-start States Paused, blocked, activated projects Priorities Set P0/P1/P2 realistically Workflows Category-based and priority-based

Key commands:

dash <category>    # Filter by category
just-start         # Auto-pick by priority
pick               # Fuzzy search projects
work <name>        # Switch to project
status . paused    # Pause current
status . active    # Activate project
status . blocked   # Mark blocked

Key insights:

  • 2-4 active projects max - Rest should be paused/ready
  • Use categories - Focus time on one area
  • Let Flow pick - Reduces decision fatigue
  • Update statuses - Keeps dashboard accurate

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
Continue your learning:

  1. Tutorial 3: Using Status Visualizations — Understand progress bars and charts
  2. Tutorial 4: Web Dashboard Deep Dive — Use the browser-based dashboard
  3. Workflow Quick Reference — Advanced workflows

docs.title: Quick Reference
docs.text:
┌───────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│  MULTIPLE PROJECTS WORKFLOW                           │
├───────────────────────────────────────────────────────┤
│  dash              View all projects                  │
│  dash <category>   Filter by category                 │
│  just-start        Auto-pick highest priority         │
│  pick              Fuzzy search all projects          │
│  work <name>       Switch to specific project         │
│  status . paused   Pause current project              │
│  status . active   Activate project                   │
│  status . blocked  Mark as blocked                    │
├───────────────────────────────────────────────────────┤
│  Priorities:                                          │
│    P0 = Critical (1-2 max)                            │
│    P1 = Important (2-3)                               │
│    P2 = Normal (unlimited)                            │
├───────────────────────────────────────────────────────┤
│  Golden Rule: Keep 2-4 active max, pause the rest!   │
└───────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

docs.title: Tutorial: Using Status Visualizations
docs.text:
What you'll build: Understanding and using visual progress indicators effectively

Time: ~15 minutes | Level: Intermediate

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
Before starting, you should:

  • [ ] Completed: Tutorial 2: Tracking Multiple Projects
  • [ ] Have projects with progress tracked (0-100%)
  • [ ] Understand basic status command

Verify your setup:

# Check you have projects with progress
dash | grep "%"

# Should see percentage values for projects

docs.title: What You'll Learn
docs.text:
By the end of this tutorial, you will:

  1. Read and interpret progress bars
  2. Use progress tracking to stay motivated
  3. Understand project metrics and statistics
  4. Create accurate progress estimates

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Flow CLI uses visual indicators to make progress tangible:

┌───────────────┐     ┌───────────────┐     ┌───────────────┐
│  Update %     │ --> │  See Progress │ --> │ Stay Motivated│
│  (status)     │     │   (dash)      │     │   (wins)      │
└───────────────┘     └───────────────┘     └───────────────┘

Visual feedback helps ADHD-friendly workflows by:

  • Making abstract progress concrete
  • Providing dopamine hits when bars fill up
  • Showing momentum across multiple projects

docs.title: Step 1.1: Basic Progress Display
docs.text:
View a project's progress:

dash

What you'll see:

🔥 ACTIVE NOW (3):
  📦 mediationverse [P0] 85% - Final simulations
  📚 stat-440 [P1] 60% - Grade midterms
  🔧 flow-cli [P2] 95% - Documentation

Progress breakdown:

Range Color Meaning 0-25% Red Just started 26-50% Yellow Making progress 51-75% Cyan Over halfway 76-99% Green Almost done 100% Bright Green Complete!

docs.title: Step 1.2: Detailed Progress Bars
docs.text:
Some commands show full progress bars:

# View detailed status (if implemented)
status mediationverse --show

What you might see:

📦 mediationverse
═══════════════════════════════════════════

Status:   🔥 ACTIVE
Priority: [P0] Critical
Progress: ████████████████░░░░ 85%
Task:     Final simulations
Updated:  2025-12-24

Recent progress:
  Dec 20: 60% → 70% (+10%)
  Dec 22: 70% → 80% (+10%)
  Dec 24: 80% → 85% (+5%)

docs.title: Step 1.3: Category Summaries
docs.text:
See aggregate progress:

dash teaching

What you'll see:

╭─────────────────────────────────────────────╮
│ 🎯 TEACHING PROJECTS (2)                    │
│ Average progress: 45%                       │
╰─────────────────────────────────────────────╯

🔥 ACTIVE (2):
  📚 stat-440 [P0] 60% - Grade midterms
  📚 causal-inference [P2] 30% - Prep syllabus

docs.title: Checkpoint
docs.text:
At this point, you should understand:

  • [x] Progress percentage colors
  • [x] How to view progress in dashboard
  • [x] What different ranges mean

Verify:

dash | grep "%"
# Expected: See projects with different progress levels

docs.title: Step 2.1: Starting a New Project (0%)
docs.text:
When starting fresh:

cd ~/projects/new-project
status new-project --create
status new-project ready P2 "Initial setup" 0

What happened: Project created at 0%:

📋 READY TO START (1):
  📊 new-project [P2] 0% - Initial setup

docs.title: Step 2.2: Small Incremental Updates
docs.text:
Update progress in small chunks:

# First day: Basic setup
status new-project active P2 "Setup environment" 10

# Next day: Start coding
status new-project active P2 "First feature" 25

# Week later: Halfway
status new-project active P2 "Core complete" 50

Why small increments?

  • More accurate than big jumps
  • More frequent dopamine hits
  • Easier to estimate remaining work

docs.title: Step 2.3: The 80-20 Rule
docs.text:
Many projects follow this pattern:

0-80%:   Fast progress (easy work)
80-95%:  Slow progress (hard/tedious work)
95-100%: Very slow (polish, edge cases)

Example progression:

# Week 1-2: Fast progress
status project active P1 "Core features" 80

# Week 3: Slows down
status project active P1 "Bug fixes" 85

# Week 4: Tedious work
status project active P1 "Edge cases" 90

# Week 5: Final polish
status project active P1 "Documentation" 95

# Week 6: Complete
status project ready P2 "Done!" 100

Tip: Don't be discouraged when 80-100% takes as long as 0-80%!

docs.title: Step 2.4: Progress Milestones
docs.text:
Set checkpoints:

Progress Milestone Task Example 0% Planning "Define scope and requirements" 25% Foundation "Basic setup complete" 50% Core "Main features implemented" 75% Integration "Everything connected" 90% Polish "Bug fixes and cleanup" 100% Done "Ready for release"

docs.title: Checkpoint
docs.text:
At this point, you should:

  • [x] Know how to track new projects
  • [x] Understand incremental updates
  • [x] Recognize the 80-20 pattern

Verify:

# Update a project with new milestone
status . active P1 "Reached 75% milestone" 75
dash
# Expected: See updated progress

docs.title: Step 3.1: Celebrate Progress
docs.text:
When you cross milestones:

# Hit 50%!
status . active P0 "Halfway done!" 50
win "Reached 50% on mediationverse package!"

# Hit 75%!
status . active P0 "Almost there!" 75
win "75% complete - final push!"

# Hit 100%!
status . ready P2 "Complete!" 100
win "COMPLETED mediationverse package!!!"

docs.title: Step 3.2: Track Velocity
docs.text:
How fast are you progressing?

# Monday
status project active P1 "Start work" 10

# Friday
status project active P1 "Week complete" 30

# Velocity: 20% per week
# Estimate: 3.5 weeks to complete (70% remaining / 20% per week)

Track in your task description:

status project active P1 "Week 2 - on track (+20%)" 30

docs.title: Step 3.3: Use Visual Momentum
docs.text:
Seeing multiple projects advance creates momentum:

# Before (Monday)
dash
# mediationverse: 65%
# stat-440: 40%
# flow-cli: 80%

# After (Friday)
dash
# mediationverse: 75% ⬆️ +10%
# stat-440: 60% ⬆️ +20%
# flow-cli: 90% ⬆️ +10%

win "Productive week! All projects advanced!"

docs.title: Step 3.4: Handle Setbacks
docs.text:
Sometimes progress goes backward:

# Discovered major bug, need to redo work
status project active P0 "Fix critical bug - set back" 70

# Previous was 85%, now 70% (-15%)

This is OK! Accurate progress > inflated numbers.

docs.title: Checkpoint
docs.text:
At this point, you should:

  • [x] Celebrate milestones with win
  • [x] Track velocity (% per week)
  • [x] Use visual momentum
  • [x] Handle setbacks honestly

Verify:

wins
# Expected: See celebration wins for milestones

docs.title: Technique 1: Sub-Project Breakdown
docs.text:
For large projects, track components:

# Main project
status mediationverse active P0 "Package development" 75

# Mental breakdown (not tracked in tool):
# - Core functions: 90% (mostly done)
# - Tests: 80% (good coverage)
# - Documentation: 60% (needs work)
# - Vignettes: 50% (in progress)
# Average: (90+80+60+50)/4 = 70%

# Update based on weighted average
status mediationverse active P0 "Focus on docs/vignettes" 70

docs.title: Technique 2: Must-Have vs Nice-to-Have
docs.text:
Adjust progress based on scope:

# Original plan (100% = everything)
status project active P1 "All features" 60

# Scope reduction (100% = must-haves only)
status project active P1 "Core features only" 85

# Suddenly much closer to done!

docs.title: Technique 3: Time-Based vs Work-Based
docs.text:
Two ways to track:

Time-based (not recommended):

# Week 1 of 10 = 10%
status project active P1 "Week 1" 10

Work-based (recommended):

# 3 of 10 features done = 30%
status project active P1 "3/10 features" 30

Tip: Work-based is more accurate because work rarely distributes evenly over time.

docs.title: Technique 4: Done is Better Than Perfect
docs.text:
Don't wait for 100% perfection:

# 95% complete, could polish forever
status project active P1 "Good enough to ship" 95

# Ship it!
status project ready P2 "Shipped v1.0!" 100
win "Shipped project v1.0 - done is better than perfect!"

# Future improvements are a new project
status project-v2 ready P2 "Enhancements for v2" 0

docs.title: Exercise 1: Estimate a New Project
docs.text:
Break down and estimate a new project.

Hint List all major tasks, estimate time for each, calculate total, set milestones. Solution 
# New R package project
cd ~/projects/r-packages/active/newpackage

# Break down tasks:
# 1. Setup (5%) - 1 day
# 2. Core functions (30%) - 1 week
# 3. Tests (20%) - 3 days
# 4. Documentation (20%) - 3 days
# 5. Vignettes (15%) - 2 days
# 6. Final checks (10%) - 1 day

# Start tracking
status newpackage ready P2 "Planning complete" 0

# After setup
status newpackage active P1 "Package skeleton created" 5

# After core
status newpackage active P1 "Main functions working" 35

# Continue incrementally...

docs.title: Exercise 2: Recover from Setback
docs.text:
Handle a project that went backwards.

Solution 
# Before: thought you were at 80%
status project active P0 "Found major issue" 80

# After analysis: need to redo significant work
status project active P0 "Revising approach - realistic reset" 60

# Document why
win "Discovered issue early - better to fix now than later"

# Make steady progress forward
status project active P0 "Fixed root cause" 70
status project active P0 "Re-implemented correctly" 80
status project active P0 "Validated thoroughly" 90
status project ready P2 "Done right this time!" 100

docs.title: Exercise 3: Celebrate Milestones
docs.text:
Track and celebrate a project's key milestones.

Solution 
# 0%: Start
status project active P1 "Project started" 0
win "Started new project - excited to build this!"

# 25%: Foundation
status project active P1 "Foundation solid" 25
win "25% complete - strong foundation!"

# 50%: Halfway
status project active P1 "Halfway there!" 50
win "50% COMPLETE! - past the hardest part!"

# 75%: Polish phase
status project active P1 "Polishing now" 75
win "75% done - can see the finish line!"

# 100%: Complete
status project ready P2 "DONE!" 100
win "PROJECT COMPLETE! Shipped and proud!"

# View all celebrations
wins

docs.title: "Progress seems stuck"
docs.text:
Cause: Working on 80-100% phase (slow progress)

Fix:

# Break down remaining work into smaller tasks
# Update more frequently with smaller increments

# Instead of jumping from 85% to 90%:
status . active P1 "Fixed bug #1" 86
status . active P1 "Fixed bug #2" 87
status . active P1 "Added validation" 88

# Smaller wins feel better!

docs.title: "Not sure what percentage to use"
docs.text:
Cause: Unclear milestones

Fix:

# Use concrete milestones:
# 0%   = Planning
# 10%  = Setup complete
# 25%  = First feature working
# 50%  = Core features done
# 75%  = All features implemented
# 90%  = Testing/polish
# 100% = Complete and shipped

# Estimate based on work done vs work remaining

docs.title: "Progress feels arbitrary"
docs.text:
Cause: Not tracking concrete deliverables

Fix:

# Track specific completions:
status . active P1 "3 of 10 functions complete" 30
status . active P1 "7 of 15 tests passing" 47
status . active P1 "2 of 4 vignettes written" 80

# % = (completed / total) * 100

docs.title: Summary
docs.text:
In this tutorial, you learned:

Concept What You Did Progress ranges Understood 0-25%, 26-50%, 51-75%, 76-99%, 100% Incremental tracking Updated in small chunks for accuracy The 80-20 rule Expected 80-100% to be slow Milestones Set and celebrated progress markers Motivation Used visual progress for dopamine Estimates Broke down work to calculate %

Key insights:

# Track progress incrementally
status . active P1 "Task complete (+5%)" 35

# Celebrate milestones
win "Reached 50%!"

# Be honest about setbacks
status . active P0 "Reset to fix properly" 60

# Ship at 95-100%, don't wait for perfection
status . ready P2 "Good enough!" 100

Progress tips:

  • Small increments - 5-10% updates feel more concrete
  • Celebrate milestones - 25%, 50%, 75%, 100%
  • Accept setbacks - Accurate % > inflated numbers
  • Ship it - 95%+ is often "done enough"

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
Continue your learning:

  1. Tutorial 4: Web Dashboard Deep Dive — Use browser-based visualizations
  2. Command Reference: status — Complete status command guide
  3. Workflows & Quick Wins — Advanced productivity tips

docs.title: Tutorial: Web Dashboard Deep Dive
docs.text:
What you'll build: Using the browser-based dashboard for rich visualizations

Time: ~20 minutes | Level: Advanced

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
Before starting, you should:

  • [ ] Completed: Tutorial 3: Using Status Visualizations
  • [ ] Have Node.js installed (for web dashboard)
  • [ ] Have multiple projects tracked with progress
  • [ ] Comfortable with terminal commands

Verify your setup:

# Check Node.js is installed
node --version

# Should see v18+ or v20+

# Check Flow CLI is installed
which flow

docs.title: What You'll Learn
docs.text:
By the end of this tutorial, you will:

  1. Launch and navigate the web dashboard
  2. Use interactive visualizations
  3. Filter and search projects
  4. Monitor real-time session data
  5. Export and share dashboard views

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
The web dashboard provides rich browser-based visualizations:

┌────────────────┐     ┌────────────────┐     ┌────────────────┐
│  Launch        │ --> │  Interactive   │ --> │  Take Actions  │
│  (flow dash)   │     │  Explore       │     │  (terminal)    │
└────────────────┘     └────────────────┘     └────────────────┘

Benefits over terminal dashboard:

  • Charts and graphs (bar, line, pie)
  • Mouse/touch interaction
  • Larger screen real estate
  • Persistent view while you work
  • Shareable URLs

docs.title: Step 1.1: Start the Web Server
docs.text:
Launch the dashboard:

flow dashboard --web

What happened: A web server starts and opens your browser:
